questions.text: As a resident in the neonatal intensive care unit, you receive a 34-week pre-term neonate weighing 1400g. While administering 3L of oxygen in an incubator, you're instructed to monitor ABGs and avoid exceeding 5L of oxygen to prevent the development of which conditions?
questions.solution:
Option D: Retrolental Fibroplasia

  • High oxygen concentration in pre-term low-birth-weight neonates is associated with an increased incidence of retrolental fibroplasia (also known as retinopathy of prematurity[ROP]).
  • It is believed that if arterial oxygen is kept within prescribed guidelines, ROP can be prevented.
  • However, with the neonatologists’ ability to keep alive very LBW neonates, there has been a resurgence of ROP despite tight control of partial pressure of oxygen.
  • In response to the high oxygen concentration, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) has been shown to contribute to neovascularization and abnormal intra-retinal vascular patterns in the retinal periphery.
  • This sequence of events leads to retrolental fibroplasia in 85% - 90% of the neonates exposed to high oxygen concentration.
  • Some yet-to-be-determined factors cause the process to regress in a large percentage of eyes. However, only a small percentage of these neonates develop blindness later in life owing to retinal detachment.

Option C: Coloboma Iridis

  • Coloboma iridis is a congenital anomaly derived from failed or incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure (also known as choroidal fissure or optic fissure). It is not associated with oxygen concentration in premature LBW neonates.
  • Multiple genetic and environmental factors in this period contribute to the causation of this anomaly, including maternal alcohol intake during pregnancy and vitamin A deficiency.
  • Treatment strategies include contact lenses or glasses, surgery, low vision aids, and an eye patch or eye drops.

Option A: Congenital Glaucoma

  • Congenital glaucoma is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder diagnosed at birth rather than being diagnosed in LBW pre-term neonates exposed to high oxygen concentrations.
  • It is also called Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) and is characterized by isolated abnormalities of the iridocorneal angle that leads to decreased aqueous outflow and elevated IOP.
  • The classic signs of PCG are tearing, photophobia, lid squeezing, and a cloudy cornea.
  • These signs may be unilateral or bilateral and are all due to elevated IOP.
  • Infants affected with PCG often have markedly enlarged eyes called Buphthalmos. After three years of age, elevated IOP will no longer cause the eye to enlarge.
  • PCG may cause severe optic neuropathy and profound vision loss until prompt treatment is provided. 

Option B: Microphthalmia

  • Microphthalmia is a congenital condition characterized by an eye smaller than normal at birth (< 15mm in the greatest dimension). It may be unilateral or bilateral and has no known association with high oxygen concentration in pre-term LBW babies.
  • Microphthalmia must be differentiated from atrophia bulbi, an acquired condition wherein a normal-sized eye at birth shrinks secondary to ocular disease.
  • There are four types of microphthalmia.
    • Pure microphthalmia - The eye is smaller than normal without any gross abnormalities.
    • Microphthalmia with a cyst
    • Microphthalmia is associated with other systemic anomalies (trisomy 13, congenital rubella)
    • Complicated microphthalmia - Extensive epibulbar choristoma associated with microphthalmia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with mild neck pain, a burning sensation in the middle finger, and a weak triceps reflex. Which level of slipped disc is suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: C6-C7

  • This is a radial nerve injury in which the middle finger is affected, and the triceps reflex is weak.
  • Compression of root C7, which is between C6 and C7 discs, is the cause of radial nerve compression.
  • The radial nerve innervates a small area of the skin over the lateral aspects of the metacarpal and the back of the first web space.
  • The radial nerve also produces extension of the wrist and the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • It also produces an extension of the digits.
  • The radial nerve is one of the largest branches of the posterior cord.
  • It usually passes out of the axilla.
  • From there, it goes into the posterior compartment of the arm while passing into the triangular space between the long head of the triceps brachii muscle, shaft of the humerus, and inferior border of the teres major muscle. It is accompanied by the triangular interval by the profound brachial vessel, which usually originates from the brachial artery in the anterior compartment of the arm.

Option B: C5-C6

  • It is a case of radial nerve injury, and the root of the radial nerve originates from C7, which is between the C6-C7 intervertebral disc.

Option C: C3-C4

  • It is a case of radial nerve injury, and the root of the radial nerve originates from C7, which is between the C6-C7 intervertebral disc.

Option D: C2-C3

  • It is a case of radial nerve injury, and the root of the radial nerve originates from C7, which is between the C6-C7 intervertebral disc.

questions.text: A 2-month-old male presents with hand spasms for 2 weeks and is noted to have characteristic facial features including short slanting palpebral fissures, flattened cheeks, prominent nasal tip, and a cleft palate. Which cardiac abnormalities are associated with this patient?

choices.text: Tetralogy of Fallot and patent truncus arteriosus
Atrial septal defects and ventricular septal defects

questions.solution:
Option A: Tetralogy of Fallot and Truncus arteriosus

  • DiGeorge syndrome is also known as 22q11 deletion syndrome.
  • It is due to abnormalities in neural crest cells development that lead to several malformations.
  • These children present with the following features:
    • Cardiac - Aortic arch anomalies, conotruncal anomalies (TOF, Truncus arteriosus, interrupted aorta), and tricuspid atresia
    • Abnormal facies - Hypertelorism, ear anomalies, short down slanting palpebral fissures (antimongoloid), short philtrum
    • Thymic hypoplasia - Cellular immune deficiency (Abnormal number and function of T-cells)
    • Cleft palate
    • Hypoparathyroidism with hypocalcemia leads to twitching and tetanic spasms (mostly in the hands and face).
  • Tetralogy of Fallot consists of four alterations: 
  • Pulmonary infundibular stenosis
  • Interventricular septal defect
  • Overriding of aorta
  • Hypertrophy of the right ventricular wall
  • Persistent truncus arteriosus occurs when the conotruncal ridges fail to divide the outflow tract. The undivided truncus overrides both the ventricles and receives blood from both sides.

Option B: Transposition of the great arteries

  • Transposition of the great arteries occurs when the conotruncal septum fails to follow its normal spiral course and runs straight down.
  • As a result, the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle.
  • It is associated with maternal diabetes.

Option C: Atrial septal defects and ventricular septal defects

  • Atrial septal defects (ASDs) and ventricular septal defects (VSDs) are present in individuals with Down syndrome and other trisomies.
  • They are not associated with DiGeorge syndrome.

Option D: Coarctation of the aorta

  • Coarctation of the aorta is the narrowing of a part of the aorta.
  • Coarctation of the aorta is related to Turner syndrome.
  • Aortic atresia is present in individuals with Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male basketball player is admitted to the hospital after injuring his shoulder during the game. Physical and radiographic examinations show the following injury, as noted in the following x-ray. Which of the following structures is most likely torn in this patient?

choices.text: Tendon of the long head of the biceps

questions.solution:
Option D: Acromioclavicular ligament

  • This patient's x-ray shows the dislocation of the acromioclavicular joint (AC).
  • The AC joint is a diarthrodial joint defined by the lateral process of the clavicle articulating with the acromion process as it projects anteriorly off the scapula.
  • The joint is primarily stabilized by the acromioclavicular ligament, composed of anterior, posterior, inferior, and superior components. 
  • The superior portion of the AC ligament is the most important component for the stability of the AC joint.
  • Supporting structures include two coracoclavicular ligaments (CC) (trapezoid and conoid ligaments), which provide vertical stability, as well as the coracoacromial ligament (AC).
  • AC injuries are frequently seen after sporting events, car accidents falling from a bicycle, and other sports-related activities.
  • The Rockwood classification remains the gold standard for driving treatment decisions and is an excellent tool for managing acromioclavicular joint injuries.
  • This patient has type III AC, and CC ligaments are torn; the clavicle has elevated above the border of the acromion, or there is an increase of 25% to 100% in the CC interspace compared to the contralateral.

.Option A: Glenohumeral ligament

  • The glenohumeral ligaments are thickening of the glenohumeral joint capsule and are involved in stabilizing the joint.

Option B: Coracoacromian ligament

  • The cricaoacromian ligament is an integral component of the coracoacromial arch. 
  • The coracoacromial ligament prevents overlapping of the humeral head.

Option C: Tendon of the long head of the biceps

  • It is involved in the flexion of the forearm.
  • It has no role in the stabilization of the shoulder joint.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain for 3 months. Physical examination reveals an enlarged and asymmetrical uterus with multiple non-tender masses. Ultrasound confirms uterine fibroids. The gynaecologist recommends uterine artery embolization. Which statement accurately describes pelvic arterial supply?

choices.text: The common iliac artery divides over the sacroiliac joint
The external iliac artery divides into anterior and posterior branches
The ovarian artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery
The inferior epigastric artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
Option A: The common iliac artery divides over the sacroiliac joint

  • In the clinical scenario, the patient presented with uterine fibroids.
  • These are also known as leiomyomas, which are smooth muscle growths of the uterine myometrium.
  • They are benign and occur in women between 20 and 40.
  • Symptoms include abnormal uterine bleeding, iron deficiency anaemia, pain, constipation and urinary frequency.
  • These tumours are sensitive to estrogen.
  • Physical examination shows that the uterus is enlarged, firm, asymmetric, non-tender and has multiple tumours.
  • It is confirmed with a sonogram.
  • The treatment plan may include uterine artery embolization and surgical resection (myectomy, hysterectomy).
  • The abdominal aorta divides into the right and left common iliac arteries anterolateral to the left side of the body of the fourth lumbar vertebra.
  • These arteries separate as they descend and divide into external and internal iliac arteries at the sacroiliac joint level.
  • In addition, each common iliac artery gives small branches to the peritoneum, psoas major, ureter, adjacent nerves and surrounding areolar tissue.
  • The external iliac artery is the chief artery of the lower limb.
  • The internal iliac artery provides the principal supply to the walls and viscera of the pelvis, the perineum and the gluteal region.
  • There are two common iliac arteries: the right common iliac and the left common iliac. The right is longer than the left one.

Option B: The external iliac artery divides into anterior and posterior branches

  • The internal iliac artery branches off into the anterior and posterior trunk as it descends posteriorly to the superior margin of the greater sciatic foramen.
  • In contrast, each external iliac artery descends midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis and enters the thigh posterior to the inguinal ligament to become the femoral artery.

The external iliac artery has no branches until it gives off the deep circumflex iliac and inferior epigastric arteries near the point it passes under the inguinal ligament.

Option D: The inferior epigastric artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery

  • The inferior epigastric artery originates from the external iliac artery posterior to the inguinal ligament.
  • It curves forward in the anterior intraperitoneal tissue and ascends obliquely along the medial margin of the deep inguinal ring. From here, it continues as an artery of the anterior abdominal wall.

Option C: The ovarian artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery

  • The ovarian artery emerges from the abdominal part of the aorta at the level of the first lumbar vertebra. It is long and slender and passes downward and laterally behind the peritoneum.
  • It crosses the external iliac artery at the pelvic inlet and enters the suspensory ligament of the ovary. It then passes into the broad ligament and enters the ovary through the mesovarium.

questions.text: Which artery is the main vascular supply to the ankle bone?
questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior tibial

  • The posterior tibial artery arises as a terminal branch of the popliteal artery between the tibia and fibula at the level of the lower margin of the popliteus muscle.
  • It takes an inferomedial course, descending through the leg's posterior (flexor) compartment. 
  • The artery enters the foot by passing inferiorly to the medial malleolus. Midway between the malleolus and the tubercle of calcaneus, it ends by splitting into the lateral and medial plantar arteries.
  • The posterior tibial artery provides most of the arterial supply for the neck and body of the talus bone. Much of the blood supply of this bone can be lost in an injury to this vessel and can result in osteonecrosis.

Option B: Anterior tibial

  • The anterior tibial artery is responsible for the blood supply of the anterior compartment of the leg

Option C: Dorsalis pedis

  • The Dorsalis Pedis is the continuation of the Anterior Tibial Artery on the dorsum of the foot. It Does not supply the ankle.

Option D: Lateral plantar

  • The Medial Plantar and Lateral Plantar branches of the Posterior Tibial Artery are distributed to tissues on the plantar surface of the foot.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presents with pelvic pain and pressure, along with menstrual irregularities. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a large mass on the pelvic brim. Which structure is likely compressed by this mass while crossing the pelvic brim?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lumbosacral trunk

  • The structures above do not cross the pelvic brim except the lumbosacral trunk.
  • The pelvic region is divided into two:
  • Greater pelvis (false pelvis): It is located superiorly.
  • Lesser pelvis (True pelvis): It is located inferiorly.
  • The junction between the greater and lesser pelvis is known as the pelvic inlet, while the outer bony edges of the pelvic inlet are called the pelvic brim.
  • The pelvic brim is formed by sacral promontory posteriorly, iliopectineal line laterally, and symphysis pubis anteriorly.
  • Mass at the pelvic brim can compress various structures depending on size and location.
  • These masses can cause compression of the urinary bladder, femoral nerve injury, and lumbosacral plexopathy.
  • The lumbosacral trunk crosses the pelvic brim.
  • It arises from L4 and L5, enters the true pelvis by crossing the pelvic brim, and contributes to the formation of the sacral plexus.
  • The first sacral nerve is joined by the nerve fibers that cross the pelvic brim on the medial side of the psoas major muscle.

Option A:  Ovarian artery

  • After emerging from the abdominal aorta at the level of L2, the ovarian artery travels down the suspensory ligament of the ovary.
  • It enters the mesovarium and anastomoses with the uterine artery in the broad ligament.
  • As it is inside the ligament and mesovarium, it is less likely to be compressed than the lumbosacral trunk.

Option B: Uterine tube

  • Uterine tubes (fallopian tubes) connect ovaries to the uterus.
  • They lie in the upper border of the broad ligament within the true pelvis and do not cross the pelvic brim.

Option C: Ovarian ligament

  • Ovarian ligaments attach ovaries to the uterus.
  • It does not cross the pelvic brim.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with malaise, fever, dysphagia, sialorrhea, difficulty opening his mouth, dehydration, trismus, and muscle rigidity. A generalized tetanus infection is suspected. All of the following muscles elevate the jaw and close the mouth except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lateral pterygoid

  • The primary function of the lateral pterygoid muscle is to pull the head of the condyle out of the mandibular fossa along the articular eminence to protrude the mandible.
  • A concerted effort of the lateral pterygoid muscles helps lower the mandible and open the jaw.
  • Unlike the other three muscles of mastication, the lateral pterygoid alone can assist in depressing the mandible (opening the jaw). At the beginning of this action, it is assisted by the digastric, mylohyoid, and geniohyoid muscles.
  • Pterygoid branches of the maxillary artery supply the lateral pterygoid muscle.
  • The lateral pterygoid muscle is supplied by the lateral pterygoid nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3), itself a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).

Option A: Masseter

  • The masseter muscle is one of the four muscles responsible for the action of mastication (chewing).
  • When the masseter contracts, it causes powerful mandible elevation, causing the mouth to close.
  • Its insertion along the angle and lateral surface of the ramus also allows it to aid in the mandible's protrusion, allowing for the jaw's anterior motion.

Option B: Temporalis

  • The temporalis muscle functions to move the mandible, which is the official term for the lower jaw. Specifically, the movements of the lower jaw caused by the temporalis muscle include:
  • Elevation
  • Retraction
  • Side-to-side
  • Based on these movements, the temporalis muscle plays a large role in biting and chewing food. As a person opens their mouth and bites down on a piece of food, the temporalis muscle contracts, causing the lower jaw to elevate and the jaws to close. Once the piece of food is in the mouth, the temporalis muscle then repeatedly contracts to move the lower jaw up, backward, and side-to-side, which allows the jaws to chew and grind the food with the teeth.

Option D: Medial pterygoid

  • The function of the medial pterygoid, while contracting bilaterally, produces elevation and protrusion of the mandible; unilaterally contracted, it produces contralateral excursion.
  • It pulls the ramus of the mandible medially and shifts the mandible toward the contralateral side.
  • In addition, the medial pterygoid and the masseter muscle form a muscular sling that supports the mandible at the mandibular angle and empowers their elevator strength. Simultaneous contractions of these muscles can exert a powerful biting force and mastication.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male is brought to the emergency ward unconscious. His son reports a previous stroke 2 months ago and recent complete unconsciousness for 1 hour. On examination, absent carotid and radial pulses, no breath or heart sounds, and dilated non-reactive pupils are noted. The doctor tests the corneal reflex using a wisp of cotton. What is the efferent limb of this reflex mediated by?
questions.solution:
Option B: Facial nerve

  • This is a case of cerebrovascular stroke.
  • The patient was in nursing care when he suddenly collapsed, most likely due to cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • Corneal reflex: The reflex is mediated by the nasociliary branch of the ophthalmic branch (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), sensing the stimulus on the cornea only (afferent fibre). The temporal and zygomatic branches of the facial nerve (CN VII) initiate the motor response (efferent fibre).
  • The corneal reflex, also known as the blink reflex, is an involuntary blinking of the eyelids elicited by stimulating the cornea (such as by touching or by a foreign body).
  • The facial nerve (CN VII) provides the efferent limb of the corneal reflex (orbicularis oculi muscle).

Option A: Accessory nerve

  • It is an incorrect option because the facial nerve (CN VII) provides the efferent limb of the corneal reflex (orbicularis oculi muscle).

Option C: Glossopharyngeal nerve

  • It is an incorrect option because the facial nerve (CN VII) provides the efferent limb of the corneal reflex (orbicularis oculi muscle).

Option D: Trigeminal nerve

  • It is an incorrect option because the facial nerve (CN VII) provides the efferent limb of the corneal reflex (orbicularis oculi muscle).

questions.text: A child presents with defects in skull bones, wide-set eyes, a murmur, poor muscle tone, respiratory difficulties, frequent infections, and feeding issues. Suspecting DiGeorge syndrome, which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: CNS defects

  • DiGeorge syndrome is also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.
  • Infants with DiGeorge syndrome are born without a thymus and parathyroid glands and have defects and cardiac outflow tracts.
  • It occurs due to failure of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches differentiation.
  • This results from a breakdown in signaling between pharyngeal endoderm and adjacent neural crest cells.
  • It includes:-
    • Cardiac defects
    • Pharyngeal arch bone defects
    • Skull defects
    • And hypoparathyroidism and immunodeficiency due to the absence of the thymus.
    • CNS defects are not part of DiGeorge syndrome; it will not help diagnose It.

Option A: Skull defects

  • It is a part of DiGeorge syndrome, and it will help in its diagnosis.

Option C: Pharyngeal arch bone defects

  • It is a part of DiGeorge syndrome and will help diagnose it.

Option D: Cardiac defects

  • It is a part of DiGeorge syndrome.
  • CNS defects are not associated with DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male visits the hospital with a complaint of fecal incontinence for the last 3 weeks. His history is significant for a lower back injury 1 month back. On examination, he is found to have a toneless external anal sphincter. Which of the following nerve roots innervate the external anal sphincter?
questions.solution:
Option A: S2, S3, S4

  • This patient with a history of back injury, toneless sphincter, and fecal incontinence most likely has an injury to the nerve roots supplying the external anal sphincter.
  • The external anal sphincter is supplied by the inferior anal nerve, a branch of the pudendal nerve, having root values S2, S3, and S4.
  • Injury to these nerve roots results in a toneless sphincter leading to fecal incontinence.

Option B: L5, S1

  • These nerve roots are most commonly compressed in the lower back leading to backache and leg pain.

Option C: S1, S2

  • These nerve roots are responsible for the ankle jerk.

Option D: L3, L4

  • These nerve roots are responsible for the knee jerk. They supply muscles of the lower leg.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the surface marking of parietal pleura?

choices.text: The right and left pleura come into contact in the midline at the level of the jugular notch (suprasternal notch).
The pleura's apex is at the clavicle's level.
The right pleura passes across the 10th rib in the anterior axillary line.
The left pleura arches laterally at the level of the 4th costal cartilage.

questions.solution:
Option D: The left pleura arches laterally at the level of the 4th costal cartilage.

  • The chest wall and the mediastinum are lined by the parietal pleura.
  • The parietal pleura encloses the pleural cavity.
  • The thoracic inlet has the following boundaries: the oblique first rib laterally and an apex which lies 2.5cm above the medial third of the clavicle behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • The pleura runs downward from the apex, forming a convex shape at the sternoclavicular joint.
  • It runs vertically downwards in the midline. It crosses the midline behind the angle of Louis to reach the level of the 4th rib.
  • The right pleura then continues vertically downwards till the xiphisternum.
  • While the left pleura deviates laterally to the sternal edge of the 6th costochondral junction (arching at the 4th costal cartilage level). This attitude of pleura is to accommodate the cardiac notch.
  • Then pleura of both sides run laterally to cross the 8th rib in the midclavicular line, the 10th rib in the midaxillary line and the twelfth rib at the erector spinae's lateral border.

Option A: The right and left pleura to come into contact in the midline at the level of the jugular notch (suprasternal notch).

  • The parietal pleura of both sides come to meet at the angle of Louis and runs vertically downwards to the level of the 4th rib.
  • They form a convexity at the sternoclavicular joint.

Option B: The pleura's apex is at the clavicle's level.

  • The apex of the pleura lies 2.5cm above the medial third of the clavicle.
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle lies in front of it.

Option C: The right pleura passes across the 10th rib in the anterior axillary line.

  • The parietal pleura of both sides crosses the 10th rib in the midaxillary line instead of the anterior axillary line.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors deficiency will not affect prothrombin time?
questions.solution:
Option D: VIII

  • Prothrombin time (PT)- Time required for clotting.
  • Normal PT = 15–20 seconds.
  • The deficiency of factors II (prothrombin), V, VII, and X may prolong the prothrombin time. Prolonged PT is seen in defects of the Extrinsic Pathway.
  • The prothrombin level is low in Vitamin K deficiency and various Liver and biliary diseases.
  • Vitamin K-dependent factors: Factors II, VII, IX, and X, as Vitamin K is a necessary cofactor for the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glutamic acid residues to carboxy glutamic acid residues.

​​​​​​​

Option A: II

  • The deficiency of factors II (prothrombin), V, VII, and X may prolong the prothrombin time. Prolonged PT is seen in defects of the extrinsic pathway.​​​​​​​

Option B: V

  • The deficiency of factors II (prothrombin), V, VII, and X may prolong the prothrombin time. Prolonged PT is seen in defects of the extrinsic pathway

Option C: VII

  • The deficiency of factors II (prothrombin), V, VII, and X may prolong the prothrombin time. Prolonged PT is seen in defects of the extrinsic pathway.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with celiac disease visited the physician because of difficulty seeing at night. She complained about frequent, foul-smelling stools on further investigation. Stool analysis revealed a high content of partially digested fat. Deficiency of which of the following causes her condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vitamin A

  • Malabsorption syndrome is a condition characterised by the failure of digestion and absorption in the small intestine. Malabsorption syndrome is generally caused by Crohn’s disease, Tropical sprue, Steatorrhea, and Celiac disease.
  • Here, the woman presents with malabsorption syndrome and undigested fat in the stool, so a deficiency of the fat-soluble vitamin is suspected.
  • Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can be excreted in the faeces and fat in persons with celiac disease and other diseases that cause malabsorption of intestinal contents.
  • Retinal, which is necessary for the synthesis of rhodopsin in the rods of the retina, can be deficient when there is a lack of Vitamin A.
  • Decreased rhodopsin levels in the rods can lower the retina’s sensitivity to light, thus causing night blindness.
  • Night blindness is due to the deficiency of vitamin A, which is essential for the function of rods. Vitamin A deficiency occurs because of the following causes:
    • A diet containing less vitamin A
    • Decreased absorption of vitamin A from the intestine.
  • Vitamin A deficiency causes defective cone function. Prolonged lack leads to anatomical changes in rods and cones and degeneration of other retinal layers. So, the retinal function can be restored only if treatment is given with vitamin A before the visual receptors degenerate.

Option A: Amino Acids

  • Amino Acids have nothing to do with the patient’s symptoms..

Option B: Glucose

  • Glucose deficiency does not cause Night Blindness.

Option D: Vitamin B12

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency causes Anemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife with complaints of multiple episodes of a sudden loss of consciousness. The patient further explains that he is otherwise well but suddenly loses consciousness and regains it within 10 to 20 seconds. The patient has an irregular pulse. The ECG of the patient shows a total A-V block. Two minutes after the onset of a syncopal attack, among the following, which becomes the pacemaker of the heart in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Purkinje fibres

  • This is a case of the Stokes-Adams syndrome attack in which the total A-V block suddenly begins.
  • In this type of heart block, the impulses from the SA node are blocked in the branches of the bundle of His (below the level of the AV node). In this condition, the distal part of the conductive system (i.e., the Purkinje fibres) becomes the pacemaker.
  • After a few seconds, some part of the Purkinje system beyond the block, usually in the distal part of the A-V node beyond the blocked point in the node or the A-V bundle, begins discharging rhythmically at a rate of 15 to 40 times per minute and acting as the pacemaker of the ventricles. This phenomenon is called ventricular escape.

Option A: Sinus node

  • The sinus node controls the beat of the heart because its rate of rhythmical discharge is faster than that of any other part of the heart. Therefore, the sinus node is virtually always the pacemaker of the normal heart.

Option B: A-V node

  • When the SA node or the connected conducting fibres are dysfunctional and electrical signals are not transmitted further, the AV node can independently produce impulses to maintain the contractions of the ventricles. It is, therefore, often referred to as the secondary pacemaker of the heart.

Option D: Cardiac septum

  • The dividing wall between the right and left sides of the heart. The septum's portion that separates the heart's right and left atria is termed the atrial (or interatrial) septum. The portion of the septum that lies between the right and left ventricles of the heart is called the ventricular (or interventricular) septum.

questions.text: A pilot is flying his plane (pressurized- 720 mmHg) at 20,000 ft, and the barometric pressure is 230 mmHg. His alveolar pO2 is 92 mmHg, and his body temperature is also normal. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Option C: Arterial pCO2 is 40 mmHg

  • Pulmonary ventilation is driven by atmospheric pressure, alveolar pressure and intrapleural pressure.
  • Atmospheric pressure, also known as barometric pressure, is the total force exerted by the gases in the air.
  • One atm is equal to 760 mmHg.
  • Alveolar pressure is the pressure of the air inside the lung alveoli.
  • This pressure determines whether the air will flow inside or outside the lung.
  • Alveolar pressure equals atmospheric, which is zero cmH2O.
  • Intrapleural pressure is air pressure within the pleural cavity, i.e. the visceral and parietal pleura.
  • The difference in the above three pressure drives pulmonary ventilation.
  • The atmospheric pressure decreases in a nonlinear manner with increasing altitude.
  • It means that as the atmospheric pressure becomes less compressed, the gas molecules in the atmosphere get tightly packed, including the gas molecule oxygen; this decreases the partial pressure of oxygen in inspired air and hence decreases alveolar pO2.
  • The decrease in alveolar pO2 is due to hyperventilation caused by hypoxic drive.
  • Since the pO2 is 92 mmHg, this will not trigger hyperventilation, and he will have a normal pCO2 of 40 mmHg.

Option A: Alveolar pCO2 will be 55 mmHg

  • The normal alveolar pCO2 ranges from 35-45 mmHg.
  • It is a marker of sufficient alveolar ventilation.

Option B: Arterial pH will be 7.6

  • The normal pH ranges between 7.35-7.45
  • A ph of 7.6 indicates an alkalotic condition. The ph is normal in this case.

Option D: Alveolar ventilation will be increased

  • Alveolar ventilation is increased if there is a hypoxic drive.
  • This patient has a normal pO2 which will not trigger hypoxia.

questions.text: A healthy 47-year-old man is enrolled in a study of renal hemodynamics. On day 1, laboratory studies show a hematocrit of 46%, a renal blood flow (RBF) of 1,000 mL/min, and a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of 105 mL/min per 1.73 m2. Follow-up laboratory studies on day 20 show a hematocrit of 45%, an RBF of 820 mL/min, and a GFR of 87 mL/min per 1.73 m2. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the changes in the patient's laboratory studies?
questions.solution:
Option B: Afferent arteriole constriction

  • Afferent arteriole constriction decreases renal glomerular hydrostatic pressure, which proportionately decreases GFR and RPF, resulting in a stable filtration fraction, as seen in this patient.
  • This effect may occur in patients who take NSAIDs.
  • These drugs inhibit the production of prostaglandins, which preferentially dilate afferent arterioles.

Option A: Efferent arteriole constriction

  • Efferent arteriole constriction increases renal glomerular hydrostatic pressure, which increases GFR and decreases RPF, resulting in an increased filtration fraction.
  • Though this patient's RPF has decreased, his GFR has also decreased, and his filtration fraction remains stable.
  • The action of angiotensin II causes efferent arteriole constriction.

Option C: Total body fluid deficit

  • Total body fluid deficit (e.g., dehydration) causes renal hypoperfusion secondary to a decrease in the effective circulating volume.
  • Subsequent RAAS activation leads to angiotensin II-mediated efferent arteriolar vasoconstriction, which, in turn, decreases RPF but relatively preserves GFR.
  • The disproportionately greater decrease in RPF compared to GFR results in an increase in filtration fraction.
  • In addition, total body fluid deficit causes significant hemoconcentration.
  • This patient's filtration fraction and hematocrit, however, have remained stable.

Option D: Urinary tract obstruction

  • Acute urinary tract obstruction increases intratubular pressures and thereby decreases GFR.
  • RPF remains stable or increases due to a compensatory release of prostaglandins with subsequent dilation of afferent arterioles.
  • As a result of these changes, the filtration fraction decreases.
  • Though this patient's GFR has decreased, his RPF has also decreased, and his filtration fraction remains stable.

questions.text: Which hormones counteract the nitric oxide effect and make the penis flaccid after orgasm?
questions.solution:
Option A: Endothelin and Norepinephrine

Norepinephrine is released from nerve endings, and endothelin is released from endothelial cells in the vasculature, causing the vasculature to narrow and then go limp after orgasm

Erection physiology:

  • Penile erection is a neurovascular event governed by the delicate balance between the contractile and relaxation properties of the corporal smooth muscle.
  • Normal erectile tissue comprises trabecular smooth muscle (approximately 50%) and an extracellular matrix providing a fibroelastic framework.
  • The corporal smooth muscle is contracted in the flaccid state and relaxed in the erect state.
  • Following sexual stimulation, initially contracted helicine arteriolar smooth muscle undergoes relaxation.
  • Receptor-mediated smooth muscle relaxation is initiated by the generation of cyclic nucleotides (cGMP and cAMP) by guanylate and adenylate cyclases, activation of protein kinase G, and a series of molecular events that lead to the eventual inhibition of the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA) pump and intracellular Ca2+ sequestration within the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Relaxation of arterial and trabecular smooth muscle results in dilation of the cavernosal and helicine arteries, increased arterial blood inflow across the endothelial cells lining the lacunar spaces, and penile engorgement.
  • Penile rigidity is achieved through the increased resistance to the outflow of blood as the trabecular walls expand against the tunica albuginea and the plexus of subtunical venules is compressed (i.e., the veno-occlusive mechanism).
  • Norepinephrine is released from nerve endings, and endothelin is released from endothelial cells in the vasculature, causing the vasculature to narrow and then go limp after orgasm.

Option B: Estrogen and progesterone

  • Estrogen and progesterone do not play a role in erection.
  • They are important for menstruation and pregnancy.

Option C: LH and FSH

  • They play a role in spermatogenesis.
  • These hormones have no role in the erection of the penis.

Option D: Progesterone and LH

  • Estrogen and progesterone do not play a role in erection.
  • LH and FSH play a role in spermatogenesis.

questions.text: Prior to undergoing arthroplasty, a 62-year-old man with coronary artery disease underwent cardiac catheterization. A catheter is placed through the femoral artery and then advanced to the aorta. Pressure tracing of one cardiac cycle is observed. If total systole duration remains normal but isovolumic contraction duration increases, then which one of the following findings indicates compromised LV performance?

choices.text: Increased Left Ventricular Ejection Time (LVET); Normal Pre-Ejection Period (PEP), and Normal QS2 duration
PEP/LVET ratio > 0.35; no change in QS2 duration
Reduction in PEP, LVET, and QS2 duration

questions.solution:
Option C: PEP/LVET ratio > 0.35; no change in QS2 duration

  • The normal PEP/LVET ratio is 0.35.
    • PEP is calculated as  (Total electromechanical systole) – (ejection time); PEP = (QS2) – (LVET)
    • PEP represents LV's electrical depolarization and isovolumic contraction before the systolic ejection.
  • QS2 = Electromechanical systole; from the onset of QRS complex on ECG to the closure of semilunar valves – dicrotic notch on the carotid pulse.
  • If QS2 is normal, but the PEP/LVET ratio has increased, it means the pre-ejection period has increased, and the ejection time is reduced; it indicates a compromised LV performance

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by ST segments on ECG?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ventricular Repolarization

  • Segments of ECG:
    • PR - Interval corresponds with atrial depolarisation and conduction through the AV node.
    • QRS - Corresponds with Ventricular depolarisation + atrial repolarisation.
    • QT - Corresponds with Ventricular depolarisation + Ventricular repolarisation.
    • ST - Corresponds to the beginning of Ventricular Repolarization.

Option A: Ventricular Depolarisation

  • It represents the QRS complex of ECG.

Option C: Atrial Depolarization

  • PR interval is associated with atrial depolarisation.

Option D: Atrial Repolarization

  • It is also associated with the QRS complex.

questions.text: Alveolar ventilation is the gas exchange between the alveoli and the external environment. Following data is obtained from a 20 year-old medical student: Tidal volume = 540 mL, Partial pressures of CO2 in expired air & arterial blood ∼ PECO2 = 20 mm Hg, PACO2 = 30 mm Hg: Respiratory rate = 15/min. What would be the alveolar ventilation?
questions.solution:
Option D: 5.4 L/min

  • Alveolar ventilation = (Tidal volume – Dead space volume) x Respiratory rate
  • = (540 – 180) 115
  • = 5.4 L/min

questions.text: Why do symptoms worsen with a hot bath and improve with decreased temperature in a demyelinating disease like Multiple Sclerosis?

choices.text: Lower temperatures slow the gating kinetics of Na+ channels
AP duration increases with increased temperature
The activity of K+ channels is increased at lower temperatures
Inadequate recharging of the denuded axon at higher temperatures

questions.solution:
Option A: Lower temperatures slow the gating kinetics of Na+ channels

  • In demyelinating diseases, after myelin is degraded, there is a redistribution of Na+ channels along the nerve (normally present at nodes of Ranvier).
  • Lower temperature alters the Na+ channel kinetics to delay the closure; thus, extra Na+ can come into the cell, enabling electronic conduction up to a point on the nerve where the next Na+ channel is.

Option B: AP duration increases with increased temperature

  • As the temperature increases, the action potential's duration is reduced, and its amplitude is decreased.
  • The relationship between conduction velocity and temperature is non-linear. The velocity increases when the blocking temperature approaches, which abruptly drops.

Option C: The activity of K+ channels is increased at lower temperatures

  • At a certain degree of demyelination, the activity of K+ channels and the membrane conduction increase with increasing temperatures, but at lower temperatures, when the degree of demyelination is increased, the conduction is blocked.

Option D: Inadequate recharging of the denuded axon at higher temperatures

  • At higher temperatures, there is increased leakage of charges from the cell membrane causing increased capacitance of the nerve.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman undergoes a neurologic exam that indicates loss of pain and temperature sensitivity, vibratory sense, and proprioception in the left side of the body. These symptoms could be explained by:

choices.text: A tumor on the right medial lemniscal pathway in the spinal cord
A tumor on the left medial lemniscal pathway in the spinal cord
A tumor affecting the right postcentral gyrus
A large tumor in the right ventrolateral spinal cord

questions.solution:
Option C: A tumour affecting the right postcentral gyrus

  • Right postcentral gyrus lesion (e.g.,  by a tumour) would result in loss of pain and temperature sensitivity, vibratory sense, and proprioception in the left side of the body

Option A: A tumour on the right medial lemniscal pathway in the spinal cord

  • Damage to the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway by a tumour below the crossing point of its fibres results in loss of vibration and joint sense (proprioception) on the same side of the body as the lesion. Damage above the crossing point results in a loss of vibration and joint sense on the opposite side of the body to the lesion

Option B: A tumour on the left medial lemniscal pathway ay the n spinal cord

  • Damage to the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway by a tumour below the crossing point of its fibres results in loss of vibration and joint sense (proprioception) on the same side of the body as the lesion. Damage above the crossing point results in a loss of vibration and joint sense on the opposite side of the body to the lesion

Option D: A large tumour in the right ventrolateral spinal cord

  • Lesions of the anterolateral tract produce a contralateral deficit in pain and temperature sensation two to five segments below the level of the cordotomy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the physician's office with a complaint of neck swelling for the past 1 month. After a complete physical examination, it is suspected that she has a goiter and her heart rate is elevated. She also complains of feeling excessively warm and has been losing weight. Further testing reveals high plasma levels of both TRH and TSH. This patient most likely has which condition?

choices.text: A hypothalamic tumor secreting large amounts of TRH
A pituitary tumor secreting large amounts of TSH

questions.solution:
Option B: A hypothalamic tumor secreting large amounts of TRH.

  • The patient presents with neck swelling for a month with elevated heart rate and levels of TRH and TSH. Such presentation is seen with a hypothalamic tumor secreting TRH, which increases the amount of TSH secreted by the anterior pituitary and subsequently elevated thyroid hormone secretion by the thyroid gland, causing symptoms of hyperthyroidism, e.g., elevated heart rate.

 

 

  • The thyroid hormone secretion is regulated by the feedback effect of the thyroid hormones at the anterior pituitary and hypothalamus. Therefore, when thyroid hormones are synthesized in excess, there is feedback inhibition of the TSH release by the anterior pituitary thyrotropes and hypothalamic TRH release.
  • Conversely, when the thyroid hormone synthesis is decreased, there is a loss of feedback inhibition leading to activation of the TSH release by the anterior pituitary thyrotropes and hypothalamic TRH release.
  • A hypothalamic tumor results in the secretion of large amounts of TRH.
  • This increased amount of TRH would stimulate the thyrotropes in the anterior pituitary gland to secrete increased amounts of TSH.
  • Increased stimulation of the thyroid gland by the TSH will result in the secretion of thyroid hormones.
  • The thyroid hormones have numerous metabolic effects, as shown in the image below:

 

 

  • The thyroid hormones affect the cardiovascular system in the following ways:
  1. Increased heart rate
  2. Increased cardiac output
  3. Increased heart strength
  4. Increased respiration
  5. Increased blood flow to the tissues
  • The thyroid hormones affect the metabolism as follows:
  1. Increased lipolysis
  2. Increased basal metabolic rate
  3. Increase protein synthesis
  4. Increase sodium-potassium ATPase activity
  5. Increase oxygen consumption
  6. Increased glucose absorption
  7. Increased gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis
  • Other actions are:
  1. Increased growth
  2. Central nervous system development

Option A: An endemic goiter

  • Endemic goiter occurs due to decreased thyroid hormone synthesis due to an underlying deficiency of iodine. As a result, the thyroid hormone secretion declines.
  • Therefore, a patient with endemic goiter will present with decreased levels of thyroid hormones. However, the TSH and TRH will be elevated due to the loss of negative feedback inhibition by the thyroid hormones.

Option C: A pituitary tumor secreting large amounts of TSH

  • A pituitary tumor secreting large amounts of TSH will result in increased stimulation of the thyroid gland follicles. Therefore, increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones occur.
  • On the other hand, the TRH levels will be decreased due to negative feedback inhibition from the elevated levels of TSH and thyroid hormones.

Option D: Graves’ disease

  • Graves’ disease occurs due to the autoimmune-mediated hyperactivation of the thyroid glands. The thyroid stimulating immunoglobulins are responsible for increased activation of the TSH receptors at the thyroid gland follicles resulting in increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones.
  • Due to increased thyroid hormone levels, the TSH and TRH levels decrease due to negative feedback inhibition.

questions.text: Which amino acid serves as a precursor for the synthesis of Nitric Oxide?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glutamate

  • Substances such as acetylcholine, serotonin, and bradykinins mediate the process of vasodilation by attaching to specific membrane receptors on endothelial cells.
  • This binding causes calcium ion influx into endothelial cells and activates endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS).
  • This enzyme generates nitric oxide from Arginine using O2 and cofactors such as NADPH, FAD, FMN, etc.
  • Nitric oxide diffuses into smooth muscles, activates the enzyme guanylate cyclase, and triggers the formation of secondary messenger cGMP from GTP, as shown in fig.
  • High levels of cGMP activate protein kinase G causing a reduction of cytosolic calcium levels and relaxing smooth muscle cells.

 

Option A: Tryptophan

  • Tryptophan is involved in the production of niacin and serotonin.
  • It requires vitamins B2 and B6 for these reactions

Option B: Histidine

  • Histidine is involved in the production of histamine.
  • It requires vitamin B6 for histamine production

Option C: Glutamate

  • Glutamate is involved in the production of neurotransmitter GABA and antioxidant glutathione.
  • It is also the major collector of ammonia in body.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient displaying darkened urine upon exposure to air, along with a history of joint pain, stiffness, and prominent pigmentation changes in the sclera and ear cartilage, what specific metabolite accumulation is likely the underlying cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Homogentisic acid

  • The child is suffering from alkaptonuria, an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, due to the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase.
  • This enzyme converts one of the intermediates of tyrosine catabolism into methyl acetoacetate.
  • As a result of this enzyme deficiency, substrate homogentisic acid accumulates and is excreted in the urine.
  • Urine turns black on exposure to air due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid, causing dark staining of diapers in infants.
  • It is a benign condition in childhood, but over the years, homogentisic acid gets polymerised in the body, forming alkapton bodies, which accumulate in cartilages such as the nose, ear pinna, intervertebral disc, and connective tissue, which turn bluish-black colour.
  • The patient develops arthralgia and arthritis. This condition is known as ochronosis, and arthritis is also known as ochronotic arthritis.

Option A: Methylmalonic acid:

  • Increased levels of methylmalonic acid are present in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, characterised by macrocytic megaloblastic anaemia and sub-acute combined spinal cord degeneration.

Option C: Phenylpyruvate:

  • Phenylpyruvate is a metabolite of the amino acid phenylalanine. Excess phenylpyruvate is present in the urine of patients suffering from phenylketonuria which is characterised by hypopigmentation, musty body odour and CNS dysfunction.

Option D: Homocysteine:

  • Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by increased levels of amino acid homocysteine in the urine.
  • It is associated with extensive atherosclerosis, marfanoid habitus and intellectual disability.

questions.text: Which enzyme defect is associated with Hurler's syndrome??
questions.solution:
Option D: Alpha-L-Iduronidase

  • Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) belong to a group of hereditary diseases caused by deficiency of any of the lysosomal acid hydrolases normally involved in the degradation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs): heparan sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and keratin sulfate.
  • A gene mutation in IDUA causes MPS. They are progressive disorders with the accumulation of GAGs in various tissues resulting in multi-organ dysfunction.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with a deficiency of alpha-L-Iduronidase and is the most severe form of MPS 1. It affects the degradation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate; hence they build up in lysosomes and result in the debilitation of the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and central nervous systems.
  • The presentation of the disease is within the first 2 years of life, with life expectancy up to 10 years. 
  • Signs and symptoms include developmental delay, mental retardation, hearing loss, poor vision due to corneal clouding, noisy breathing, enlargement of tonsils with upper airway obstruction, frequent respiratory infections, coarse facial features (frontal bossing, depressed nasal bridge, small jaws, macroglossia, flat mid face), carpal tunnel syndrome, stiff joints, short stature, dysostosis multiplex (enlarged skull, abnormal spine, and ribs). Hepatosplenomegaly and umbilical hernia is also seen. The cardiovascular system involves cardiomegaly and thickened valves.
  • Scheie syndrome belongs to a group of MPS 1. It also has a buildup of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate with the deficiency of enzyme alpha-iduronidase, just like Hurler syndrome. However, it is the less severe form with developmental delay, corneal clouding, and skeletal deformities.

Diagnosis of Mucopolysaccharidoses:

  1. Clinical presentation and history are majorly used for diagnosis.
  2. Urinalysis is done for the presence of increased amounts of GAGs. In this scenario, the levels of dermatan and heparan sulfate are increased.
  3. The enzyme activity of alpha-iduronidase will be decreased in white blood cells, fibroblasts, and serum.
  4. This disease can be treated by bone marrow transplantation, preferably before 18 months. Enzyme replacement therapy is also available.

Option A: Beta-Glucuronidase

  • β-glucuronidase located in lysosomes catalyzes hydrolysis of β-D-glucuronic acid residues from the non-reducing end of GAGs such as Dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate, chondroitin 4-sulfate, chondroitin 6-sulfate
  • Deficiencies in β-glucuronidase is known as Sly syndrome or Mucopolysaccharidosis VII and results in the build-up of non-hydrolyzed mucopolysaccharides with general features like coarse facial features, short stature and mental retardation.

Option B: Neuraminidase

  • Neuraminidase is a hydrolase that cleaves neuraminic acid at its glycosidic linkages.
  • The most common is viral Neuraminidase on the surface of the influenza virus, which allows the virus to be delivered from the host cell and start a replication cycle. Hence it is important to initiate the infection by the influenza virus.

Option C: Beta-Galactosidase

  • Beta-galactosidase, aka lactase, is the enzyme that catalyzes lactose-producing galactose and glucose in the intestines for absorption.
  • Primary or secondary deficiency of this enzyme results in lactose intolerance. This disease is characterized by abdominal pain, flatulence, bloating, and osmotic diarrhea after eating milk or dairy products.
  • Treatment involves a lactose-free diet.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the office with poor performance and learning difficulties in school. According to the parents, the child has incoherent speech and stunted growth. On physical examination, coarse facial features, clubbed fingers and a protuberant abdomen is found. Ophthalmic examination shows an absence of corneal clouding. Auscultation of the chest determines a loud P2 sound. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hunter's syndrome

  • Hunter syndrome has an X-linked recessive inheritance. The impaired metabolism of glycosaminoglycans causes due to a deficiency of the enzyme Iduronate sulfatase. As a result, dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate accumulate in lysosomes, leading to mucopolysaccharidoses type 2.
  • It is a milder form of Hurler syndrome with a mutation in the IDS gene.
  • The presentation of the disease is between 2 and 4 years, and death is by the age of 15 years, usually due to cardiopulmonary compromise.
  • Early in life, it presents with intellectual disability, skeletal deformities, coarse facial features, and ivory-colored lesions on the skin. However, later on in life, there is progressive neurocognitive decline, hydrocephalus, and seizures.
  • Complications of hunter syndrome include mental retardation, valvular heart disease, carpal tunnel syndrome, seizures, and airway obstruction.
  • Hunter syndrome is also associated with aggressive behavior. However, corneal clouding is absent, unlike hurler syndrome.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Characteristic findings on physical examination.
    • Urinalysis shows increased dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.
    • The enzyme activity shows a decreased activity of Iduronate sulfatase on fibroblasts and white blood cells.
  • The management plan majorly includes enzyme replacement therapy.

Option A: Hurler syndrome

  • Hurler syndrome is characterized by impaired metabolism of glycosaminoglycans due to deficiency of enzyme alpha-iduronidase leading to accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate in lysosomes.
  • It leads to developmental delay, mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and abnormal facies.
  • It includes corneal clouding, which is absent in hunter.

Option C: Fragile X syndrome

  • Clinical features of Fragile X syndrome are most apparent after puberty in males.
  • It has an X-linked dominant inheritance with trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. This expansion results in hypermethylation of DNA and decreased expression of the gene.
  • It is known as the most common cause of inherited intellectual disability. Findings include postpubertal enlarged testis, long face with a large jaw, large everted ears, autism, and mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Tay-Sachs disease

  • It is a lysosomal storage disease caused by deficiency of the enzyme hexosamine A resulting in the accumulation of an abnormal metabolite GM2 ganglioside in lysosomes.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, "cherry red" spot on the macula, blindness, and lysosomes with onion skin but no hepatosplenomegaly. It is also associated with muscular weakness and seizures.

questions.text: A young boy suffering from severe fasting hypoglycemia was brought to ER. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly whereas blood examination indicated hyperlactic acidemia and hyperuricemia. A liver biopsy indicated that hepatocytes contained more than the normal amount of glycogen that was of normal structure. All these findings in the patient suggest most likely deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glucose-6-phosphatase

  • A deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase (Von Gierke’s disease) causes severe fasting hypoglycemia, hyper lactic acidemia, ketosis and hyperuricemia (see fig)

​​​​​​​

Option A: Glycogen synthase

  • A deficiency of glycogen synthase would result in lower amounts of stored glycogen, which is rare.

Option C: Glycogen phosphorylase

  • It is RLE of glycogenolysis and release glucose as glucose 1-P from straight chain of glycogen by phosphorolysis of α (1→4) glycosidic bond. 
  • A deficiency of glycogen phosphorylase would result in decrease in glycogen degradation, causing fasting hypoglycemia, but not the other symptoms.

Option D: Amylo-α(1→6)-glucosidase

  • Amylo α(1→6)-glucosidase or debranching enzyme hydrolyzes single glucose units joined through an α(1→6) glycosidic bond at the branch point of a glycogen chain.
  • Its deficiency causes Cori’s disease and give rise to limit dextrins which were not found in this patient.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient visits a physician with complaints of increasing fatigue and muscle aches during exercise. He recalls avoiding sports activities in his younger years because he was not able to keep up. Stress testing reveals normal cardiac function, but blood tests show gradually increasing levels of serum lactic acid and ammonia under resting conditions. His physician suspects a mitochondrial DNA disorder that affects mitochondrial function due to mutation in mitochondrial genes. Which of the following options gives the names of mitochondrial pathways affected in this patient and also lists the compound linking these pathways?

choices.text: Citric acid cycle, electron transport chain, and α-ketoglutarate
Citric acid cycle and urea cycle, and fumarate
Citric acid and urea cycle, and arginine

questions.solution:
• Mutation in mitochondrial genome mainly affects oxidative phosphorylation leading to low ATP and anaerobic glycolysis with lactic acid accumulation especially under stressful conditions such as exercise due to depletion of blood oxygen saturation.
  • A vicious cycle of exercise intolerance leading to muscle inactivity with fewer mitochondria exacerbates myopathy (muscle weakness and incoordination) in mitochondrial disorders.
  • All the reactions of the citric acid cycle and some of the initial reactions of urea cycle are located primarily in the mitochondria, whereas glycogen and glucose metabolism pathways primarily occur in the cytosol.
  • α-keto glutarate and fumarate are intermediates of the citric acid cycle, but only fumarate is an intermediate of both the citric acid and urea cycles.
  • Fumarate and arginine are produced from argininosuccinate in the urea cycle, after which arginine is converted to ornithine to yield urea and fumarate is converted to malate and then oxaloacetate in the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: A 13-year-old young boy presents to a physician with a complaint of recurrent respiratory infections that cause him to miss school several times. He has bulky foul-smelling stools. On physical examination, he has a height below the 10th percentile. Multiple nasal polyps are also found. A sweat chloride test is found positive. Based on the given condition, which of the following vitamin should consider?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin A

  • The above-given case is a case of cystic fibrosis, and fatty foul smell stool is indicative of malabsorption. In intestinal disorders, e.g., chronic malabsorption or diarrhea due to digestive enzyme deficiency, fat-soluble vitamins are poorly absorbed and can become deficient. 
  • Hence, supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins should be routinely done in these disorders. Vitamins A, D, E, and K are fats soluble and have to be administered intramuscularly or as oral emulsions (mixtures of oil and water).
  • The other vitamins listed are water-soluble, which can be efficiently administered orally, and rapidly absorbed from the intestine.

Option B: Vitamin C

  • Vitamin C deficiency cause anorexia, gingival swelling, poor wound healing, and mucocutaneous petechiae.

Option C: Vitamin B1

  • Congenital lactic acidosis may occur due to in thiamine (B1) deficiency by conversion of excess pyruvate to lactic acid due to low activity og pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) that converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA and require thiamine as its cofactor.

Option D: Vitamin B2

  • Riboflavin deficiency caused by malnutrition, Increases demand such as pregnancy.
  • Riboflavin (vitamin B2) causes cheilitis, pharyngitis, stomatitis, normocytic normochromic anemia, and corneal vascularization.

questions.text: A young type I diabetic patient is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis in the emergency department. The doctor notices a fruity odor on the patient’s breath. This odor is due to the?
questions.solution:
Lack of food intake and missed insulin dose caused diabetic ketoacidosis in the patient. The main fuel under such conditions is Ketone bodies, Acetoacetate, Beta-hydroxybutyrate and Acetone

The fruity odor is due to acetone, which is being exhaled. Acetone is derived from the spontaneous decarboxylation of acetoacetate to acetone within the blood and tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is typically used to conjugate bile acids?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glycine

  • Bile acids are present in the deprotonated form at physiological pH. They are made in the liver and stored in the gall bladder, emulsifying the dietary fat, which increases the surface area. They are formed from cholesterol by modification of the side chain.
  • Conjugation of primary bile acid occurs in the liver with glycine or taurine to form glycocholic acid and taurocholic acid, respectively.
  • The presence of the charged carboxyl group of glycine or the charged sulfate of taurine adds to the hydrophilic nature of the bile acids, thereby increasing their ability to emulsify lipids during the digestive process.

  • A group of rare inborn errors affects the enzymes of bile acid synthesis, resulting in the accumulation of toxic acids in the liver. Patients with these disorders may have a lethal accumulation of abnormal bile acids and conjugated bilirubin in the liver due to cholestasis (abnormal concentration of bile acids in the gall bladder), illustrated by infants with a defective cholic acid synthesis that lives 4 to 6 months on average.

Option A: Sulfate

  • Sulfate is not used to conjugate bile acids.

Option C: Acetate

  • Acetate is not used to conjugate bile acids.

Option D: Glutathione

  • Glutathione is not used to conjugate bile acids.

Option E: Glucuronic acid

  • Glucuronic acid is not used to conjugate bile acids.

questions.text: An infant presenting with diarrhea, blood examination showing acanthocytes, undetectable cholesterol and triglyceride, and absent VLDL and LDL fractions on lipoprotein electrophoresis, the prescription includes oral vitamin A, vitamin D, vitamin K, and later vitamin E. To confirm the diagnosis, which gene sequencing could have been performed?
questions.solution:
Option B: Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein

  • VLDL and LDL fractions were absent on lipoprotein electrophoresis. This indicates abetalipoproteinemia.
  • Abetalipoproteinemia, or Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that interferes with the normal absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins from food.
  • The defective protein is Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein (MTTP). So, sequencing of MTTP protein gene would confirm this condition by revealing any mutations present in this gene which would ultimately affect the function of this protein.

Option A: Lipoprotein lipase

  • LPL defect causes familial hyperchylomicronemia with increase chylomicrons and VLDL.
  • LPL deficiency cause hepatosplenomegaly, xanthoma, abdominal pain, and pancreatitis.

Option C: Cholesterol Ester transfer protein (CETP)

  • Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) mediates the exchange of cholesteryl ester for triglycerides between HDL and VLDL and LDL

Option D: Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT)

  • LCAT is involved cholesterol esterification.
  • Defect in LCAT causes Fish eye disease with features such as hemolytic anemia and end state renal disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of bilateral flank pain for one day. He is a known case of sarcoidosis. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The x-ray of the patient is done, which reveals two discrete areas of calcification within the inter-polar region of the renal parenchyma, which measured 6 and 3 mm, respectively. Laboratory evaluation revealed mild hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, mild hyperphosphatemia, a severe non-anion gap metabolic alkalosis, and a suppressed parathyroid hormone level. The above-mentioned pathological findings are due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Overproduction of 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D

  • This is a case of nephrocalcinosis secondary to sarcoidosis in which the patient presents with complaints of bilateral flank pain.
  • The x-ray of the patient is done, which reveals two discrete areas of calcification within the interpolar region of the renal parenchyma, which measured 6 and 3 mm. respectively. Laboratory evaluation revealed mild hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, mild hyperphosphatemia, a severe non-anion gap metabolic alkalosis, and a suppressed parathyroid hormone level which is suggestive of nephrocalcinosis secondary to sarcoidosis.
  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease of unknown cause. Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases can cause hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria due to excessive production of vitamin D from the extrarenal conversion of 1,25 (OH)2D3
  • Nephrocalcinosis calcification of the interstitium and renal tubules. It is associated with hypercalcemia.
  • Significant degrees of calcinosis, under certain conditions, can lead to chronic tubulointerstitial disease and renal failure. Along with further damage, slowly progressive chronic kidney disease develops.

Option B: Dystrophic calcification

  • Dystrophic calcification is a localized calcification.
  • It is secondary to local injury or necrosis caused due to cardiovascular conditions, fat necrosis, infarcts or autoimmune connective tissue disorder.

Option C: Mutation in calcium-sensing receptors

  • The calcium-sensing receptor is a protein-coding gene.
  • Mutation in the calcium-sensing receptor gene can cause autosomal dominant hypocalcemia type-1.

Option D: Increased reabsorption of calcium

  • Nephrocalcinosis is associated with increased calcium intake.
  • Disorders associated with hypercalcemia, such as hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, vitamin D intoxication, metastatic cancer, or excessive calcium intake (Milk alkali syndrome), can lead to the formation of calcium stones and calcium deposits in the kidneys, causing nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: In the presence of recombinant erythropoietin, bone marrow cells from an organ donor are grown in vitro at 37°C. The image shows a photomicrograph of a typical "burst-forming unit." Which of the following physiologic adaptations to transmembrane signalling is exemplified by this colony dedicated to the erythrocyte differentiation pathway?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hyperplasia

  • Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue.
  • It is often a normal process and is a reaction to trophic cues or increasing functional demand, similar to hypertrophy.
  • For example, people living at high altitudes are more likely to develop erythroid hyperplasia. Low oxygen tension stimulates the formation of erythropoietin, which helps erythroid precursors survive and proliferate in the bone marrow.
  • The physiological and molecular mechanisms that cause hyperplasia are linked to cell proliferation regulation (i.e., cell cycle).

Option A: Atrophy

  • Atrophy is a decrease in the number of cells in a tissue.
  • Decreased oxygenation and nutrient supply to a tissue lead to a cascade of events that causes cellular apoptosis and, ultimately, tissue atrophy.

Option B: Dysplasia

  • Dysplasia is characterized by cellular atypia.
  • It entails abnormal tissue morphology and nuclear hyperchromatism.
  • Dysplasia can be precancerous.

Option D: Metaplasia

  • Metaplasia is the change of one cell line to another
  • The most common example is the change of esophageal squamous epithelium to the columnar epithelium, as seen in Barrett's esophagus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the hospital with bloody vomiting for 2 days. He is a chronic alcoholic and drinks 4-5 glasses of alcohol daily. Examination reveals hepatomegaly and ascites with fluid thrill. He is given IV octreotide for suspected oesophagal varices management. Laboratory results show increased transaminases. Further workup indicates hepatic failure, and a liver transplant is planned. A test shown below is done for the?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tissue typing

  • Tissue typing (HLA typing) is the technique in which the tissues of a prospective donor and recipient are tested for compatibility before carrying out transplantation.
  • Tissue typing is done to decrease the risk of graft rejection
  • The value of HLA matching varies between different solid organ transplants.
  • HLA matching is important to increase graft survival.
  • Mismatched donor and recipient tissues lead to the rejection of the tissues.
  • The two commonly used techniques are:

1. Mixed leukocyte reaction for MHC II

 

2. Micro-cytotoxicity assay for MHC I

  • Human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) are proteins (markers) on most cells in an individual. A person’s immune system uses HLA to see which cells belong in the body and which do not.

 

Option B: Drug allergy

  • Drug allergy is tested with a small amount of drug administered to the skin.
  • A rash, itchiness, and pain can be a sign of drug allergy.
  • Tissues of the donor and recipient are not used for this.

Option C: Infection Susceptibility

  • Infection susceptibility is the risk of acquiring an infection when a person is not immune or vaccinated against infection.
  • The procedure shown above is not to check for infection susceptibility.

Option D: Substance toxicity

  • Substance toxicity is not being evaluated in the procedure shown in the image
  • The toxicity of a substance depends on the chemical nature of the substance and the amount of substance absorbed by the body.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has been brought to the clinic with easy bruising and fatigue for the past few weeks. On examination, no abnormal findings are noted. Bone marrow study has revealed the myeloblasts and promonocytes in the bone marrow of more than 20%. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which genetic mutation is present in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Chromosomal Inversion

  • One of the molecular mechanisms involved in AML is genetic inversion.

AML

  • AML develops due to genetic changes in a hematopoietic precursor cell that alters normal growth and differentiation, resulting in large numbers of abnormal, immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow and blood.
  • These aberrant cells can divide and proliferate but cannot normally differentiate into mature, fully functional hematopoietic cells.
  • Many chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations are associated with prognosis in AML.
  • Cases of AML may demonstrate mutations in oncogenes (e.g., NRAS, FLT3) and/or loss of tumour suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, WT1 [Wilms tumour suppressor gene]).
  • Any hematologic malignancies are associated with specific chromosomal translocations that generate chimeric fusion genes that are never expressed in wild-type cells.
  • Chromosomal aberrations in AML commonly involve transcription factors that regulate hematopoiesis.
  • The chromosomal aberrations t(8;21)(q22;q22) and the inv(16)(p13q22) in AML involve subunits of the core-binding factor (CBF) group of transcription factors.
  • Members of the CBF group function as heterodimeric complexes regulating diverse target genes involved in tissue differentiation.
  • The cytogenetic hallmark of APL is a translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor-alpha (RARA) locus on chromosome 17.
  • These translocations lead to the formation of chimeric fusion transcripts from each of the derivative chromosomes.

Option A: Trinucleotide repeat expansion

  • Increased repetition of base triplets that leads to faulty protein synthesis or folding
  • Characterized by genetic anticipation
  • Seen in Fragile X syndrome and Huntington's disease

Option B: Anticipation

  • A phenomenon in which disease onset occurs earlier and/or the disease manifestation is more severe in offspring than in parents.
  • Seen in Huntington's disease

Option C: Heteroplasmy

  • The presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA results in variable expression in mitochondrially inherited disease.
  • Seen in mitochondrial disorders

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of mild fever, increasing fatigue, and red-purple rash on upper and lower extremities for four days. He is an immigrant from Russia and worked in a benzene factory. Physical examination does not reveal lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly, but petechial skin lesions are noted along with pallor. A CBC demonstrates severe pancytopenia with normocytic red cell indices. A bone marrow biopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism in the development of this patient’s anaemia?

choices.text: Decreased erythropoietin production by the kidneys

questions.solution:
Option A: Damage to stem cells

  • This is the case of aplastic anaemia in a patient with the signs and symptoms of pallor, mild fever, increasing fatigue, and petechial skin lesions on the upper and lower extremities, with CBC results showing severe pancytopenia and normocytic anaemia.
  • Patients with aplastic anaemia present with severe pancytopenia and clinical symptoms related to various cytopenias, including fatigue (anaemia), fever (neutropenia), and petechiae (thrombocytopenia).
  • This is caused by damage to bone marrow stem cells which is caused by a toxic environmental factor in this case, as the patient has a history of working in a benzene factory.
  • The bone marrow biopsy, seen in the above picture, is mainly aplastic, consisting largely of fat cells and fibrous stroma & lacking normal hematopoietic activity suggesting the diagnosis of aplastic anaemia.
  • Damage to the stem cells due to prolonged benzene exposure usually results in suppression of erythropoiesis by abnormal mitotic cells and apoptosis likely mediated by expanded production of inhibitory cytokines and nitric oxide.
  • The lack of appropriate reticulocyte response to anaemia indicates decreased or ineffective hematopoiesis.

Option B: Decreased erythropoietin production by the kidneys

  • Decreased erythropoietin production due to increased production of interleukins and tumour necrosis factor destroying RBC precursors resulting in decreased reticulocyte count with resultant anaemia.
  • This is usually seen in anaemia due to any chronic inflammatory, infectious, or malignant disease.

Option C: Folate deficiency

  • Folate deficiency can arise from multiple causes like inadequate dietary intake, celiac disease, short bowel syndrome, amyloidosis, gastric bypass, drugs, congenital deficiencies, pregnancy, and dialysis, etc.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

Option D: Impaired globin chain synthesis

  • Impaired or absent globin chain synthesis in beta-thalassemia results in excessive unbound globin chains that can precipitate in mature and immature RBCs leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis.
  • Peripheral smear shows microcytic, hypochromic, and nucleated RBCs, target cells, and poikilocytes.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to extreme weakness. Physical examination revealed enlarged cervical lymph nodes and a palpable spleen 2 cm below the costal margin. Her haemoglobin level is 10.4 g/dl, the platelet count is 27 x 109/L, and the total leukocyte count is 40 x 109/L, with 80% mature lymphoid cells with coarsely clumped chromatin. A nodular lymphoid infiltrate is found in the bone marrow. The lymphoid cells in the peripheral blood are positive for CD19, CD5, CD20, and CD23 but negative for CD79B and FMC-7. In this patient, the HPE of the lymph node will most likely show effacement of lymph node architecture by?

choices.text: A monomorphic lymphoid proliferation with admixed proliferation centres
A polymorphous population of lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils and scattered large binucleated cells
A predominantly follicular pattern with variably-sized follicles effacing nodal architecture
The diffuse proliferation of medium to large lymphoid cells with a high mitotic rate.

questions.solution:
Option A: A monomorphic lymphoid proliferation with admixed proliferation centres

  • This elderly female with symptoms of lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and peripheral blood lymphoid cells positive for CD19, CD5, CD20 and CD23 and negative for CD79B and FMC-7.
