  • These findings are highly consistent with a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is a monoclonal disorder.
  • The progressive accumulation of nonfunctional lymphocytes characterizes it.
  • The histological feature of most CLL consists of the proliferation of small mature B cells with irregularly condensed chromatin.
  • A histological hallmark is when it involves lymph nodes.
  • Lymph node biopsy is suggestive of a pseudofollicular pattern with proliferation centres.
  • The formation of proliferation centres (pseudofollicles) is due to nodular expansion of paraimmunoblast and prolymphocytes admixed with small lymphocytes.
  • Paraimmunoblast is a large cell with a round nucleus, an enlarged central nucleolus with basophilic cytoplasm and dispersed chromatin.
  • Prolymphocytes are small to medium mature lymphocytes with clumped chromatin.
  • The below image shows the lymph node histological features
  • Image A demonstrated a vaguely nodular (pseudofollicular pattern).
  • Image B demonstrates the predominance of small lymphocytes with scattered large cells (prolymphocytes and paraimmunoblasts).

Option B: A polymorphous population of lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils and scattered large binucleated cells

  • Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by Reed Sternberg cells.
  • Reed Sternberg cells are large binucleated or multinucleated cells with pale chromatin, present in a reactive background composed of mixed inflammatory cells consisting of small lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils and histiocytes.

Option C: A predominantly follicular pattern with variably-sized follicles effacing nodal architecture

  • Nodal architecture effaced by closely packed follicles is a characteristic of follicular lymphoma.
  • The closely packed follicles are composed of centroblasts and centrocytes.

Option D: A diffuse proliferation of medium to large lymphoid cells with a high mitotic rate.

  • The diffuse proliferation of large lymphoid cells is suggestive of high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Diffuse B cell lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma and peripheral T cell lymphoma are all types of high-grade Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with no known co-morbid presented to the hospital with complaints of spontaneous vaginal bleeding. She gets symptomatic treatment. She suffers from a tonic-clonic seizure in the next 24 hours. She is febrile, jaundiced, and has extensive purpura on physical examination. A haemoglobin of 5.3 g/dL with 8% reticulocytes, a platelet count of 10,000/mL, and a BUN of 48 mg/dL were found in the lab. A peripheral blood smear is also advised. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) occurs in acute or chronic form.
  • This disease has a pentad that includes fever, Microangiopathic hemolytic Anemia, Thrombocytopenia, Neurologic symptoms and Renal impairment.
  • All these things are positive in this patient.
  • The deposition of PAS-positive hyaline microthrombi in arterioles and capillaries throughout the body, particularly in the heart, brain, and kidneys, is a morphologic hallmark of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Platelet aggregates, fibrin, a few erythrocytes and leukocytes make up the microthrombi.
  • The peripheral blood smear displays microangiopathic hemolytic Anemia and numerous schistocytes.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura resembles hemolytic uremic syndrome, which occurs more often in children than adults.
  • The other choices are not associated with microangiopathic changes (e.g., schistocytes).

 

Option A: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia

  • Drugs can cause thrombocytopenia by several mechanisms, including direct bone marrow or other organ toxicity.
  • Clinically, these patients present with moderate to severe thrombocytopenia (defined as a platelet count of less than 50 × 109/L) and spontaneous bleeding varying from simple ecchymosis, petechiae, and mucosal bleeding to life-threatening spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage.
  • Excluding other causes of thrombocytopenia (such as congenital disorders and inflammatory processes) is important.
  • Many drugs can cause thrombocytopenia. Some of them are Heparin, furosemide, Gold, Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory disease, Antibiotics, and Statins.
  • In this case, no such drug has been used

Option B: Henoch-Schönlein purpura

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is the most common vasculitis in childhood.
  • It most commonly affects children 2-8 years of age 
  • The features include rash and one or more of the following:
    • Arthritis/arthralgia (50-75%)
    • Abdominal pain (50%)
    • Nephritis (25-50%)

Option C: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • It is a quantitative disorder of platelets caused by antibodies directed against platelet or megakaryocytic antigens.
  • Related to antibody-mediated immune destruction of platelets or their precursors.
  • The peripheral blood smear in Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura exhibits numerous large platelets, and the bone marrow shows a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes.
  • Clinical Features include:
    • Petechia
    • Purpura
    • Hemorrhagic bullae
    • Gum bleeding
    • Hematuria
    • Melena

questions.text: Carcinoid tumour arises from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Option B: Kulschitsky cells

  •  Carcinoid tumour/neuroendocrine tumour arises from neuroendocrine cells called Kulschitsky cells/Enterochromaffin (EC) cells present in the gastrointestinal tract & respiratory tract:
  • CARCINOID TUMOR
    • Arises from NEURO ENDOCRINE CELLS
    • Chromogranin
    • NSE
    • MC Site Involved → GIT more than Bronchus
    • Overproduction of 5-HT [Serotonin] occurs
    • ↑ 5HT in circulation by cancer cells
  • CLINICAL FEATURES
    • H → Hepatomegaly
    • I → Intestine [Diarrhea]
    • V → Vasomotor [Flushing]
    • A → Asthma-like symptoms
    • Systemic fibrosis
      • → Isolated Rt heart involvement Q
      • → Tricuspid valve
      • → Regurgitation / Insuficiency
      • → Pulmonary valve → Stenosis
  • DIAGNOSIS
    • 1. SCREENING TEST → 24 hr HIAA Levels in Urine
    • 2. PLASMA CHROMOGRAMIN - A Levels → ↑↑↑
    • 3. BIOPSY & ELECTRON MICROSCOPY
    • Granules
    • Chromogranin A ⊕
    • NSE ⊕ [Neuron specific enolase]

Option A: Hematopoietic cells

  • Carcinoid tumour does not arise from Hematopoietic cells

Option C: Neuroglial cells

  • Carcinoid tumour does not arise from Neuroglial cells

Option D: Chromaffin cells

  • Carcinoid tumour does not arise from Chromaffin cells

questions.text: A fifty-year-old man is brought to the emergency depart with complaints of shortness of breath. The patient is unable to complete a full sentence. Examination findings show a respiratory rate greater than 25 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, the patient is using his accessory muscle to breathe, and there is cyanosis of his extremities. Wheezes can be heard all over the chest on chest examination. The patient goes into respiratory failure and dies shortly after. If an autopsy is performed, which of the following is the most likely histological finding in this patient's lungs?

choices.text: Smooth muscle hypertrophy of the bronchus with a proliferation of eosinophils
Leakage of protein-rich fluid into alveolar spaces with diffuse alveolar damage
Destruction of alveolar walls with dilation of air spaces
Hypoplasia of bronchial submucosal glands, which secretes mucus

questions.solution:
Option A: Smooth muscle hypertrophy of the bronchus with a proliferation of eosinophils

 

  • Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease caused by the narrowing of airways.
  • It is also known as hyperreactive airway disease.
  • It is characterised as:
    • Bronchial hyperreactivity
    • Airway obstruction
  • Signs and symptoms include:
    • Wheezing
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest tightness
    • Coughing
  • Asthma manifests morphologically as:
    • Hypertrophy of smooth muscle of bronchus.
    • Hyperplasia of submucosal glands and goblet cells of the bronchus.

 

Option B: Leakage of protein-rich fluid into alveolar spaces with diffuse alveolar damage

  • Leakage of protein-rich fluid into alveolar spaces is seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • This patient has asthma.

 

Option C: Destruction of alveolar walls with dilation of air spaces

  • Destruction of alveolar walls is seen in emphysema.
  • This patient has asthma.

 

Option D: Hypoplasia of bronchial submucosal glands, which secretes mucus

  • Hyperplasia of bronchial submucosal glands can be seen in cystic fibrosis, asthma and chronic bronchitis.
  • This patient has asthma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman visits an outpatient clinic. She was concerned because she had discovered a lump in her right breast. Palpation revealed irregular nodularity. Mammography reveals varying densities in both breasts. A needle biopsy of a breast lesion is shown (see image below). An excisional biopsy of the contralateral breast reveals similar histology. Which of the following pathologic diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option B: Lobular carcinoma in situ 

  • Lobular carcinoma in situ is caused by the asynchronous growth of ducts and lobules. 
  • It is caused by the loss of the E - Cadherin gene, CDH1 (which produces a protein that connects cells). 
  • Because E-cadherin also functions as a tumor suppressor protein, so mutations can result in carcinoma development. 
  • Sometimes, a mutation in another protein called catenin is required for E-cadherin to function. 
  • Because LCIS and invasive lobular carcinoma share the same mutation, the risk of developing invasive lobular carcinoma increases. 
  • It is mostly unrelated to calcification and is discovered by chance. 
  • It is usually bilateral. 
  • Morphology of LCIS shows 
    • Uniform cells with oval or round nuclei (due to E- cadherin loss)
    • Signet ring cells 
  • It almost always expresses ER and PR but not HER2.
  • Prophylactic bilateral mastectomy, tamoxifen, and close clinical monitoring are all part of the treatment plan. 

Other Options

Option A: Colloid carcinoma

  • Colloid carcinoma is a soft rubbery mass. 
  • It appears to be floating cells in a lake of mucin. 

Option C: Phyllodes tumor

  • Phyllodes tumors are caused by a mutation in the MED12 gene, which causes stoma overgrowth. 
  • It does not match the histological presentation. 

Option D: Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinoma is caused by BRCA1 gene hypermethylation. 
  • The histological presentation does not explain this tumor

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presented to an outpatient clinic with a left breast mass. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and her pulse is 80/minute. Physical examination reveals a hard, immobile mass in the left outer quadrant. Axillary lymph nodes are also palpable. Ultrasound and mammography also show signs of carcinoma. The physician advised the patient to undergo a sentinel lymph node biopsy to confirm metastasis. What is meant by a sentinel lymph node?

choices.text: The first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives flow from a primary tumour
First lymph node to be biopsied in the tumour
The lymph node that is positive for malignancy in a tumour
The lymph node that is positive for malignancy and more than 2 cm in diameter

questions.solution:
Option A: First node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives flow from a primary tumour

  • The Sentinel lymph node is the first regional lymph node to drain lymph from the affected area. 
  • The sentinel lymph nodes in breast cancer are the axillary lymph nodes. 
  • To make therapeutic decisions, sentinel lymph node biopsies are performed. 
  • A biopsy can help determine whether or not metastatic carcinoma exists
  • The surgeon can make intraoperative decisions by 
    • Frozen sections of sentinel lymph nodes 
    • Mapping with coloured dyes or radiolabeled tracers. 
  • Regional lymph nodes act as a barrier to the spread of carcinoma. 
  • Immune responses in regional lymph nodes can destroy cancer cells. 
  • Because of these reactions, lymph nodes enlarge, and a microscopic examination is required to rule out metastasis. 

Option B: First lymph node to be biopsied in the tumour

  • Any lymph node can be the first to be biopsied in a tumour. 
  • The Sentinel lymph node is the first node in the lymphatic system to drain the affected area. 

Option C: The lymph node that is positive for malignancy in a tumour

  • In the case of metastatic disease, many lymph nodes may be positive. 
  • In the case of breast carcinoma, mediastinal lymph nodes and axillary lymph nodes can be positive for malignancy. 

Option D: The lymph node that is positive for malignancy and more than 2 cm in diameter

  • The sentinel lymph node is the first node that drains the affected area. 
  • The size of the lymph node does not define the Sentinel lymph node.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for a regular health check-up. She denies any current medical problem except that she remembers being hospitalised for a throat infection as a child. Examination reveals normal vitals. On physical examination, normal S1 and S2 with a late rumbling diastolic murmur is heard at the apex and is enhanced by expiration. Which of the following skin lesion is most likely accompanied by the illness?
questions.solution:
Option B: Erythema marginatum

  • Erythema marginatum is a non-pruritic, pink eruption in cases of acute rheumatic fever.
  • It is present on the trunk and sometimes on the limbs.
  • The face is mainly spared.
  • It is a consequence of pharyngeal infection with group A streptococcus, usually in childhood.
  • Rheumatic fever can sometimes lead to valvular damage, often mitral stenosis.
  • The characteristic murmur of MS is a late, rumbling diastolic murmur that changes with respiration, as described in the clinical case above.

 

 

Option A: Erythema migrans

  • It is a Bullseye red rash with central clearing:
  • It is present in the early stage of Lyme disease caused by borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by an infected black-legged tick.
  • Lyme disease can cause heart block but is not associated with MS.

 

 

Option C: Erythema multiforme

  • Erythema multiforme is a skin reaction due to type IV hypersensitivity, mostly triggered by infections, medications or other conditions.
  • It causes severe skin eruption that results in small red raised or target lesions all over the body, as given in the image.
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome is a major form of erythema multiforme.
  • Erythema multiforme does not accompany Rheumatic fever.

 

 

Option D: Janeway lesion

  • Janeway's lesions are non-tender, macular, and erythematous lesions on the palms and soles of the patient, as given in the image.
  • These are mostly present in the hand's thenar and hypothenar surface and the toes' plantar surface.
  • The duration is usually from days to weeks.
  • It is associated with acute infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A three-year-old child is brought to your clinic by his mother with complaints of fever and blood in his urine. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass in the child's abdomen. Further investigations are performed, and the mother is informed that her child suffers from the most malignant tumour in children. Which of the following is the most important determinant of the prognosis of patients with this tumour ?
questions.solution:
Option B: Histology

  • Wilms tumour is the most common renal cancer in children.
  • It is also called nephroblastoma.
  • Symptoms of Wilms tumour include:
    • Painless, palpable abdominal mass
    • Abdominal pain
    • Fever
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Hematuria
  • Wilms tumour is associated with multiple syndromes:
    • WAGR syndrome
    • Denys-Drash syndrome
    • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
  • The most important factor for the prognosis of Wilms tumour is histology.
  • Higher the degree of anaplasia, the poorer the prognosis.
  • The presence of anaplasia associated with the p53 gene mutation is responsible for the adverse prognosis.

Option A: Stage of disease

  • Staging is done to determine the prognosis and treatment.
  • Histology, however, is the most important prognosis factor for Wilms tumour.

Option C: Loss of chromosome 1p

  • A poorer prognosis is associated with a loss of heterozygosity at chromosome 1p.
  • Histology, however, is the most important prognosis factor for Wilms tumour.

 

Option D: Age of presentation

  • A poorer prognosis is associated with patients older than 2 years.
  • Histology, however, is the most important prognosis factor for Wilms tumour.

questions.text: A 60-year-old alcoholic male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of weight loss, weakness, and mild recurrent right upper abdominal pain for a month. He was diagnosed with alcoholic liver disease two years ago. His vitals are within the normal range. Examination reveals yellowish discolouration of eyes and sclera. Ultrasound abdomen shows hepatomegaly with solid nodules more than 10mm with irregular borders and portal vein thrombosis. A liver biopsy is done and shows the following histological procedure. Which of the following is true regarding this pathology?

choices.text: Chronic hepatitis B and C can lead to this condition
50% of hepatic adenomas can progress to this condition

questions.solution:
Option A: Chronic hepatitis B and C can lead to this condition

  • This is the case of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), in which the patient presents with complaints of weight loss, weakness, jaundice, and recurrent mild right upper abdominal pain due to hepatomegaly.
  • He is a known case of alcoholic liver disease. The medical history, along with the presence of signs and symptoms, establishes the diagnosis of HCC.
  • Alcohol abusers with liver cirrhosis are at an increased risk of developing HCC.
  • Ultrasonographic findings of solid nodules >10mm with irregular borders with hepatomegaly confirm the diagnosis.
  • Liver biopsy is used for the staging of the disease, with the morphological and histological picture showing a large nodular well-vascularized tumour with wide trabeculae, small cell changes, prominent acinar pattern, mitotic activity with cytological atypia with the presence of Mallory-bodies and the absence of Kupffer cells.
  • Chronic HBV and HCV infection in the presence of cirrhosis can increase the risk of HCC by 1000-fold due to chronic inflammation resulting in the integration of the viral genome into the host DNA.

 

 

Option B: Associated with increased p53 activity

  • P53 mutation is the most commonly occurring tumour suppressor genetic mutation in HCC and is usually associated with reduced p53 activity and increased emergence of potential tumour cells.
  • Exposure to aflatoxin (AFB-1) and chronic HBV infection is most associated with p53 mutation with its reduced activity. 

 

 

Option C: AFP is decreased

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are usually elevated in HCC due to the production by the tumour or by regenerated hepatocytes and activation of the β-catenin pathway.
  • AFP is 75-91% specific for the diagnosis of HCC, and a level higher than 400ng/mL is generally diagnostic in the presence of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Option D: 50% of hepatic adenomas can progress to this condition

  • Hepatic adenoma is an uncommon benign solid tumour of the liver with a high risk of progression to malignancy and haemorrhage.
  • However, only 10% of patients with hepatic adenoma can have a progression to hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A middle aged adult undergoes orchiectomy. Looking at the gross and the histological findings, which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most common germ cell tumor seen in middle-aged adults: Seminoma
  • Gross findings: Well circumscribed, no hemorrhage, no necrosis
  • M/E: Tumor cells have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with slurring of speech and right-side weakness of both upper and lower limbs. CT head revealed the presence of an infarct in the brain. Disease or infarction of neurological tissue causes it to be replaced by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Neuroglia

  • Reactive astrocytes can be seen as early as 1 week after the insult. 
  • As the process of liquefaction and phagocytosis proceeds, astrocytes at the edges of the lesion progressively enlarge, divide, and develop a prominent network of cytoplasmic extensions.
  • After several months, the astrocytic response recedes, leaving behind a dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and some perivascular connective tissue. 
  • In the cerebral cortex, the cavity is separated from the meninges and subarachnoid space by a gliotic layer of tissue derived from the molecular layer of the cortex. 
  • The pia and arachnoid are unaffected and do not contribute to the healing process.
  • Infarcts undergo these reactive and reparative stages from the inward edges; thus, different areas of a lesion may look different, particularly during the early stages, revealing the natural progression of the response.

Option A: Fluid

  • A dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and perivascular connective tissue is formed after several months of injury.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Proliferation of adjacent nerve cells

  • A dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and perivascular connective tissue is formed after several months of injury.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Blood vessel

  • A dense meshwork of glial fibres admixed with new capillaries and perivascular connective tissue is formed after several months of injury.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with right flank and lower back pain. His blood pressure is 150/96 mmHg, and Murphy's kidney punch is positive on the right side. What are the initial medication choices for suspected right renal nephrolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Chlorthalidone

  • In the above-given case, the sign and symptoms of right flank pain, positive Murphy's kidney punch, and high blood pressure are suggestive of the diagnosis of renal nephrolithiasis.
  • Chlortalidone is a thiazide diuretic drug used to treat high blood pressure and oedema due to heart failure, liver failure and nephrotic syndrome.
  • Thiazide diuretics such as chlorthalidone reduce calcium excretion in the urine.
  • This will help formation, especially in people with high calcium levels in the urine.

Option A: Furosemide

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases Ca2+ excretion and can precipitate the patient's condition, aggravating the situation.

Option B: Losartan

  • Losartan belongs to angiotensin II receptor antagonists.
  • Losartan is used mainly to treat high blood pressure.
  • High BP adds to the workload of the heart and arteries. However, it has little or no effect on renal stones.

Option C: Atenolol

  • Atenolol is a beta-blocker medication which is used to treat high BP and angina.
  • Other uses include the treatment of certain irregular heartbeats. Atenolol does not seem to improve mortality in those with high BP.

questions.text: A 44-year-old known hypertensive patient came into your clinic complaining of difficulty breathing and an increase in abdominal girth over the past week. On examination, fluid thrill and shifting dullness are appreciated. You extract the history that the patient is an alcoholic. If the patient is diagnosed with hepatic cirrhosis, which of the following medications would you prefer for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist, acting mainly on the distal tubules to increase natriuresis and conserve potassium.
  • Spironolactone is the drug of choice in the initial treatment of ascites due to cirrhosis.

  • Aldosterone Antagonism: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by antagonizing the effects of aldosterone, a hormone that promotes sodium and water retention in the kidneys. In cirrhosis, there is an imbalance in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, leading to increased aldosterone levels. By blocking the aldosterone receptors, spironolactone reduces sodium reabsorption and increases sodium excretion, thereby reducing fluid retention.

  • Diuretic Effect: Spironolactone promotes diuresis (increased urine production) and helps to eliminate excess fluid from the body. By reducing the volume of fluid in the intravascular and interstitial spaces, it helps to alleviate ascites.

  • Potassium-Sparing Action: Unlike some other diuretics, spironolactone has a potassium-sparing effect, meaning it reduces the excretion of potassium in the urine. This is important in the context of cirrhosis and ascites because liver dysfunction can lead to impaired potassium handling. Spironolactone helps maintain normal potassium levels while still promoting diuresis.

Option A: Furosemide

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic which causes marked natriuresis and diuresis in normal subjects.
  • It is generally used as an adjunct to spironolactone treatment because of its low efficacy when used alone in cirrhosis.
  • High doses of furosemide are associated with severe electrolyte disturbance and metabolic alkalosis and should be used cautiously.

Option B: Acetazolamide

  • Acetazolamide is not used for the treatment of hepatic cirrhosis.
  • At equally natriuretic doses, K+ excretion is maximum with carbonic anhydrase inhibitors because Na+ delivered to the distal tubules is exchanged only with K+ (excretion of H+ is inhibited by these drugs).
  • It has a high risk of causing hepatic encephalopathy.

Option D: Mannitol

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic; it has no documented role in the management of hepatic cirrhosis.

questions.text: Which statement is most likely inaccurate regarding the use of nedocromil in a 15-year-old boy experiencing recurrent shortness of breath, chest tightness, and nonproductive cough during or after soccer practice, despite having normal spirometry and oxygen saturation on room air?

choices.text: It is given by inhalational route

questions.solution:
Option A: Given in acute bronchial asthma

  • This patient is most likely suffering from acute asthma exacerbation, and he is receiving nedocromil for asthma prophylactic asthma management.
  • Nedocromil is a mast cell stabiliser that prevents the subsequent release of inflammatory mediators, including histamine and leukotrienes, which result in allergic symptoms and bronchoconstriction.
  • This drug inhibits mast cell degranulation, which is normally implicated in anaphylaxis and other reactive allergens.
  • This drug is a preventive treatment given prior to exercise and as a prophylactic treatment to prevent the recurrence of future asthma attacks.
  • However, this drug is NOT used in the acute exacerbation of asthma.

Option B: Inhibits degranulation of mast cells

  • This statement is correct about nedocromil, as this drug inhibits the degranulation of the mast cell.

Option C: It is not a bronchodilator

  • This statement is also correct, as nedocromil is not a bronchodilator.

Option D: It is given by inhalational route

  • The inhalational route administers nedocromil and other mast cell stabilisers.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, working as the CEO of a multi-million dollar Automobile company, comes to your clinic with complaints of a burning sensation in the abdomen for the past 3 months. The pain is more intense on an empty stomach, is relieved after eating food, and restarts after 2-3 hours of eating. He takes aspirin on and off, and a smoking history of 20-pack-year is also present. He claims to have taken on & off non-allopathic treatment without much benefit. What is the most likely diagnosis and suitable management option for this case?

choices.text: Duodenal ulcer, give omeprazole and advise him to stop smoking and consume aspirin
Gastric ulcer, give omeprazole and advise him to stop smoking

questions.solution:
Option A: Duodenal ulcer, give omeprazole and advise to stop smoking and aspirin

  • The patient presents with the typical symptoms of duodenal ulcers, such as epigastric pain that relieves by eating and increases on an empty stomach.           
  • Smoking and aspirin are the causative factors in this case. Smoking stimulates basal acid output causing peptic ulcer disease. It also increases the risk of infection from Helicobacter pylori, which is 90% associated with duodenal ulcers. Aspirin can also damage the gastro-duodenal by various mechanisms, e.g. topical irritant effect on the epithelium, inhibition of gastric prostaglandins and blood reduction in the mucosa.
  • The main goal is to stop smoking, stop taking aspirin and start anti-ulcer drugs such as omeprazole.
  • Cimetidine should be avoided in elderly patients, as it causes CNS disturbances such as confusion and encephalopathy.

           

Option B: Gastric ulcer, give omeprazole and advise to stop smoking 

  • In a Gastric ulcer, pain increases by eating, and the patient wants to vomit out to relieve pain.  

 

Option C: Pancreatic ulcer, give cimetidine

  • In pancreatic ulcer, the patient presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back in the inter-scapular region.

 

Option D: Duodenal ulcer, give cimetidine

  • Cimetidine should be avoided in elderly patients, as it causes CNS disturbances such as confusion and encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient who was undergoing surgery was given a muscle relaxant. It produced a marked fall in BP and an increase in airway resistance which were then reversed with diphenhydramine. The muscle relaxant was most probably which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tubocurarine

  • The nicotinic acetylcholine receptor is competitively inhibited by tubocurarine, meaning that this alkaloid blocks the nerve impulse.

  • These alkaloids have a discernibly broad range of activities and potential uses.

  • Hypotension and bronchoconstriction (increase in airway resistance) are important adverse effects caused by histamine.

  • This is confirmed to be due to histamine because of reversal with diphenhydramine.

  • Maximum histamine release is caused by d-tubocurarine.

  • Vecuronium does not cause histamine release. Therefore, it is the preferred agent in asthmatic patients.

Option A: Pancuronium

  • It is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent.

  • It competitively inhibits the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction by blocking acetylcholine binding.

  • Side effects:

    • Flushing

    • Increased saliva

    • Rash

    • Bronchospasm

  • It is used as a supplement to general anaesthesia to help with tracheal intubation and to give skeletal muscle relaxation during surgery or mechanical breathing.

Option B: Diazepam

  • The class of drugs known as benzodiazepines includes diazepam.

  • It is used to treat seizures and fits as well as anxiety.

  • Additionally, it is applied in hospitals to lessen the effects of alcohol withdrawal, such as sweating and trouble sleeping.

  • It is used in multiple conditions like anxiety, seizures, alcohol withdrawal syndrome, muscle spasms, insomnia, and restless legs syndrome.

Option D: Vecuronium

  • This is a neuromuscular blocking agent.

  • It is often used to facilitate endotracheal intubation and surgical relaxation in patients under general anaesthesia.

  • It is used as part of general anaesthesia to provide skeletal muscle relaxation.

  • It is an androstane, a quaternary ammonium ion and an acetate ester.

questions.text: To which of the following class does the drug ‘Pyronaridine’ belong??
questions.solution:
Option A: Antimalarial drug

  • Pyronaridine is an antimalarial agent related to amodi­aquine.
  • It is highly effective against chloroquine resist­ant falciparum malaria.
  • Currently, it is being evaluated in combination with artesunate.
  • Pyronaridine inhibits the formation of hemozoin polymer, which is a waste product of haemoglobin, and hence it facilitates the formation of hematin and free haemoglobin, which are both toxic to the parasite digestive vacuole ​​​​​​​

Option B: Anti-HIV drug

  • Anti-HIV drugs are NRTIs like didanosine and protease inhibitors like ritonavir

Option C: Antifungal drug

  • Antifungal drugs are the azoles like clotrimazole

Option D: Antibacterial drug

  • Antibiotics are antibacterial drugs like penicillin and clindamycin

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman has a throbbing headache, nausea, vomiting, and subsequent tingling, numbness, and blue discoloration of a finger tip. Which drug is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dihydroergotamine

  • Dihydroergotamine forms due to the hydrogenation of ergotamine. As a result, the serotonergic and alpha-adrenergic agonist actions are reduced, but alpha receptor blocking property is enhanced. Therefore, it is a less potent vasoconstrictor, constricts capacitance vessels, and causes less intimal damage than ergotamine.
  • This patient developed such symptoms of vasoconstriction (tingling, numbness, fingertip turning blue) - This is a classical sign of Dihydroergot-induced vasoconstriction.
  • Dihydroergotamine can be used for an acute migraine attack, resulting in these symptoms.
  • The most common side effects are nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, muscle cramps, weakness, paresthesias and vascular spasms of coronary and other vessels, causing chest pain, myocardial ischemic disease, and worsening peripheral vascular disease.
  • Due to their vasoconstricting potential, ergot alkaloids are contra-indicated in patients with peripheral vascular disease. These may also lead to the development of gangrene.
  • Contraindications for ergotamine usage:
    • Peripheral vascular disease
    • Coronary artery disease
    • Uncontrolled hypertension
    • Fever and/or sepsis
    • Pregnancy
    • Within 24 hours of using triptans

Option B: Sumatriptan

  • Sumatriptan is a vasoconstrictor which can result in limb paresthesia, weakness and coronary vasospasm. However, these are infrequent side effects and are short lasting.

Option C: Aspirin

  • Aspirin inhibits the enzymes COX-1 and COX-2. Doing this causes inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Inhibition of the thromboxane A2 synthesis leads to increased bleeding time from impaired platelet aggregation. However, it does not cause vasoconstriction of peripheral vessels and does not cause ischemic vascular disease.

Option D: Butorphanol

  • It is an opioid κ receptor agonist that works as an analgesic and causes nausea, sedation, respiratory depression and cardiac stimulation. It should be avoided in patients with cardiac ischemia.
  • It has no effects on the peripheral vessels leading to ischemic disease

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of neck mass and weight loss for 2-months. The mass is painless. The patient also complains of loss of appetite and mild abdominal pain. He gives no history of any other abnormalities and has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On the examination of the neck, there is a painless, golf ball-sized mass in the anterior triangle of the neck. The biopsy of the patient is done, which is shown in the image below. Which of the following is included in the treatment protocol of the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vinblastine

  • This is a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma in which the patient presents with complaints of a painless swelling in the neck accompanied by weight loss for 2 months.
  • The patient also gives a history of mild abdominal pain and loss of appetite during this period of time.
  • The patient gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illness.
  • The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) in the biopsy of the patient points to a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
  • Out of the above-mentioned drugs, only vinblastine is included in the treatment protocol for Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option A: Actinomycin-D

  • Actinomycin-D is a chemotherapy agent.
  • It is used in the treatment of:
    • Wilms tumour
    • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Option B: Ciprofloxacin

  • Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic, and it is not used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • It is most commonly used in the treatment of abdominal infections.

Option D: Methotrexate

  • Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent.
  • It is commonly used for:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Choriocarcinoma

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant female presents to the clinic with a complaint of vaginal discharge. A diagnosis of gonorrhoea is made. Patient history is significant of a severe allergy to amoxicillin; which of the following drugs can be used to treat gonorrhoea in a single dose?
questions.solution:
Option D: Spectinomycin

  • Pregnant women infected with N. gonorrhoeae should be treated with dual therapy consisting of ceftriaxone 250 mg in a single IM dose and azithromycin 1 g orally as a single dose.
  • Spectinomycin is useful in persons who cannot tolerate cephalosporins.

Option A: Ceftriaxone

  • Due to cross hypersensitivity, 10% of the patients with a history of penicillin allergy will have an allergic reaction if given a cephalosporin.
  • Therefore, ceftriaxone can not be given to patients with severe allergies to penicillins.

Option B: Tetracycline

  • Tetracyclines are teratogenic and are contraindicated in pregnancy.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin

  • Ciprofloxacin is teratogenic and is contraindicated in pregnancy

questions.text: In a 55-year-old man with symptoms including anorexia, weakness, shortness of breath, and paraesthesia, the investigation revealed hemoglobin of 6.8 g/dl, macrocytes and neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei on peripheral smear, sluggish tendon reflexes, and atrophic gastritis on endoscopy. What drug is likely to be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cyanocobalamin

  • In this case, a 55-year-old man presented with signs and symptoms of anaemia.
  • Endoscopy revealed atrophic gastritis. Haemoglobin is 6.8 g/dl and the peripheral smear showed the presence of macrocytes and neutrophils having hyper-segmented nuclei. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Pernicious anaemia can be made.
  • Pernicious anaemia is associated with atrophic gastritis leading to decrease vitamin B12 absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Intrinsic factor is released by parietal cells in the stomach. In atrophic gastritis, parietal cells are damaged by auto-antibodies.
  • Intrinsic factor is required for vitamin B12 absorption in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia along with neurological symptoms.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause sub-acute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and peripheral neuritis—diminished vibration and position sense, paresthesia and depressed stretch reflexes

Option A: Folic acid

  • Folic acid absorption occurs in the small intestine, and it does not need an intrinsic factor for its absorption.
  • Its deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia without any neurological symptoms.

Option C: Ferrous Sulphate

  • It is indicated in iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells on peripheral smear report.

Option D: Erythropoietin

  • Erythropoietin is used in chronic renal failure-induced anaemia and bone marrow suppression-induced anaemia.
  • It is released by the kidney's interstitial cells that stimulate the production of erythrocytes in the bone marrow.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents in the ER with alcohol intoxication. Twelve hours later, she shows agitation and seizure-like symptoms, along with shakiness and nausea. With a history of alcohol use disorder, her vital signs are stable. What's the mechanism of action of the preferred drug for this situation?

choices.text: Facilitate GABA by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening
Facilitate GABA action by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

questions.solution:
Option A: Facilitate GABA by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening

  • The clinical scenario describes withdrawal symptoms.
  • Long-acting benzodiazepines are used to treat withdrawal symptoms.
  • Benzodiazepine works by increasing the opening frequency of chloride channels.
  • Alcohol and benzodiazepines are central nervous system (CNS) depressants that stimulate GABA and inhibit glutamate receptors.
  • Chronic use leads to the downregulation of the GABA receptor and upregulation of the glutamate receptor.
  • Thus, sudden cessation causes glutamate-mediated overexcitation of the CNS.
  • The above symptoms usually appear within 2 days of stopping alcohol.
  • Severe alcohol withdrawal can be potentially fatal due to delirium tremens and seizures.
  • It requires early recognition and treatment with long-acting benzodiazepines.
  • Chlordiazepoxide: It's a drug of choice for an alcohol withdrawal condition called Delirium Tremens.

 

 

 

Option B: Facilitate GABA action by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

  • Barbiturates work by increasing the opening time of the chloride channel.

 

Option C: 5HT antagonist

  • 5HT antagonists are serotonin inhibitors.
  • Atypical antipsychotics work by inhibiting 5HT receptors.

 

Option D: 5HT agonist

  • 5HT agonists are serotonin receptor stimulators.
  • They are used in the treatment of migraines and anxiety.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to the outdoor patient department for a routine check-up. The physician finds his basal glucose level to be 250 mg/dL. He prescribes him long-acting insulin and short-acting insulin. Which of the following is long-acting insulin and treated like basal insulin?
questions.solution:
Option C: Glargine

  • Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin that is administered once daily and delivers a basal insulin level throughout the day.
  • Insulin glargine is used by people who have type 1 or type  2 diabetes. In order to achieve optimal glycemic control, several treatments combine it with insulin with a quick onset of action.
  • At the beginning stages of type 1 diabetes, patients frequently require both long-acting and short-acting insulins in order to control their blood sugar levels.
  • Because of the destruction of beta cells in the pancreas that is caused by autoimmunity in type 1 diabetes, the body loses its ability to manufacture insulin from the pancreas, which leads to a rapid loss of control over the amount of glucose in the blood. Insulin glargine is used for basal glycemic control due to the fact that its duration of action lasts for 24 hours, whereas rapid-acting insulin is used for coverage of elevated blood glucose and carbohydrate intake due to the fact that its onset of action is rapid and its duration of action is relatively short.
  • Indications:
    • DM type 1
    • Uncontrolled DM 2
    • Gestational DM
    • DK
    • Hyperkalemia

Option A: Lispro

  • Lispro is a rapid-acting insulin.

Option B: Aspart

  • Aspart is a rapid-acting insulin.

Option D: Glulisine

  • Glulisine is a rapid-acting insulin.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female presents to an outpatient department with complaints of a burning micturition and lower abdominal pain. She was on empirical antibiotics for urinary tract infections, but there was no improvement. A mid-stream urine sample was collected and sent for antibiotic sensitivity testing in the laboratory. Which of the following McFarland standards is the minimum requirement for analysing the antibiotic sensitivity of the given sample?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mc Farland standard 0.5

  • McFarland Standards are used to calculate the approximate number of bacteria in a liquid suspension by comparing the turbidity of the test suspension with that of the McFarland Standard.
  • A McFarland Standard is a chemical solution of sulphuric acid.
  • The turbidity of a McFarland Standard is visually comparable to a bacterial suspension of known concentration on shaking well.
  • 0.5 McFarland Standard is most commonly used in the clinical microbiology laboratory, which is prescribed for antimicrobial susceptibility testing and culture media performance testing.

 

Option B: Mc Farland standard 1

  • For the antibiotic sensitivity test, the organism broth prepared should match with McFarland standard 0.5.
  • McFarland Standard 1 is not used for antimicrobial sensitivity testing.

 

Option C:  Mc Farland standard 2

  • McFarland Standard 2 is not considered suitable for antimicrobial sensitivity testing.

 

Option D: Mc Farland standard 3

  • McFarland Standard 3 is not considered suitable for antimicrobial sensitivity testing.
  • The suspension should be diluted with saline if the bacterial density is too heavy in the cultured broth,
  • In contrast, if the Bacterial density is not sufficient, then more bacteria should be added to the suspension, or it can be cultured for some more time until the required turbidity appears.
  •  The adjusted bacterial suspensions should be used as inoculation within 15-20 minutes for the desired results.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, cough, sore throat, headache and tiredness for 8 days. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. A sample was sent to the laboratory for testing. The growth obtained on solid media is shown in the image below. Which of the following bacterial colonies are visualised?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mycoplasma pneumoniae

  • This is a case of atypical pneumonia in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, cough, sore throat, headache, and tiredness for 8 days.

  • The image given above in the case shows the growth of mycoplasma pneumonia, which suggests atypical pneumonia caused due to mycoplasma.

  • Mycoplasma produces colonies that are typically biphasic and have a ‘fried egg appearance’ consisting of a central opaque granular area of growth extending into a depth of medium surrounded by a flat translucent zone.

  • Lab diagnosis:

    • CAT (Cold Agglutination Test) → Type of heterophile agglutination test.

    • Streptococcus MG Agglutination test → Type of heterophile agglutination test.

    • PCR for M. pneumoniae.

Option A: Coxiella burnetii

  • Coxiella burnetii is a gram-negative bacterium.

  • It naturally affects animals.

  • When it infects humans, it causes Q-fever in humans.

Option B: Bordetella pertussis

  • Bordetella pertussis is a small-sized, gram-negative bacterium.

  • It usually causes whooping cough, which is an acute respiratory tract infection.

Option D: Legionellae

  • Legionellae is a gram-negative bacterium.

  • It can cause:

    • Pneumonia

    • Pontiac fever

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and weight loss. Amoebic liver abscess was confirmed on further examination, and the patient underwent an abscess drainage procedure for management. Soon after that, he developed symptoms of cutaneous amoebiasis. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient's current symptoms?

choices.text: It is a non-spreading necrotizing inflammation of the skin and cutaneous tissue
Rapid improvement with anti-amoebic treatment occurs
It doesn't occur in the perianal region
The infection reaches the skin through the air

questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option B: Rapid improvement with anti-amoebic treatment occurs

  • This is a case of amoebic liver abscess in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and weight loss.

  • The patient currently has symptoms of cutaneous amoebiasis.

  • Entamoeba histolytica causes cutaneous amoebiasis.

  • Usually, intestinal amoebiasis is present concomitantly with cutaneous amoebiasis.

Cutaneous amoebiasis:

  • Cutaneous amoebiasis or Amoebiasis cutis- is usually seen over the region adjoining a visceral lesion, e.g. area of drainage of liver abscess or colostomy wound or from the rectum.

  • It may also be seen following anal intercourse.

  • Perianal skin ulcers: By direct extension of ulcers to the perianal skin.

  • Ameboma (Amoebic granuloma): a diffuse pseudotumor-like mass of granulomatous tissue found in the rectosigmoid region and sometimes growing sufficiently large to block the lumen

  • Rapid improvement with anti-amoebic treatment occurs.

  • D.O.C:- Metronidazole

Other options

Option A: It is a non-spreading necrotizing inflammation of the skin and cutaneous tissue

  • It is not a non-spreading inflammation.

  • It is a spreading necrotizing inflammation of the skin and cutaneous tissue.

Option C: It doesn't occur in the perianal region

  • Perianal skin ulcers are also seen in cutaneous amoebiasis.

  • Due to direct extension of ulcers to the perianal skin.

Option D: The infection reaches the skin through the air

  • Cutaneous amoebiasis is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and rarely sexual transmission (20–30% in homosexuals).

questions.text: A 30-year-old African female presents to OPD with a complaint of fever for the last 2 days. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg, a pulse rate of 80 beats per minute, and lymphadenitis. His blood smear examination shows sheathed microfilaria with two nuclei in the tail tip. Which one of the following is true about the patient's given condition?

choices.text: The intermediate hosts in India are Mansonia
W. Bancrofti is the causative organism
Nuclei are clear, so counting is difficult
The immature worm is found in the lymphatic system

questions.solution:
Option A: The intermediate hosts in India are Mansonia.

  • Brugia malayi has 2 terminal nuclei: Microfilaria of brugia malayi
  • Transmission:
    • Nocturnal strains: Transmitted from man-man by the bite of Mansonia
    • Subperiodic strains: Transmitted from monkeys (zoonotic) by Mansonia anopheles and Aedes rarely transmit.
  • Diagnosis: Microfilaria is differentiated from W. bancrofti by the pointed tail tip; the nuclei column is darkly stained, large, coarse, overlapping, and extended till the tail tip.
  • The head end of microfilaria - Sheathed, cephalic space (2:1), darkly stained large coarse overlapping nuclei.
  • The tail end of microfilaria – 4-5 nuclei in the tail region and 2 widely spaced nuclei in the tail tip

Option B: W. bancrofti is the causative organism

  • Brugia malayi is causative organism and
  • TAIL TIP shows no nuclei in W. bancrofti.

Option C: Nuclei are clear, so counting is difficult.

  • The nuclei of Brugia malayi are blurr, so counting is difficult.

Option D: Immature worm is found in the lymphatic system

  • The adult worm is found in the lymphatic system, not immature.
  • The adult worms live in the lower intestine, coming out of the anus at night to lay their eggs.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presented to ER with a toothache on the left side of the face for 7 days with subsequent development of pain and swelling associated with periorbital oedema. She was a known case of Type-1 DM for 2 years. Her culture report confirmed the presence of aseptate hyphae. Which of the following shows the presence of aseptate hyphae?
questions.solution:
Option A: Zygomycetes

  • Zygomycetes are fungi belonging to the division Zygomycota of the kingdom Fungi.
  • Zygomycetes are a lower group of fungi and include:
    • Mucor
    • Rhizopus
    • Absidia
  • Zygomycetes lack internal cross-walls called septa and hence are called aseptate fungi.
  • Zygomycetes do not have chitin as a structural component of their cell wall. Their cell wall contains chitosan- the deacetylated homopolymer of chitin.

Option B: Ascomycetes

  • Ascomycetes are a higher group of fungi.
  • They belong to the phylum Ascomycota.
  • Ascomycetes have septate hyphae, unlike zygomycetes.
  • This group includes:
    • Dermatophytes
    • Aspergillus

Option C: Basidiomycetes

  • Basidiomycetes are fungi of the division Basidiomycota.
  • Basidiomycota, together with Ascomycota, constitute the subkingdom Dikarya.
  • Basidiomycetes are filamentous fungi composed of hyphae. Hyphae in this group of fungi are septate.
  • This group includes:
    • Mushrooms
    • Puffballs
    • Stinkhorns
    • Bracket fungi
    • Mirror yeasts
    • Cryptococcus

Option D: Deuteromycetes

  • Deuteromycetes are also called imperfect fungi.
  • They do not fit into the commonly established taxonomic classification of fungi.
  • Deuteromycetes have septate hyphae.
  • They reproduce asexually and do not display a sexual phase.
  • Examples of Deuteromycetes include:
  • Alternaria
  • Colletotrichum
  • Trichoderma

questions.text: A 56-year-old presents to the physician with complaints of high fever, headache, confusion and neck stiffness for one week. The patient had a history of pulmonary TB 5 years back, for which he received complete treatment. He is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. The doctor suspects meningitis and orders a CSF examination. The sample was sent for analysis in the laboratory. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tubercular meningitis

  • This is a case of tubercular meningitis in which the patient presents with complaints of high fever, headache, confusion and neck stiffness for the past week.
  • Tubercular meningitis is also usually accompanied by fits.
  • In the case of tubercular meningitis, there is usually a history of pulmonary TB.
  • CSF Chloride is decreased in tuberculous meningitis.
  • In this case, the meninges surrounding the brain are affected.
  • CSF from tuberculous meningitis often develops a spider web clot on standing.
  • Other CSF findings are increased lymphocytes, Decreased chloride.
  • The use of PCR and DNA probes may help detect the bacilli speedily and more often.

Option A: Chronic alcoholism

  • This case is not of chronic alcoholism because the symptoms of the patient clearly suggest meningitis.

Option B: General paralysis of insane

  • General paralysis of the insane is caused by syphilis.
  • It is a neuropsychiatric disorder affecting the central nervous system.

Option C: Pyogenic meningitis

  • Pyogenic meningitis is a serious disease in which there is an accumulation of pus in the brain due to inflammation of the meninges,

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic by his parents with complaints of high fever, cough and runny nose for 5 days. Two days after these symptoms started, he developed some spots opposite the lower 2nd molar. And now he has developed a rash over his neck, trunk and arms. Which of the following statement is true about the given condition?

choices.text: Infective period is 1 week before to 1 week after the appearance of the rash
Infection does not give life-long immunity

questions.solution:
Option D: Koplik spots are seen

  • The baby boy is likely suffering from measles based on the findings of koplik spot and rash.
  • Measles is a highly contagious acute viral disease caused by the single-stranded RNA measles virus.
  • Koplik spots are pathognomonic of measles.
  • They are found opposite the second molar.
  • They appear at the end of the prodrome, which lasts for 3 to 5 days and is characterized by high-grade fever and lassitude.
  • It is usually found just before the appearance of the rash.
  • The infectivity period of measles is 4 days before the rash and 5 days after the rash.
  • The isolation period of measles is up to 3rd day of the rash.
  • The incubation period of measles is 10-14 days.
  • Secondary Attack Rate → > 90%
  • Inclusion Bodies → WARTHIN FINKELDEY GIANT CELLS
  • Fever → Koplik spot → Rash
    • (Occur on the 10th day) (12th day) (14th day)

Option A: Infective period is 1 week before to 1 week after the appearance of the rash

  • The infectivity period of measles is 4 days before the rash and 5 days after the rash.
  • The isolation period of measles is up to 3rd day of the rash.

Option B: Infection does not give life-long immunity

  • Measles virus infection provides life-long immunity.
  • The infection can be prevented by vaccines too.

Option C: SSPE is an early complication

  • SSPE (Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is NOT an early complication.
  • It is a very rare complication of measles but can be fatal.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient, who has been a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension for 10 years, presents with acute infection, redness and pain in his scrotum and penis. On examination, he has an acute necrotic infection of the scrotum & penis associated with rapid progression to gangrene and sloughing of tissue. The doctor orders his internee to make arrangements for emergency surgical debridement. Which of the following is the most common associated organism?
questions.solution:
Option B: Streptococcus

  • Fournier's gangrene is necrotizing fasciitis of the genitalia, usually affecting the scrotum and penis.
  • Many types of bacteriological culture have been encountered in Fournier's gangrene, both single strain and polymicrobial culture.
  • Most cases are due to mixed infections caused by aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
  • The most common causative organism is Streptococcus pyogenes (Beta-hemolytic streptococci).
  • Others are Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterobacteriaceae (E. coli, Klebsiella, proteus), Enterococci, Pseudomonas, and Anaerobes like Bacteroides and Peptostreptococcus.
  • There are two types of necrotizing fasciitis:
    • Type 1:- It is a polymicrobial infection, i.e. mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection. It occurs most commonly after surgical procedures in diabetic patients or those with peripheral vascular disease.
    • Type 2:- It is caused most commonly by streptococcus pyogenes (Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci).

Option A: Staphylococcus

  • Staphylococcus aureus has been identified as the most common cause of pyomyositis.
  • Pyomyositis is a localized infection of skeletal muscles.

Option C: Proteus

 Proteus is pleomorphic bacillus → Any shape , Gram Gram-negative-capsulated, Fishy odour, Swarming is seen.

It does not lead to Fournier's gangrene .

Option D: Pneumococcus

  • Necrotizing fasciitis due to streptococcus pneumonia is very rare.
  • It is one of the main causes of community-acquired pneumonia and meningitis

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of fever, headache, dyspepsia, and epigastric pain for 1 week. The patient further explains that the fever is on and off and is more severe at night. The doctor orders a blood culture of the patient. Before the test, the laboratory technician started sterilizing disposable plastic Petri dishes and syringes, for which he decided to use the ethylene oxide sterilization method. What is the operating temperature in the sterilization method used in this case during a warm cycle?
questions.solution:
Option A : 49-63ºC

  • This is a case of typhoid fever in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, epigastric pain, headache, and dyspepsia.
  • The investigation of choice for typhoid fever in the first 2 weeks is blood culture.
  • The operating temperature in an ethylene oxide sterilization during a warm cycle is 49-63ºC.
  • Ethylene oxide sterilization (High-level disinfectant)
    • Cold cycle starts at 37 + 5 ºC
    • The warm cycle starts at 54 + 5 ºC
    • ETO is a highly penetrating gas
  • Factors affecting ETO disinfectant power:
    • ETO concentration
    • Humidity
    • Temperature
    • AT ETO concentration of 700 mg/l & 40-50% relative humidity at 38oC, sterilization is achieved [5-8hrs]
  • Control→ Bacillus Globigii spores used.
  • All other options are incorrect.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was admitted to the hospital with a 4-day history of swollen lymph nodes of the neck. She has a fever, fatigue, and lack of appetite. On examination, she is lethargic with normal vital signs and has a maculopapular rash on the trunk, neck, palms and pressure points. The doctor confirmed the diagnosis as an infection caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. What is the mechanism of autoimmunity in this infection?

choices.text: Inappropriate Expression of MHC Class II Molecules

questions.solution:
Option D: Polyclonal B cell activation

  • Epstein Barr virus causes autoimmunity by Polyclonal B-cell activation.

  • Polyclonal B cell activation: Directly induces the proliferation and differentiation of antibody-secreting cells from different B cells regardless of their antigen specificity.

  • Mechanisms to autoimmunity:-

    • Exposure of Sequestered antigens: lens and sperm protein

    • Formation of neoantigens

    • Cross-reacting antigens

    • Polyclonal activation of B cells

    • Inappropriate expression of MHC class II molecules

  • The Epstein-Barr virus is commonly known for causing infectious mononucleosis.

  • It is one of the members of the herpes virus family.

  • Epstein-Barr virus has also been associated with Burkitt’s lymphoma.

  • It is usually a self-resolving condition.

  • Other examples of autoimmunity disorders include

    • Graves’ disease

    • SLE

    • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

    • Myasthenia Gravis

    • Rheumatoid Arthritis

Option A: Molecular mimicry

  • In this, an environmental trigger mimics a body component so that  an immune reaction is directed against the cross-reacting body components, E.g., Reiter’s syndrome occurs after Chlamydia or Shigella infection.

Option B: Release of Sequestered Antigen

  • Certain self-antigens are present in closed systems and are not accessible to the immune apparatus. E.g., sperm, CNS, lens, uveal eye tract.

Option C: Inappropriate Expression of MHC Class II Molecules

  • It is found in almost all organ-specific autoimmune disorders.

  • Examples: type-1 diabetes.

questions.text: The medical officer arrives to examine the 22-year-old woman who had been brought in unconscious with a blood-soaked cloth tied around her left wrist. She was allegedly found by her roommate in a pool of blood with a kitchen knife lying next to her in the bathroom of their dorm. On examination, the doctor notes the presence of multiple shallow incision wounds extending from the lateral to the medial aspect indicating hesitation when making the cuts. These will be documented as evidence to support which type of wounds??
questions.solution:
Option A: Self-inflicted wounds

  • Hesitation cuts are seen in suicidal wounds/ self-inflicted wounds.
  • Hesitation cuts/marks or tentative cuts or trial wound: These cuts are multiple, small and superficial often involving only the skin, and are seen at the beginning of the incised wound, presumably hesitating while gaining courage to make a final decisive cut.

Option B: Homicidal wounds

  • Hesitation cuts are absent in homicidal wounds.

Option C: Defence wounds

  • Defense wounds are wounds of the extremities, which result from the immediate and instinctive reaction of the victim to ward off an attack.
  • Defense wounds are absent if the victim is: unconscious; taken by surprise; attacked from behind and under the influence of alcohol/drugs.

Option D: Accidental wounds

  • Hesitation cuts are absent in accidental wounds
  • Accidental wounds are rare. They are caused by falling against projecting sharp objects like glass, nails, etc.,

questions.text: A 27-year-old man has filed a case of criminal negligence against a doctor after repeat X-rays on a follow-up visit showed that his fractured right radial bone had malunited and thus created a deformity. The lawyer defending the doctor attempted to use one of the following doctrines during the trial but was reminded by the judge that it cannot be used in case of criminal negligence. Which doctrine among the following was the lawyer citing?
questions.solution:
Option B: Contributory negligence

  • Contributory negligence: The plaintiff failed to take reasonable care of his safety and this factor contributed to the harm ultimately suffered by the plaintiff.
  • The burden of proof lies with the defendant (doctor in this case).

Option A: Vicarious liability

  • Vicarious Liability or Respondent Superior.
  • A doctrine that holds an employer legally responsible for the wrongful acts of an employee, if such acts occur within the scope of the employment.

Option C: Res ipsa loquitur

  • Res ipsa loquitur: Doctrine of common knowledge.
  • The very nature of an accident or injury itself proves the negligent action of the physician.

Option D: Novus actus interveniens

  • Novus actus interveniens: "New act intervening" breaking the chain of causation such that even if the defendant has acted negligently, a subsequent intervening action breaks the chain of causation with the loss or damage sustained and so the defendant is not liable.

questions.text: The body of a 25-year-old man is being examined by a forensic pathologist. He had allegedly consumed sulphuric acid intentionally to commit suicide. The doctor notices that the lips and tongue are swollen and blackish. The teeth appear chalky white and the injuries are limited to the upper respiratory and digestive tract. The doctor is aware of the characteristics of acid burns. Which one of the following is true of an acid burn?

choices.text: Greater risk of severe systemic toxicity

questions.solution:
Option C: Perforation is more common

  • Perforation is more common in an acid burn.

Option A: Liquefactive necrosis

  • Acid burns cause coagulation necrosis, NOT Liquefactive necrosis.

Option B: Saponification occurs

  • Alkaline causes saponification.

Option D: Greater risk of severe systemic toxicity

  • In acid ingestion, local symptoms are more severe than systemic symptoms.

questions.text: In traditional Chinese medicine, the roots of  the plant are used only after processing to reduce the toxic alkaloid content. The use of a larger than recommended dose and inadequate processing increases the risk of poisoning. A characteristic finding in the case of poisoning with this plant toxin is the presence of "Hippus sign", where the pupils alternately contract and dilate. Which one of the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aconite

  • In Aconite poisoning: The pupils alternately contract and dilate (hippus) but remain dilated in the later stages.

Option A: Opium

  • The contact of morphine with the skin of sensitive persons may cause erythema, urticaria and itching dermatitis.
  • When opium is taken by mouth, symptoms begin within half hour. If the drug is injected, its action is noted within 3 or 4 minutes. It first stimulates, then depresses and finally paralyses the nerve centres.

Option B: Curare

  • Curareis found in various species of strychnos. Curarine is the active principle. Its action is entirely peripheral and at the myoneural junction, and blocks the postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in muscles, thus causing a flaccid paralysis of skeletal muscles.
  • It causes gradual paralysis of limbs followed by paralysis of respiratory muscle and death from asphyxia. There is headache, vertigo, mydriasis, blurred vision and hypotension due to the liberated histamine.

Option D: Datura

  • Datura: A member of the Solanaceae family, the fruits are spherical and have sharp spines known as thorn-apple.
  • All parts of these plants are poisonous: Fruit, Flowers, and Seeds (highest concentrations of alkaloids are found in roots and seeds).
  • Active Principles: The plant contains belladonna alkaloids whose primary actions are anticholinergic.
    • Hyoscine (scopolamine). The major active principle is hyoscine.
    • Hyoscyamine
    • Atropine
  • Dryness of mouth, dysphagia, dilated pupils, dry; hot skin, drunken gait, delirium, drowsiness, death due to respiratory failure can be seen.

questions.text: The body of a 45-year-old male with a known history of HIV infection has been sent for postmortem investigations. What is the best method of organ removal in the autopsy of this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rokinansky method

  • Rokitansky's technique: It involves in situ dissection in part, combined with en block removal.
  • It is the preferred choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases, such as HTV, and hepatitis B.

Option A: Letulle’s method

  • Lettulle's technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed en masse and dissected as organ blocks.
  • It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.

Option B: Ghon’s method

  • Ghon's Technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital system are removed as organ blocks.
  • The neuronal system is removed as another block.

Option D: Virchow method

  • Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one.
  • The cranial cavity is exposed first, followed by the thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs. The spinal cord is removed from the back.
  • In this, the anatomico-pathologic relations are not preserved.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman has had a normal-term pregnancy but has delivered a stillborn. She has a history of drug abuse and is also a chronic alcoholic. During the autopsy, the doctor identified an epiphysis, which is known to appear just before birth. The doctor thus understands that the fetal growth had been normal till full term. Which epiphysis did the doctor identify?
questions.solution:
Option D: Upper end of tibia

  • Gestational age of Upper end of the tibia: 9th month of intra-uterine age (38 weeks).
  • The upper end of the tibia is identified here. In 80 percent of full-term infants, a center is present in the upper end of the tibia, but in other cases, it appears after birth.

Option A: Lower end of femur

  • Gestational age of the Lower end of femur: 9th month of intra-uterine age (36 weeks).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the hospital with abdominal pain, diarrheal episodes, weakness, cough, and anemia. On examination, he was found to be positive for Casoni's test. The clinical diagnosis of a hydatid cyst was made by the physician. Which of the following is the most common site of hydatid cysts in the human body?
questions.solution:
Option B: Right postero-superior lobe of liver

  • It is caused by infection with a small tapeworm parasite called Echinococcosis granuloses.
  • The most common site of hydatid cyst in the human body is the Right postero-superior lobe of the liver.
  • In hydatid disease, 70% of cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver.

Option A: Spleen

  • Hydatid cysts very seldom cause spleen damage.

Option C: Right antero-inferior lobe of liver

  • The hydatid cyst is most commonly located in the right postero-superior lobe of the liver.

Option D: Left lobe of liver

  • More than 70% of the hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the OPD with maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, severe headache, and myalgia. On serological examination, Bartonella quintana was found to be the causative organism. All of the following statements are true about the given condition except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Also called 7-day fever

  • It is also known as a 5-day fever, Shin-bone fever, Wolhynia fever, and Quintana fever.

Other options

Option A: Caused by Bartonella quintana

  • The above-given clinical features point toward the diagnosis of Trench fever. 
  • The causative organism of trench fever is Bartonella quintana.

Option C: Transmitted by Pediculus corporis

  • It is transmitted by pediculus corporis.

Option D: Doxycycline is the treatment

  • The treatment of choice for trench fever is Doxycycline.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male came to the OPD with a chief complaint of jaw discomfort and inability to open his mouth fully for 3 days. He also said he had struck his right shin with a hammer 10 days ago. On examination, he was unable to open his jaw wider than 1 inch. The clinical diagnosis of tetanus was made by the physician. Which of the following statements are true regarding Tetanus?

choices.text: One dose of TT gives Life long immunity

questions.solution:
Option A: No period of communicability

  • Period of communicability: NONE (Not transmitted from person to person).

Other options

Option B: India eliminated tetanus in 2010

  • India declared maternal and neonatal tetanus elimination on July 2016.

Option C: Also known as 2nd-day disease

  • 8th Day Disease: Tetanus neonatorum

Option D: One dose of TT gives Life long immunity

  • One dose of TT does not give lifelong immunity.
  • The primary course of tetanus immunization: 3 doses of DPT at intervals of 4-8 weeks starting at 6 weeks age (to be followed by boosters at 18 months, 5-6 years, 10 years, and 16 years age).

questions.text: A Graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed to reach an end objective is known as network analysis. Which of the following is the ‘Critical path’ in the Network analysis shown below?
questions.solution:
Option A: Red path

  • Longest path in Network analysis (PERT) Critical path.
  • Red path → 3+1+3 weeks → 7 weeks - Longest path.

Option B: Purple path

  • Purple path → 3+2 weeks → 5 weeks.

Option C: Green path

  • Green path → 4+2 weeks → 6 weeks.

Option D: Black path

  • Black path: There is nothing like a Black path in the Image.

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese female presented to the rural PHC. Which of the following is the appropriate statistical test to find out whether obesity is a significant risk factor for breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wilcoxon’s signed rank test

  • The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is a non-parametric statistical hypothesis test used either to test the location of a population based on a sample of data, or to compare the locations of two populations using two matched samples.
  • The one-sample version serves a purpose similar to that of the one-sample Student's t-test. 
  • For two matched samples, it is a paired difference test like the paired Student's t-test (also known as the "t-test for matched pairs" or "t-test for dependent samples"). 

Other options

Option A: Student’s paired ‘t’ test

  • Paired Student’s t-test: Comparing means (+ SD) in paired data (in the same group of individuals before and after an intervention).

Option B: Student’s unpaired ‘t’ test

  • Unpaired Student’s t-test: Comparing means (+ SD) in two different groups of individuals.

Option C: Chi-square test

  • CHI-SQUARE TEST is used to test the significance of the association between 2 or more qualitative characteristics.
  • Obesity and Breast cancer are qualitative variables.
  • This option is incorrect as 2 groups required

questions.text:
The BP of Mr. Ram is 120/ 80 mm Hg. Different (I, II, III, IV) sphygmomanometers are used to measure his BP with 3 readings each. Based on their readings, match the sphygmomanometers with their respective accuracy and precision parameters.


	
		
			I. 120/ 80, 120/ 80, 120/ 80
			A. Precise but Inaccurate
		
		
			II. 140/ 96, 108/62, 96/82
			B. Imprecise but Accurate
		
		
			III. 140/ 96, 140/ 96, 140/ 96
			C. Precise and Accurate
		
		
			IV. 122/ 82, 120/ 80, 118/ 78
			D. Imprecise and Inaccurate

choices.text: A – II, B – IV, C – I, D – III
A – III, B – II, C – IV, D – I
A – IV, B – III, C – II, D – I
A – III, B – IV, C – I, D – II

questions.solution:
Option D: A – III, B – IV, C – I, D – II

  • Precision → Repeatability, Consistency, Reproducibility/Reliability.
  • Accuracy → Close to True/Actual value, known as validity.
I Precise Accurate
II X X
III Precise X
IV X Accurate
  • As listed in the table above, The sphygmomanometer (I) is precise and accurate.
  • The sphygmomanometer (II) is neither precise nor accurate.
  • The sphygmomanometer (III) is precise but not accurate.
  • The sphygmomanometer is accurate but not precise.

questions.text:
While testing the deleterious health hazards on a group of people after giving a drug and a placebo, the following results were obtained:


	
		
			 
			Number of people
			Number of people affected
		
		
			Placebo
			15225
			1605
		
		
			Drug
			15225
			1804
		
	


Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Relative risk reduction (RRR) 11%, Absolute risk reduction (ARR) 11%

questions.solution:
Option B: RRR 11%, ARR 1%

  • Event rate for drug (Ed) = 1804/15225 x 100= 0.118
  • Event rate for placebo (Ep)= 1605/15225 x 100= 0.105
  • ARR = Ed – Ep = 0.013 =1.3%
  • RRR = Ed – Ep/Ed = 0.013/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%

questions.text: A patient after 1 month of getting vaccinated presented to the hospital with excessive bruising and bleeding, purplish spots, and a rash. The diagnosis of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) was made by the physician. ITP is a complication observed with which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
Option A: MMR

  • MMR can lead to ITP causing serum platelet count to go as low as 50,000/microL leading to bruising and/or bleeding.
  • Usually, it is mild & self-limiting.
  • Occasionally may need steroids or platelets.
  • Similar to drug-induced ITP, post-vaccination ITP develops when antibodies against platelet antigens such as GP Ib/IX, GP Ia/IIa, and GP VI cross-react after immunization.
  • The MMR vaccination is thought to induce ITP through a similar mechanism.

Other options

Option B: Rotavirus vaccine

  • The rotavirus vaccine does not lead to ITP.
  • The adverse effect of the rotavirus vaccine is intussusception.

Option C: Hepatitis B vaccine 

  • Adverse effects of the Hep B vaccine include hypersensitivity, and shock.
  • Hepatitis B vaccine in newborns: 3 doses- (6, 10, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at home or (0, 6, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at an institute(Dose: 0.5 ml each).

Option D: Influenza vaccine

  • Killed influenza vaccine causes reactions such as Anaphylaxis, Guillain barre syndrome, and Oculo-respiratory syndrome.
  • It does not cause ITP.

questions.text: The ICD-11 catalogues known human diseases, medical conditions, and mental health disorders and is issued for insurance coding purposes, for statistical tracking of illnesses, and as a global health categorization tool that can be used across countries and in different languages. ICD -11 has 3 volumes plus 26 chapters. What does Volume 2 contain?
questions.solution:
Reference guide

  • Volume II contains a Reference Guide.

Tabulation list

  • Volume I - Tabulation List

Alphabetical index

  • Volume III- Alphabetical Index

Functional assessment

  • Chapter V - Functional Assessment

ICD-11 (International Classification of Diseases - 11th Edition, WHO)

  • Revised every 10 years, right now 11th edition.
  • Released in June 2018 and it contains 3 Volumes & 26 chapters along with chapters X and V.
    • Volume I - Tabulation List
    • Volume II - Reference Guide
    • Volume III- Alphabetical Index
