  • Some important chapters to be remembered:
    • Chapter 6 - Mental behavior and Neurodevelopmental disorders.
    • Chapter 26 - Traditional Medicine
    • Chapter X - Extension codes
    • Chapter V - Functional Assessment

questions.text: Vital statistics are quantitative information about a population's "vital events". Which of the following is included in Vital statistics in a population?
questions.solution:
Option C: Birth Rate

Vital statistics include indicators such as,

  • Birth rate
  • Death rate
  • Natural growth rate
  • Life expectancy at birth
  • Mortality Rate
  • Fertility rate

Option A/ B/ D: Sex ratio/ Population size/ Dependency ratio

  • Sex ratio
  • Population size
  • Dependency ratio

These all are included in Population statistics.

Population statistics Vital statistics

Population size

Sex ratio

Density of population

Dependency ratio

Birth rate, Death rate

Natural growth rate

Life expectancy at birth

Mortality rates

Fertility rates

Learning Objective

  • Demographic indicators have been divided into two parts, Population statistics and vital statistics.
  • Vital statistics includes Birth rate, death rate, natural growth rate, life expectancy at birth, mortality and fertility rate.

questions.text: If ASHA found any child who lies in the yellow area according to the ICDS growth chart. What is the step to be taken?

choices.text: Child is referred to higher center

questions.solution:
Option B: Child is referred to PHC

 

  • Growth monitoring of the children should be done using ICDS growth charts.
  • The green category requires home-based management.
  • The yellow category is mild to moderate malnutrition, Children falling in this category Should be referred to the PHC.
  • The red category is severe malnutrition, Children falling in this category should be immediately referred to a higher center.

Option A: Child is referred to higher center

  • Since this child falls into the yellow category, this child should be referred to the PHC.
  • The red-category child is referred to a higher center.

Option C: Community-based management of malnutrition

  • Community-based management of malnutrition is not appropriate for the child who falls in the yellow category.

Option D: Only follow–up

  • Since the child falls into the yellow category, just following up could lead to progression to the red category.
  • Timely referral to PHC could improve the child's status.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant lady recently delivered a baby at your hospital. The baby was classified as SFD. Which of the following is not included in SFD (Small for date Newborns)?
questions.solution:
Option A: Preterm LBW

  • Small for dates Neonates are defined term, post-term newborn, weight for the gestational age <10 percentile.
  • Therefore, Preterm LBW is not included here.

other options

Option B: Term LBW

  • A term neonate with <10 percentile weight for gestational age, is considered small for date.

Option C: Post-term LBW

  • A post-term neonate with <10 percentile weight for gestational age, is considered small for date.

Option D: IUGR

  • IUGR is the most common cause for small for date.

questions.text: A multipurpose worker is located at the subcenter and is recommended by the Kartar Singh committee. As per IPHS norms, the proposed number of Female health workers at Sub–center type A?
questions.solution:
Option B: 1

  • It is the most peripheral unit of the health system of India and its population.
    • It is of two types
    • Staffing pattern is as follow

Other options are incorrect

Option B - 2 - It is in type B sub centre

Other options incorrect

questions.text: The Child-Pugh score puts patients into three categories of Score A (<7), Score B (7-9), and Score C (10-15). The following is a type of which scale?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ordinal

  • Child-Pugh Score' divides the scores into 3 CATEGORIES, hence it is a CATEGORICAL scale.
  • The variables are qualitative and arranged in an order of increasing severity, hence it is an example of an ORDINAL scale.
  • Examples: TNM staging (cancers), Severity of disease, Social classes.

Option A: Nominal

  • Based on NOM (names); No specific order.
  • Examples: Race, Religion, Country of birth, Clinical features, Sites of lymphadenopathy, Sex of child, Type of anemia, ABO blood group, Site of malignancy.

Option C: Quantitative

  • Quantitative variable: It is a variable that can be measured directly.
  • Measured on an ordinal/metric scale.
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Mid-arm circumference, Blood sugar level, ºC/ ºF temperature scale, Body mass index (BMI), Hemoglobin level, and Serum cholesterol level.

Option D: Continuous

  • Continuous variable: It is a variable that has a large number of possible values & several in-between values.
  • Measured on a metric scale.
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Mid-arm circumference, Blood sugar level, ºC/ ºF temperature scale, Body mass index (BMI), Hemoglobin level, and Serum cholesterol level.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with severe headaches and fatigue. On examination, his BP was 160/95 mmHg. According to the WHO Global Target for Prevention and Control of Non-communicable Diseases by 2025, which of the following is the target percentage to decrease Hypertension?
questions.solution:
Option A: 25%

  • According to the WHO Global Target for Prevention and Control of Non-communicable Disease by 2025, 25% relative reduction in the prevalence of raised blood pressure or contain the prevalence of raised blood pressure.

questions.text: A disaster is a sudden, calamitous event that seriously disrupts the functioning of a community or society and causes human, material, economic or environmental losses. In Disaster management, all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Maximum mortality is reported from hydrological disasters
Most common disease reported after disaster is gastroenteritis

questions.solution:
Option A: Response in the pre-disaster phase

  • The response is a post-disaster phase (not a pre-disaster phase). It is a part of the Recovery phase after a disaster.
  • Disasters Response: Search rescue & first aid, Field care, Triage, Identification of dead.

Option B: Mitigation before a disaster strikes 

  • Mitigation: Measures designed to either prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the effects of emergencies.

Option C: Maximum mortality is reported from hydrological disasters 

  • Maximum mortality is reported from hydrological disasters.
  • Extreme and detrimental changes in the quantity, distribution, or movement of water on land, beneath the surface, or in the atmosphere are known as hydrological disasters. Critical climate events like droughts, tornadoes, mudslides, landslides, or floods might cause them to occur. The 2018 flood in Kerala, which is the worst catastrophe in the century and caused more than 1 million people to be displaced, is a true example of a hydrological disaster.

Option D: Most common disease reported after disaster is gastroenteritis

 

  • The most commonly reported disease in the post-disaster phase is Acute Gastroenteritis.
  • Diseases common in Post-disaster Phase: Gastroenteritis (MC), Acute respiratory tract infections (Pneumonia), Leptospirosis, Rickettsiosis, Rabies, and Equine encephalitis.

.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot presents with fever and loose stools. The patient is stabilized with IV fluids and antibiotics. Which of the following is compatible with the diagnosis of hypercyanotic spells?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inability to hear a murmur

  • In patients suffering from hyper cyanotic spells intensity of the ejection systolic murmur becomes less, murmur will become softer
  • Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks (hypoxic, “blue,” or “tet” spells) are a particular problem during the first 2 years of life.
  • The infant becomes hyperpneic and restless, cyanosis increases, gasping respiration ensues, and syncope may follow.
  • The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initially awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying.
  • Temporary disappearance or a decrease in intensity of the systolic murmur is usual as flow across the right ventricular outflow tract diminishes.

Option A: O2 saturation < 70% in room air

  • The decreased O2 saturation is not included in the hypercyanotic criteria for the TOF

Option C: Hepatomegaly

  • Hepatomegaly is seen in congestive heart failure.
  • Hypercyanotic spells do not cause hepatomegaly.

Option D: S3 gallop rhythm

  • The intensity of murmur is reduced in the Hypercyanotic spells.
  • Moreover, the S3 gallop is seen in volume-overloaded conditions.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of breathlessness, chest pain, and sweating for one hour. She has had a history of diabetes mellitus type 1 since the age of ten. The on-duty intern carries out an ECG, which reveals ST segment depression and T wave inversion in the anterior chest leads. His provisional diagnosis based on ECG and clinical picture is NSTEMI or unstable angina. Which is the best investigation he should order to differentiate between unstable angina and NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cardiac biomarkers

  • The symptoms of acute chest pain, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis in a patient with a history of diabetes are most suggestive of Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS).
  • Acute coronary syndrome is caused by a sudden occlusion of the coronary vessel. The ACS involves three subtypes: STEMI (ST-elevation myocardial infarction), NSTEMI (non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction), and unstable angina.
  • NSTEMI and unstable angina are characterized by the absence of ST segment elevations. However, ST segment depressions or T wave inversions can be present, as in this case.
  • In order to differentiate between NSTEMI and unstable angina, cardiac enzymes can be useful. In NSTEMI, there is infarction (necrosis) that results in the elevation of cardiac enzymes.

  • In unstable angina, there is ischemia without necrosis, so cardiac enzymes are normal. Therefore, in this case, cardiac enzymes should be done to differentiate the NSTEMI and unstable angina.

Option A: Repeat ECG

  • A repeat ECG can be carried out to monitor any evolution of changes in ECG, including the detection of any arrhythmia. However, an ECG does not help differentiate between NSTEMI and unstable angina.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option C: Trans-thoracic Echocardiography

  • Transthoracic echocardiography assesses the structural and functional changes in heart chambers. This does not help make a distinction between NSTEMI and unstable angina.

Option D: Coronary Angiography

  • Coronary angiography helps to visualize the coronary arteries that may be occluded. It is done as a part of primary percutaneous intervention for the treatment of STEMI. However, the differentiation between NSTEMI and unstable angina cannot be done through coronary angiography.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a recent respiratory tract infection complains of severe chest pain at rest. The electrocardiogram of the patient is given. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acute Pericarditis

  • The history points to a recent viral infection that could contribute to the development of pericarditis.
  • The most common cause of pericarditis is idiopathic or viral.
  • ECG findings:
    • Heart rate = 75 bpm
    • Axis = normal
    • PR interval = 0.16 sec
    • QRS = 0.08 sec
    • QT = 400 msec
    • Uniform ST-segment elevation - Concave upwards (RED) in all the leads
    • ST segment depression (BLUE) in aVR seals the diagnosis of pericarditis.

 

 

Option A: Acute MI

  • ECG Findings include:
    • Hyperacute T wave (Indicates severe myocardial ischemia)
    • T wave inversion
    • ST ↑ elevation - convex in upper direction (Indicates myocardial injury)
    • Deep Q waves

 

Option B: Prinzmetal angina

  • Prinzmetal (variant) angina is a clinical syndrome in which chest pain occurs without the usual precipitating factors and is associated with ST-segment elevation rather than depression.
  • It often affects women under 50 years of age.

 

Option C: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

  • It is also called Broken Heart Syndrome
  • It occurs due to catecholamine toxicity and intense emotional trauma in patients with life-threatening stress, such as the death of a loved one.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease and diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency with a complaint of nausea, abdominal pain and lethargy for 2 days. He reports having occasional dark, tarry stools. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated blood glucose and a high anion gap metabolic acidosis on an arterial blood gas sample. Which of the following types of insulin should be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Regular insulin

  • This patient with a history of vomiting, lethargy and abdominal pain with elevated blood glucose, high anion gap metabolic acidosis and positive urine sample for ketones most likely has diabetic ketoacidosis precipitated by his gastrointestinal bleed (history of peptic ulcer disease and black tarry stools).
  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas. It is classified into 2 types:
    • Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus type 1 is an autoimmune disease characterized by T-cell-mediated destruction of the beta cells of the pancreas (due to the presence of glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies). Onset is typical in people aged <30 years. 
    • Non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus type 2 is caused by increased resistance to insulin leading to progressive pancreatic beta-cell failure; it is associated with obesity, and the onset is >40 years.
  • Types of insulin preparations are based on their duration of action. These include:
    • Ultra-short acting insulin
    • Short-acting insulin
    • Intermediate-acting insulin
    • Long-acting insulin

Type of insulin

Onset

Duration

Examples

Ultra-short/rapid-acting
  • 15 minutes
  • 2-4 hours
  • Lispro, aspart, glulisine

Short-acting
  • 30-60 minutes
  • 4-6 hours
  • Regular insulin
  • The only type of insulin that can be given intravenously.

Intermediate-acting
  • 2-4 hours
  • 18-28 hours
  • A peak in 4-10 hours
  • NPH
  • The most commonly used form of insulin.

Long-acting
  • 3-4 hours
  • 24 hours
  • Glargine, detemir.
  • Given at bedtime

Option B: Lispro

  • Lispro is ultrashort-acting insulin. It can not be given intravenously.

Option C: Glargine

  • It is long-acting insulin given subcutaneously at bedtime.

Option D: Aspart

  • Aspart is short-acting insulin given subcutaneously. While managing emergencies such as diabetic ketoacidosis, intravenous insulin should be given.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to OPD with complaints of fatigue and weakness. She has had decreased appetite, weight loss, and severe lightheadedness upon standing. Vital signs show a heart rate of 58 bpm, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.2° C. The examination is remarkable for pigmentation of the oral mucosa, proximal muscle weakness of the lower extremities, and hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases, knuckles and knees. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Adrenal Insufficiency

  • This patient has hyperpigmentation of oral mucosa and other skin areas. Plus, he also has other symptoms of adrenal insufficiency.
  • In primary adrenal insufficiency, the adrenal gland does not produce the hormones secreted by the adrenal cortex in adequate amounts.
  • The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency is an autoimmune disorder worldwide. In developing countries, the most common cause is tuberculosis.
  • This leads to increased levels of ACTH from the pituitary gland.
  • The release of ACTH from the pituitary gland is associated with the release of Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)
  • High MSH causes hyperpigmentation of mucosa and skin.
  • BRADYCARDIA should be present
  • Secondary Adrenal Insufficiency Doesn’t have hyperpigmentation
  • Management of adrenal insufficiency is hydrocortisone
  • To stabilize BP: FLUDROCORTISONE can be added.
  • To stabilize the hypoglycemic condition: DEXAMETHASONE can be used.

Option B: Depression

  • Although, fatigue and weakness are also present in the case of depression. But, decreased blood pressure, hyperpigmentation of skin and other features cannot be explained by it. There is some organic cause that must be ruled out first.

Option C: Anorexia with surreptitious diuretic use

  • A patient with anorexia has symptoms of decreased blood pressure and decreased appetite, weight loss and lightheadedness on standing. But no hyperpigmentation is present in that case. Hyperpigmentation and other symptoms can be explained by Addison’s disease.

Option D: Hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism can also present as decreased blood pressure, fatigue, and weakness. But it also causes weight gain and cold intolerance, and hyperpigmentation is not present.

questions.text:
55-year-old male suffering from Chronic Kidney disease presents to the emergency department with bilateral leg oedema and chest pain with mild shortness of breath. A blood sample is drawn for ABGs analysis which shows the following results. Which of the following acid-base disorder is present in this patient?
pH= 7.2
pCO2 =40 mm Hg
HCO3= 15 mEq/L
Na= 145mEq/L 

Chloride= 100 mEq/L

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
Option B: High anion gap metabolic acidosis

  • This patient has low pH, which shows metabolic acidosis.
  • As carbon dioxide is normal, while bicarbonates are low, therefore, the cause of acidosis is low bicarbonate ions.
  • This means this is metabolic acidosis.
  • Moreover, the Anion gap is more than 12 ( Na-(Chloride – Bicarbonate ions)
  • Therefore, the accurate diagnosis is high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Option A: Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

  • Although low bicarbonate ions are causing metabolic acidosis in this patient, the anion gap is not normal.

Option C: No acid-base abnormality

  • A disturbance in pH shows that there is a definite acid-base disorder.

Option D: High anion gap metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis will be present if bicarbonates are high.
  • However, in this case, bicarbonates are decreasing.

questions.text: A 30 years male presents to the outpatient department with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting for the past 3 hours. He says that pain is radiating to the back. USG shows multiple renal stones. Blood investigations reveal increased serum cysteine levels. Urinalysis shows hexagonal-shaped crystals. Which of the following is not indicated in the prevention of these stones?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cysteamine

The clinical diagnosis of the profile given in the question is CYSTINURIA.

Cystinuria:

  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Defect in re-absorptive transport of cystine and the di-basic amino acids ornithine, arginine and lysine from the luminal fluid of the proximal renal tubule and small intestine.
  • Urinalysis: hexagonal-shaped crystals
  • The foundation of cystine stone prevention is adequate hydration and urinary alkalinization.
  • When the conservative therapy fails, the addition of drugs such as D-penicillamine and captopril.

NOTE

  • The clinical profile should not be confused with Cystinosis, treated with Cysteamine.

Option B: Increase fluid intake

  • Increased fluid intake increases urine formation.
  • This decreases the concentration of solutes and thus prevents its precipitation.

Option C: Alkalinization of urine

  • Alkalinization of urine promotes the dissolution of the cysteine, making it less likely to precipitate and cause stone formation.

Option D: Penicillamine

  • Penicillamine is a first-generation chelating agent that combines with cysteine to form a soluble disulfide complex (50 times more soluble than cystine), thus preventing the stone formation and possibly even dissolving existing cystine stones.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of headache, swelling on both ankles and puffiness of the face, and generalised weakness. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and his pulse is 80 beats/min. In addition to generalised oedema, cervical lymphadenopathy is also noted on examination. He is a truck driver by occupation. His investigations reveal hypercholesterolemia, raised serum creatinine, hypoalbuminemia and a CD4 count of 150. Rapid HIV test is positive. HBV and HCV are negative by a rapid test kit. Urine analysis reveals nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis

  • The patient in the given scenario has a positive rapid HIV test and CD4 count of 150, suggesting that the patient has an HIV infection.
  • Isolated nephrotic range proteinuria secondary to HIV infection indicates HIV nephropathy.
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults associated with an HIV infection.
  • The patient usually presents with signs of nephrotic syndrome along with kidney injury, which is signified by raised creatinine and high blood pressure in this patient.

Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • It is usually idiopathic but may be associated with malignancies (Hodgkin’s lymphoma), not HIV.
  • It usually presents with selective proteinuria and normal kidney function tests initially.
  • The patient’s age, HIV infection and raised creatinine make this diagnosis less likely.

Option C: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous Nephropathy can be associated with infections, autoimmune conditions and solid organ malignancies.
  • The infections this condition is associated with are hepatitis B and C, not HIV.
  • This patient has a positive rapid test for HIV, but they are negative for HBV and HCV, making this diagnosis less likely.​​​​​​​

Option D: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis

  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is usually a nephritic syndrome but can present with nephrotic range proteinuria in advanced disease.
  • It is associated with either an autoimmune condition such as SLE or an infection such as HBV or HCV.
  • This patient has HIV nephropathy, which is associated with FSGS, making MPGN a less likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male who is a suspected case of leprosy with Type 1 reaction has come to the clinic. On examination, the patient was afebrile. Peripheral nerves, including the greater auricular, radial cutaneous, ulnar and common peroneal nerves, were all thickened with the tenderness of the radial cutaneous and ulnar nerves bilaterally. Examination of the skin revealed multiple asymmetric and well-demarcated raised, erythematous plaques across the chest, abdomen, arms, back, legs and face with reduced sensation to pinprick in all lesions. What will be the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Systemic steroids

The given clinical case is a case of Type 1 lepra reaction with severe neuritis.

Therapy for Reactions

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are best treated with glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone, initially at 40-60 mg/d). As the inflammation subsides, the glucocorticoid dose can be tapered, but steroid therapy must be continued for at least 6 months.

Raised erythematous plaques of multi-bacillary leprosy in Type 1 reaction.

Option B: Clofazimine

  • Clofazimine is used to treat leprosy paired with dapsone and rifampicin. It is only used for erythema nodosum leprosum (Type 2 lepra) and multibacillary (MB) leprosy.
  • It is considered an orphan drug and is unavailable in pharmacies.

Option C:  Paracetamol

  • Type 2 Lepra reaction: If erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is mild (i.e., without fever or other organ involvement), it may be treated with antipyretics alone. In cases with many skin lesions, fever, malaise, and other tissue involvement, brief glucocorticoid courses (1-2 weeks) are effective.

Option D:  Thalidomide

  • If despite two courses of glucocorticoid therapy, Type 2 lepra (ENL) appears to be recurring and persisting, treatment with thalidomide should be initiated

questions.text: A 45-year-old COPD patient presents to the hospital with a complaint of pedal oedema. He is prescribed thiazide diuretics. He presents 2 weeks later, complaining of excessive sleepiness. His ABGs show pH= 7.42, pCO2= 67 mmHg and HCO3 = 42mEq. Serum electrolytes are Na =140 mEq, K = 3.0 mEq, CL-=88 mEq. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with paradoxical aciduria

questions.solution:
Option A: Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory acidosis

  • This patient’s ABGs show normal pH, increased pCO2= 67 mmHg (normal=40 mmHg) and increased HCO3=42mEq (normal=24mEq).
  • Thiazide diuretics increase Na+ excretion from the body.
  • This results in dehydration and decreased edema.
  • Decreased Na+ leads to an increased aldosterone level which causes hypokalemic alkalosis.
  • So, this patient has metabolic alkalosis secondary to thiazide diuretics.
  • The patient is a known case of COPD, which results in increased CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis.
  • So, the patient has both metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis. Both counteract each other resulting in a normal pH.

Option B: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

  • The patient has an increased pCO2= 67 mmHg (normal=40 mmHg).
  • He has respiratory acidosis, not respiratory alkalosis.

Option C: Metabolic alkalosis with metabolic acidosis

  • The patient has an increased pCO2= 67 mmHg (normal=40 mmHg) and increased HCO3=42mEq (normal=24mEq).
  • He has metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis.

Option D: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with paradoxical aciduria

  • Anion gap in this patient= Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-) = 140- (88+42) =10 mEq/L
  • Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-) = 140- (88+42) =10 mEq/LThis patient has a normal anion gap.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), hyperlipidemia, hypertension, diabetes, and 10 days of progressively increasing dyspnea with exertion presented. Thoracocentesis was performed after a chest scan revealed a significant left pleural effusion. Which of the following is not part of the criteria used to distinguish between exudate and transudate?

choices.text: Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)/serum LDH ratio > 0.6
Pleural fluid LDH level > two-thirds the upper limit of the laboratory’s reference range of serum LDH
Pleural fluid sugar < 2/3rd of blood sugar

questions.solution:
Option D: Effusion sugar is less than 2/3rd of blood sugar

  • It is possible to distinguish between exudate and transudate using Light's criterion.
  • Light's standards: Transudative pleural effusions do not match any of the following characteristics, but exudative pleural effusions must meet at least one of the following:
  • A serum or pleural fluid protein level >0.5
  • LDH of pleural fluid to serum >0.63
  • Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds the normal serum upper limit.
  • With these parameters, around 25% of transudates are mistaken for exudates.
  • The difference between the protein levels in the blood and the pleural fluid should be assessed if one or more of the exudative criteria are satisfied and the patient is clinically suspected of having a disease causing a transudative effusion.
  • The exudative classification by these parameters might be disregarded if this gradient is >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL) since nearly all of these individuals have

Option A: Effusion protein/serum protein ratio greater than 0.5

  • A pleural effusion fluid /serum protein greater than 0.5 is a Light criterion for exudative effusion.
  • Most exudative effusions are caused by pulmonary embolism, malignancy, TB, and pneumonia. Exudative effusions can be differentially diagnosed using a variety of pleural fluid assays.

Option B: Effusion lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)/serum LDH ratio greater than 0.6

  • Effusion lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)/serum LDH ratio greater than 0.6 is a Light criterion for exudative effusion.
  • An enzyme called lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is often found inside body cells.
  • Cellular damage causes LDH to flow out and mix with the effusion.

Option C: Effusion LDH level greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of the laboratory's reference range of serum LDH

  • Effusion LDH level greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of the laboratory's reference range of serum LDH is a Light criterion for exudative effusion.
  • LDH leaks from damaged cells and combines with the effusion. A high LDH value in the effusion is a sign of damaged cells, which usually result from an exudative process.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented to you with complaints of nausea, vomiting, yellowish discolouration of skin, and sclera. He also had complaints of low-grade fever associated with right upper quadrant pain for the past 1 week. Initial investigations were done. He is found to have HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive. Which of the following test is useful to estimate the severity of acute hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Prothrombin time

Marked prolongation of prothrombin time.

  • When the PT is high, it takes longer for the blood to clot (17 seconds, for example).
  • This usually happens because the liver is not making the right amount of blood clotting proteins, so the clotting process takes longer.
  • A high PT usually means that there is serious liver damage or cirrhosis.
  • A high PT may indicate there is a higher risk for internal bleeding from the upper part of the GI tract (oesophagus, stomach).

Option A:  Serum bilirubin

  • Total bilirubin levels may be elevated in infectious hepatitis. Bilirubin levels higher than 30 mg/dL indicate more severe disease.

Option C: α-glutaryl transferase

  • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is an enzyme found in the cell membranes of many tissues, mainly in the liver, kidney, and pancreas.
  • It is also found in other tissues, including the intestine, spleen, heart, brain, and seminal vesicles.
  • The highest concentration is in the kidney, but the liver is considered the source of normal enzyme activity.

The reference ranges for GGT are as follows:

  • Male and female aged 45 years and older: 8-38 units/L or 8-38 international units (IU)/L (SI units)
  • Female younger than age 45 years: 5-27 units/L or 5-27 IU/L (SI units)
  • Elderly: Slightly higher than adult level
  • Child: Similar to adult level
  • Newborn: Five times higher than adult level

Option D: Alkaline phosphatase

  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels are usually in the reference range but may elevate to no higher than twice the normal level. If ALP is elevated significantly, consider liver abscess or biliary obstruction.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents in the hospital with complaints of painful joints in the hands. She also complained of morning stiffness associated with a decrease in the intensity of the pain after physical activity. On examination, a decrease in the range of movement and a weakening in hand grip and strength along with trigger fingers were noticed. Which of the following would be the earliest radiological change in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option C: Periarticular osteopenia

  • Painful small joints of hands with morning stiffness and trigger finger are classic features suggestive of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
  • Periarticular osteopenia is one of the earliest manifestations of RA, which can be observed on an x-ray.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis's clinical features include
  • Early morning joint stiffness that lasts more than 01 hours and eases with physical activity.
  • The earliest involved joints are the small joints of the hands and feet.
  • Wrist, metacarpophalangeal,(MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are primarily involved in RA.
  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint may or may not be involved due to co-existing osteoarthritis.
  • Joint involvement will always be in a symmetrical pattern.
  • The introduction of disease-modifying therapies has revolutionized the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
  • Radiological features of RA
    • Evidence of soft tissue swelling and joint effusion
    • Symmetrical involvement
    • Juxta-articular osteopenia (within weeks)
    • Loss of articular cartilage and bone erosions (after months)
    • Narrowing of joint space
    • Articular destruction and joint deformity, e.g. subluxation of atlantoaxial and cervical joints
    • Lack of hypertrophic bone changes (sclerosis or osteophyte)

Option A: Decreased joint space

  • The decrease in bone mass is called osteopenia, which can lead to loss of joint space, juxta-articular osteoporosis, and soft-tissue swelling, which are early manifestations of RA but not the earliest manifestations of the disease in radiographs.

Option B: Articular erosion

  • Periarticular erosions result from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation, which is seen during the late stage of RA and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Option D: Subchondral cyst

  • Subchondral cysts are fluid-filled sac that forms in the bone beneath the cartilage of a joint such as the hip, knee, or shoulder.
  • These are most commonly seen in patients with osteoarthritis but can be formed in the late stages of RA.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy, adequately vaccinated according to his age, was brought to emergency with a 3-day history of fever, rash, irritability, and poor feeding. After a few days, the baby developed non-purulent conjunctivitis and foot edema. Her mother also complained of his tongue turning into a deep red tongue and appearing swollen. A differential diagnosis of Kawasaki disease was made. What is the cardinal feature of Kawasaki disease apparent on blood reports?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thrombocytosis

Diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease 

The diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires the presence of fever lasting at least five days without any other explanation combined with at least four of the five following criteria: 

  • bilateral bulbar conjunctiva injection 

  • oral mucous membrane changes, including infected fissured lips, infected pharynx, or strawberry tongue 

  • peripheral extremity changes, including erythema of plasma or soles, edema of hands or feet (acute phase), and periungual desquamation (convalescent phase)

  • polymorphous rash 

  • cervical lymphadenopathy (at least one lymph node >1.5 cm in diameter)

  • Kawasaki disease is acute inflammatory vasculitis of the middle and small arteries.
  • It is associated with coronary artery weakening and aneurysms in about 15-25% of untreated cases.
  •  Thrombocytosis is a characteristic finding in Kawasaki disease that occurs in 2nd to 3rd week of illness.
  • It has been reported that platelets are not only activated but also hyperactive, which increases the chance of thrombosis in already weakened vessels. 
  • Giant cell arteritis is inflammation of specific arteries near the temples.
  • The most common symptoms of giant cell arteritis are:
    • Severe head pain and tenderness, which usually affects both temples.
    • Head pain can worsen over time, come and go, or subside briefly.

Treatment:

  • Platelet-lowering medications, primarily hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea) or interferon alfa (Intron A).
  •  Platelets can be removed from your blood via a dialysis-like procedure.

Other options

Option B: Thrombocytopenia

  • Thrombocytopenia is a temporary uncommon feature of Kawasaki disease.
  • It is usually seen in the acute phases of the disease.
  • It is usually apparent on blood reports and doesn't appear clinically. 
  • Thrombocytopenia is a condition in which the platelet count in your blood is abnormally low.
  • Platelets are tiny blood cells that develop from larger cells in the bone marrow
  • Platelets stick together to form a plug to seal your wound when you are injured.
  • This plug is known as a blood clot.

Option C: Increased hemoglobin

  • A high hemoglobin count occurs most commonly when your body requires more oxygen-carrying capacity, usually due to smoking.
  • Because you live at a high elevation, your red blood cell production naturally increases to compensate for the lower oxygen supply.
  • There is no effect on hemoglobin in the case of Kawasaki disease.

Option D: Decreased hematocrit

  • Hematocrit lower than normal can indicate: an insufficient supply of healthy red blood cells (anemia)
  • Many white blood cells result from chronic illness, infection, or a white blood cell disorder such as leukemia or lymphoma.
  • Deficiencies in vitamins or minerals Blood loss, recent or long-term
  • There is no effect on hematocrit in the case of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department by her home health aide secondary to her behaving in a disorganized manner, including yelling, cursing, and throwing belongings out of the window. Moreover, she has a 20-year-old history of focal impaired awareness with cognitive changes and behavioural arrest, progressing to poorly controlled bilateral tonic-clonic seizures. Subsequently, her Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) displays asymmetry of the hippocampus, with a prominent right temporal horn of the lateral ventricle. Based on the history and findings, what is the most probable diagnosis in her case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy

Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy Syndrome (MTLE)

  • It is associated with focal seizures with impairment of consciousness.
  • MRI can detect the characteristic hippocampal sclerosis that appears to be essential in the pathophysiology of MTLE for many patients.
  • It tends to be refractory to treatment with anticonvulsants but responds well to surgical intervention.
  • EEG shows Temporal (Unilateral or Bilateral) spikes.
  • MRI Brain (coronal views below) showing asymmetry of the lateral ventricles, with a prominent right temporal horn of the lateral ventricle, indicative of decreased volume in the right hippocampal region

Other options

Option A: Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome

  • It occurs in children.
  • It has multiple seizure types
  • EEG shows slow (< 3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges.
  • There is impaired cognitive function in most but not all cases.

Option C: Benign Rolandic Epilepsy

  • It is the most common type of epilepsy in children
  • This common focal motor epilepsy is unique among the focal epilepsies of childhood in that it is self-limiting despite a very abnormal EEG pattern.
  • It is usually transmitted in families as an autosomal dominant trait and begins between 5 and 9 years of age.
  • It typically announces itself by a nocturnal tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset. Thereafter, the seizures take the form of clonic contractions of one side of the face, less often of one arm or leg, and the interictal EEG shows high-voltage spikes in the contralateral lower rolandic or centrotemporal area.
  • Seizures are readily controlled by a single anticonvulsant drug and gradually disappear during adolescence.

Option D: Epilepsia Partialis Continua

  • If a focal seizure continues for hours or days, it is known as Epilepsia Partialis Continua.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents in the emergency department following a fall from a height. The patient complains of severe headache, vomiting, and blurred vision. Glasgow coma scale score is 13/15, blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and heart rate is 110 beats/min. A raised intracranial pressure is suspected. Which of the following treatment options is the most effective way of reducing ICP?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ventriculostomy

  • The patient has signs and symptoms of raised Intracranial pressure (ICP) following a fall from a height.
  • The most effective way of reducing ICP is Ventriculostomy
  • It is a fully automated process in which an ICP monitor catheter is placed in the left horn of the ventricle, and when the sensor detects ICP of more than 25 mmHg, a one-way valve opens, and CSF flows into a sterile container.

Option A: Osmotherapy

  • IV mannitol, IV saline 3%, and IV Acetazolamide can be used in the first-line treatment of raised intracranial pressure.
  • However, they are not the most effective way of reducing ICP.

Option B: Vasopressors

  • Nor-epinephrine, phenylephrine, and dopamine are used as vasopressors therapy.
  • They ensure cerebral perfusion pressure of >60 mmHg
  • However, norepinephrine does not affect raised intracranial pressure, and dopamine is shown to increase the ICP because of dopamine-induced vasodilatation.

Option D: Elective ventilation

  • Hyperventilation is very effective in reducing raised intracranial pressure.
  • CO2 is a potent vasodilator. Therefore, hypocapnia is appreciated paCO2 = 30-35mmg to decrease raised ICP.
  • However, it is the least effective method of reducing raised ICP.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female comes to the neurology clinic with dysphagia. There is also loss of taste on the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. There is no history of muscle weakness, dyspnea or diplopia. The woman is diabetic and hypertensive. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and her pulse is 70 beats/min. On physical examination, when the right side of the pharynx is touched with a tongue blade, the palate elevates symmetrically. When the left side of the pharynx is touched, the palate does not elevate at all. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: 9th cranial nerve

  • This patient with dysphagia, loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd and loss of gag reflex is affected by the 9th cranial nerve palsy known as glossopharyngeal palsy.
  • The gag reflex is a throat contraction that happens when something touches the roof of the mouth, tongue and around the tonsils.
  • It helps to prevent choking and swallowing unnecessary substances.
  • 9th nerve forms the Afferent [A] pathway - Receives stimulus
  • 10th nerve forms the Efferent [E] pathway - Elevates pharynx
  • In this patient, Afferent, i.e. 9th, is affected on the left side
Right Side Left Side
A:⊕ 9th A:×
E:⊕ 10th E:⊕ 10th

Option A: 4th cranial nerve

  • The trochlear nerve (CN IV) supplies to the superior oblique of an eye.
  • It is involved in the abduction, internal rotation and depression while adducted.
  • Its lesion causes upward deviation of the eye and vertical diplopia.

Option B: 6th cranial nerve

  • Abducent nerve (CN VI) supplies to the lateral rectus of the eye.
  • It is involved in abduction.
  • 6th nerve palsy causes medially deviated eye and horizontal diplopia.

Option D: 10th cranial nerve

  • Vagus nerve lesion will cause the following manifestations:
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Immobile vocal cords on the affected side (dysphagia and dysphonia)
  • Gastroparesis
  • Loss of saliva production

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented to your clinic with features of typical Parkinsonism. He is noted to have short shuffling steps, stooped posture, and absent automatic arm swing. He is having a good response to levodopa. Which of the following would have been the earliest symptom of Parkinsonism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Resting tremors

  • Parkinson's disease is caused by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the brain. The basal ganglia and substantia nigra are balanced systems comprising dopaminergic and cholinergic neurons. In Parkinson's disease, the dopaminergic neurons are compromised, and the cholinergic system is unopposed. Lewy bodies (composed of alpha-synuclein) are intracellular eosinophilic inclusions seen in dopaminergic neurons of basal ganglia.
  • The onset of Parkinson's disease is after 50 years of age.
  • Parkinsonism refers to the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease. It can be caused by many reasons, including a side effect of medications (e.g. antipsychotic drugs, methyl-phenyl tetrahydropyridine (MPTP)).
  • Features of Parkinsonism include:
    • A resting tremor is the earliest sign of Parkinsonism. It presents as a slight tremor of the hand, foot, jaw or face on one side of the body. The tremor consists of a shaking or oscillating movement and usually appears when a person is at rest. The tremor can be exacerbated by stress or excitement, sometimes attracting unwanted attention. The tremor usually spreads to the other side as the disease progresses but remains more prominent on the initially affected side. The tremor goes away when performing routine tasks.
    • Bradykinesia is the slowing of voluntary movements.
    • Rigidity appears as cogwheel rigidity in the upper limbs and lead-pipe rigidity in the lower limbs. Rigidity is ratchet-like jerking when testing the tone in one limb when the patient clenches the opposite fist.
    • Poor postural reflexes, difficulty initiating the first step, stooped posture and walking with small shuffling steps.
    • Expressionless face.
    • Micrographia (small handwriting).
    • Dysarthria and dysphagia.
    • Autonomic disturbances.
  • Treatment of Parkinson's disease involves carbidopa-levodopa (the drug of choice). Dopamine receptor agonists such as bromocriptine and pramipexole can be used. Monoamine-oxidase B inhibitors (selegiline) and catechol-o-methyltransferase inhibitors (Entacapone, tolcapone) are often used.

Option B: Rigidity

  • Rigidity is a feature of Parkinsonism, but it is a late feature which presents after resting tremors.
  • It presents as cogwheel rigidity.

Option C: Bradykinesia

  • Bradykinesia is slow movements. It is a late feature of Parkinsonism.

Option D: Chorea

  • Chorea refers to abnormal, uncoordinated random involuntary movements. It is a feature of the overtreatment of Parkinson's disease (dopaminergic excess).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to OPD complaining of worsening malaise, body weakness, abdominal pain, and dark urine for 1 day. He has had a past medical history of a carbuncle on his buttock, for which he received cotrimoxazole 3 days before. On physical examination, he is icteric with normal vital signs. Investigations reveal that haemoglobin has fallen from 14.4 g/dL to 9.1 g/dL, and his bilirubin has risen from normal to 3.5 mg/dL, urine dipstick is positive for bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What may be the most common cause of death regarding this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute renal failure

The presenting complaints and lab findings of this patient suggest G6PD deficiency. Acute renal failure is the most common cause of death in G6PD deficiency.

G6PD deficiency:

  • It is an x-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of the G6PD enzyme.
  • G6PD neutralises free radical-induced damage inside RBC.
  • Its deficiency leads to unopposed oxidative stress and intravascular hemolysis, which leads to acute renal failure.
  • Acute renal failure is the most common cause of death in G6PD deficiency.
  • PBF shows bite cells, anisocytosis, and spherocytes, diagnosing glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • Bite cells are formed due to the splenic removal of abnormal haemoglobin aggregates. (Heinz bodies)

Pathophysiology of acute renal failure in G6PD deficiency:

Hemolytic episode

↓

Hemoglobinemia

↓

Hemoglobinuria (Black urine)

↓

Blockage of tubules of the kidney

↓

Acute tubular necrosis

↓

Renal failure

Option A: Low oxyhemoglobin values

  • Low oxyhemoglobin level is found in aplastic anaemia.
  • It is not a cause of death in G6PD deficiency.

Option C: Sequestration crisis

  • Sequestration crisis is characteristic of sickle cell anaemia.

Option D: Low oxygen affinity

  • Low oxygen affinity is not a common cause of death in G6PD deficiency.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic alcoholic man complains of a burning sensation in the mouth. On examination, he has thickened, dry, smooth tongue without the filiform papillae. Mean corpuscular volume(MCV) is 100 fl. Which of the following should be the first line of approach in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Estimation of Vitamin B12 levels

  • The above-given scenario is likely a case of Vitamin B12 deficiency; hence estimation of Vitamin B12 levels should be the first step. Its deficiency may cause bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration (demyelination) of the spinal cord's cervical and thoracic posterior and lateral (pyramidal) tracts.

 

                                                                    

 

Glossitis

Option B: Brush biopsy

  • It consists of the oral brush biopsy instrument used to rapidly obtain a transepithelial specimen.
  • The sample is spread onto an enclosed glass slide and fixed; the computer system detects potentially abnormal cells by searching for a combination of abnormal cellular morphology unique to the oral epithelium.
  • Brush biopsies are utilized routinely in the detection of precancerous and cancerous lesions.
  • This patient has more likely glossitis due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option C: Start Antifungal therapy

  • The MCV of 100fL and burning sensation suggest glossitis due to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Antifungal therapy is the treatment of oral thrush, which is a white plaque on the tongue that can be scrapped off.

Option D: Incisional biopsy

  • An incisional biopsy is performed on patients with abnormal growth, such as lumps, tumours, and lesions.
  • This patient has more likely glossitis due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male, a known case of type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past 20 years with poor glycaemic control, presents to the local clinic with complaints of passing foamy urine. He has a 25-pack-a-year smoking history and drinks half a bottle of alcohol daily. Vital signs show pulse 88 beats/minute, blood pressure 160/90mmHg and respiratory rate 12 breaths/minute. After further workup, a diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy is confirmed. Which of the following would be the earliest finding that can confirm the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Urine albumin >30 mg/dL.

  • Microvascular complications of diabetes are diabetic nephropathy, retinopathy and neuropathy. The risk of developing these complications can be reduced by achieving tight glycaemic control.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is the most important cause of end-stage renal disease.
  • It has the following types:
    • Diffuse glomerulosclerosis in which hyaline deposition is in all areas of glomeruli. It is also seen in hypertensive patients,
    • Isolated glomerular basement membrane thickening.
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome), in which hyaline deposition is in one area of a glomerulus. It is pathognomonic for diabetes.
  • Elevated blood glucose levels increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of the kidneys. High GFR can damage the renal glomeruli leading to filtration of proteins (albumin) into the Bowman's capsule.
  • Microalbuminuria is urinary albumin of about 30-300mg/day and urine albumin to creatinine ratio of 0.02-0.2. If microalbuminuria is present, then strict glycemic control is important to limit progression from microalbuminuria to clinical proteinuria.
  • Without proper treatment, microalbuminuria can worsen, and hypertension usually develops. Persistent hypertension and proteinuria cause a decrease in glomerular filtration rate leading to renal insufficiency and end-stage renal disease.
  • If a patient has hypertension, the risk of progression to diabetic nephropathy increases, so adequate blood pressure control is necessary.
  • Screening for diabetic neuropathy can be done by quantifying 24-hour urine albumin excretion. If urine is positive for microalbuminuria, angiotensin convertase enzyme (ACE) inhibitors should be initiated in the patient; it will slow the progression to overt proteinuria and decline in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Microalbuminuria is a reliable indicator of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Urine dipstick becomes positive when the amount of proteins excreted is >300mg/day. So microalbuminuria should be screened in diabetic patients instead of urine dipstick tests.
  • It takes 1-5 years for microalbuminuria to advance into proteinuria. Using ACE inhibitors and controlling blood pressure, this progression can be slowed down.
  • Once diabetic nephropathy has progressed to proteinuria or renal failure, glycaemic control does not significantly influence further course. ACE inhibitors and dietary protein restriction are recommended.

Option A: Shrunken kidney is a hallmark.

  • The shrunken kidney is a hallmark of renal artery stenosis, not diabetic nephropathy.

Option B: Fibrin caps

  • The fibrinous cap is a layer of connective tissue formed in atherosclerotic plaque. It is not formed in diabetic nephropathy.

Option C: Elevated creatinine clearance.

  • Diabetic nephropathy is initially marked by microalbuminuria. In late stages, creatinine clearance can be reduced, not elevated.

questions.text: Tony Stark is a 45-year-old male who was referred by his primary care physician after presenting to the ER with difficulty in breathing. Tony's physician was unable to find a medical explanation for his symptoms, which left Tony feeling confused, stressed, and angry. Over the last 6 months, Tony has had several instances where he felt an intense fear that would reach a peak within a few minutes. During these instances, he would also experience sweating, heart palpitations, chest pain and discomfort, and shortness of breath. Tony began to rely on his wife for even small things as to drive their children to their various activities. She was understanding but she is worried about her husband. His Doctor Jarvis diagnosed Tony to have panic attacks. Which of the following symptoms she can be least worried about her husband?
questions.solution:
Panic attack

  • An acute attack of intense anxiety
  • Feeling of impending doom
  • Fear of having a heart attack, dying, or going mad
  • Suicidal thoughts are not a common symptom of panic attack.
  • Palpitations, increased heart rate
  • Shortness of breath
  • Choking sensations
  • Sweating
  • Trembling
  • Chest pain
  • Dizziness
  • Chills or hot splashes
  • Numbness or tingling sensations
  • Depersonalisation
  • Derealisation

questions.text: Despite 5 years of psychiatric treatment, a 25-year-old female university graduate patient presents to an outpatient clinic with symptoms that have not resolved. She cries during the psychiatric interview, complaining of not being able to explain herself and being unable to socialize with others. During her mental evaluation, she said something interesting: "There were occasions when I laughed for no reason, but I suppose that wasn't very healthy." Which of the following is the benefit of ECT in the case of Manic-Depressive Psychosis?
questions.solution:
• ECT shortens the duration of depressive episode.
  • It does not prevent the recurrence unless given as a maintenance treatment.

HOW TO REMEMBER: In bipolar d/o treatment is to decrease the duration of illness and decrease the frequency of the episodes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient had the peculiar symptom of feeling as if he were living in the time of ancient monarchs many years ago, and sometimes even several centuries ago. He claimed that he felt transported to a location several centuries ago, during the reign of Raja Raja Cholan. He had the impression that he was the king, and that he could see everything around him, even ancient structures, but he was unable to respond to the situation. He noticed the present after a few minutes. This is an example of an Oneiroid state, which is defined as follows:
questions.solution:
• Oneiroid state – Dream-like state in which the patient is very confused and unaware of time and place
  • Twilight state - Disturbed consciousness with hallucination
  • Stupor – Decrease response to stimuli


HOW TO REMEMBER: oneiroid= orientation ( awareness about time, place and person ) lost

questions.text: Diana is a 25-year-old woman who presents with a history of non-suicidal self-injury, specifically cutting her arms and legs, since she was a teenager. She has made two suicide attempts by overdosing on prescribed medications, one as a teenager and one six months ago; she also reports chronic suicidal ideation, explaining that it gives her relief to think about suicide as a “way out.”. She describes a longstanding pattern of changing her hobbies, style of clothing. At times, she thinks that her partner is “the best thing that’s ever happened to me” and will impulsively buy him lavish gifts however, at other times she admits to thinking “I can’t stand him ” .Which of the following therapies is effective for her?
questions.solution: Dialectical behavior therapy is effective for impulsive behaviors in borderline personality disorder, including self injurious behaviors and so-called parasuicidal gestures.

questions.text: A 44-year-old premenopausal woman recently diagnosed with breast cancer presents with a lump in her breast and further investigation established a diagnosis of HER-2 negative, ER-negative, and PR-negative invasive early breast cancer. Partial mastectomy was done to remove the tumor and advised to receive 6 cycles of chemotherapy. Which of the following is the best chemotherapy regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, 5-fluorouracil

  • For breast carcinoma, the best chemotherapy regimen is cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, and 5-fluorouracil.
  • For HER-2 positive breast cancer, adding trastuzumab to polychemotherapy is approved.
New Drugs in CA Breast
Ixabepilone
  • Used for anthracycline and taxane resistant breast cancer
Lapatinib
  • Inhibitor of Her-2-neu and EGFR tyrosine kinase
  • Second-line Her-2-neu therapy
Sunitinib
  • Approved for advanced renal cancer and refractory metastatic breast cancer

Option B: Methotrexate, cisplatin

  • This combination has very low efficacy.
  • This is not a recommended therapy for breast carcinoma.

Options C: Cisplatin, adriamycin, steroid 

  • Steroid-based chemotherapies are only helpful if the tumor is estrogen or progesterone-receptor-positive.
  • Tumor in the above clinical scenario is negative for both estrogen and progesterone receptor.

Options D: Methotrexate, adriamycin, steroid

  • Only tumors with estrogen or progesterone receptors will benefit from steroid-based chemotherapy 
  • In the clinical condition mentioned above, the tumor tests negative for both estrogen and progesterone receptor.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD complaining of swelling on the right side of the neck for the last 6 months. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 130/70 mmHg, a pulse rate of 86 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. His neck examination reveals a solid mass on the right side of his neck.  A thyroid scan reveals the following finding, shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypersecreting adenoma

  • In the case mentioned above, the patient has a swelling in the right region of the neck with no associated symptoms, and the thyroid scan suggests hypersecreting adenoma.
  • The given thyroid scan shows increased focal uptake in the right upper lobe of the thyroid and decreased uptake in the rest of the thyroid gland; this is suggestive of hypersecreting thyroid adenoma.
  • There is no ectopic thyroid tissue, so lateral aberrant thyroid and lateral extension are ruled out.
  • Malignancy is ruled out as there is no cold nodule.

  • Hyperfunctioning adenomas become independent of stimulating thyroid hormone (TSH) control and secrete thyroid hormone autonomously, resulting in clinical hyperthyroidism.
  • The elevated thyroid hormone levels ultimately diminish TSH levels and thus depress the function of the remaining normal thyroid gland.
  • The sole focus of increased uptake on a thyroid scan is the diagnosis of a hyperfunctioning adenoma.
  • Most hyperfunctioning or autonomous thyroid nodules have attained a size of at least 3 cm before hyperthyroidism occurs. These nodules are rarely malignant.

Option A: Papillary carcinoma thyroid

  • Papillary carcinoma thyroid manifests as either a palpable thyroid nodule or an incidental imaging finding.
  • Carcinomas usually display diminished uptake and are called "cold" nodules, whereas a sole focus of increased uptake on a thyroid scan is virtually diagnostic of a hyperfunctioning adenoma.

Option B: Lateral aberrant thyroid

  • Lateral aberrant thyroid is a misnomer.
  • It is the metastatic node from papillary carcinoma thyroid and usually shows diminished uptake (cold nodule).

Option D: Graves’ disease

  • Graves’ disease presents a swelling of the neck and protrusion of the eyes resulting from an overactive thyroid gland.
  • Graves’ disease on radioisotope scan shows elevated uptake with a diffusely enlarged gland without nodularity.

questions.text: A 71-year-old male was referred to the surgery department by his family physician for an incidental finding of a gallstone. The patient denied any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or jaundice. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Observation  

  • Since only 1% of patients with asymptomatic stones develop complications, prophylactic cholecystectomy is not warranted in asymptomatic patients.
  • Most patients with gallstones are asymptomatic, often being identified at the time of abdominal imaging for other reasons or during laparotomy.
  • Symptomatic patients present with typical symptoms of postprandial right upper quadrant pain (biliary colic) caused by a stone obstructing the cystic duct
  • Medical treatment of gallstones is generally unsuccessful and is rarely used. Options include dissolution with oral bile salt therapy, contact dissolution, which requires cannulation of the gallbladder, and infusion of organic solvent, and extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.
  • Hence treatment of silent gallstones is observation.

 

Option B: Ursodeoxycholic acid

  • Ursodeoxycholic acid can be used as a medical therapy in carefully selected patients with functional gallbladder radiolucent stones <10 mm in diameter.
  • Stones are dissolved in 50% of patients within 6 months to 2 years.  
  • However, stones >10mm in size rarely dissolve.
  • This patient is asymptomatic.
  • Therefore, she is not a candidate for any surgical or medical management.

Option C: Cholecystectomy 

  • Cholecystectomy is not indicated in asymptomatic patients.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Lithotripsy

  • Lithotripsy of bile duct stones is highly effective and can be considered in patients in whom primary endoscopic or surgical stone removal fails.
  • This patient is asymptomatic.
  • Therefore, she is not a candidate for any surgical or medical management.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with complaints of dysphagia and hematemesis. He has a long history of smoking and alcohol consumption. He is a known case of advanced carcinoma esophagus and is on palliative chemotherapy. What is the common site of the CA esophagus for this patient?

choices.text: The lower end of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Option A: Middle 1/3rd 

  • The middle part of the esophagus is the most common location for Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus(SCCE), which is the most common histology found all around the world. 
  • The incidence of adenocarcinoma is significantly higher in the United States. 
  • Intraepithelial neoplasia, such as dysplasia and carcinoma in situ, can lead to the development of invasive SCCE if it progresses far enough to invade the lamina propria and spreads beyond the submucosa. 
  • Because symptoms appear more commonly in advanced disease, an early diagnosis of SCCE must not be based on symptoms, and as a result, screening approaches must be employed in asymptomatic persons who are exposed to risk factors. 
  • Although esophageal squamous cell carcinoma can develop in the proximal and middle portions of the esophagus.   

Option B: Upper 1/3rd 

  • The Upper 1/3rd of the esophagus is not the most common site for SCCE. 

Option C: Lower 1/3rd 

  • The lower 1/3rd of the esophagus is not the most common site for SCCE. 

Option D: The lower end of the esophagus 

  • The lower end of the esophagus is not the most common site for SCCE.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely related to postoperative ileus?

choices.text: The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia does not affect the return of small bowel motor activity
The presence of peritonitis at the time of the original operation delays the return of normal bowel function
The routine use of metoclopramide will hasten the return of small intestinal motor activity
Contrast radiographic studies have no role in distinguishing early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus

questions.solution:
Option B: The presence of peritonitis at the time of the original operation delays the return of normal bowel function

  • When there is peritonitis along with ileus, the recovery is delayed.
  • An ileus is defined as intestinal distension and the slowing or absence of passage of luminal contents without a demonstrable mechanical obstruction
  • Causes of ileus
    • After laparotomy
    • Metabolic and electrolyte derangements (Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia, Hypomagnesemia, Uremia, Diabetic coma)
    • Drugs (Opiates, Psychotropic drugs, Anticholinergics, Calcium channel blockers, Tricyclic antidepressants)
    • Infection (Intra abdominal inflammation, Systemic sepsis, Peritonitis, Pneumonia)
    • Retroperitoneal inflammation or hemorrhage
    • Mesenteric ischemia
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Ureteral colic
    • Spinal cord injury
    • Myocardial infarction
  • Among the proposed mechanisms responsible for postoperative ileus are Surgical stress-induced sympathetic reflexes, Inflammatory response mediator release, and Anesthetic/analgesic side effects, each of which can inhibit intestinal motility. The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia may delay the recovery of postoperative ileus compared to the IM route of narcotic administration.
  • Normal motility returns generally follow a characteristic temporal sequence, with small intestinal motility returning to normal within the first 24 hours after laparotomy and gastric and colonic motility returning to normal by 48 hours and 3 to 5 days, respectively. Because small bowel motility returns before colonic and gastric motility, listening for bowel sounds is not a reliable indicator that the ileus has fully resolved
  • The typical and most notable clinical feature is abdominal distension without the usual colicky abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting may or may not occur. Patients with ileus continue to pass flatus and diarrhea, which may help distinguish these patients from those with a mechanical small bowel obstruction
  • Plain radiographs may reveal distended small bowel as well as large bowel loops. In the postoperative setting, CT scanning is the test of choice because it can demonstrate the presence of an intraabdominal abscess or other evidence of peritoneal sepsis that may be causing ileus and can exclude the presence of complete mechanical obstruction
  • The treatment of ileus is entirely supportive, with nasogastric decompression and IV fluids. There has been little success in using prokinetic agents to shorten recovery times after lower abdominal procedures.
  • Measures to reduce postoperative ileus
    • Intraoperative measures
      • Minimize handling of the bowel
      • Laparoscopic approach, if possible
      • Avoid excessive intraoperative fluid administration
    • Postoperative measures
      • Correct electrolyte abnormalities
      • Early enteral feeding
      • Epidural anesthesia, if indicated
      • Avoid excessive intravenous fluid administration
      • Consider mu-opioid antagonists

Option A: The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia does not affect the return of small bowel motor activity

  • Intravenous analgesia increases the chances of a drug overdose.
  • But adequate pain control is an effective method to restore bowel activity.

Option C: The routine use of metoclopramide will hasten the return of small intestinal motor activity

  • Routine use of metoclopramide is not recommended.
  • Although it is a promotility drug.
  • There are several adverse effects, such as movement disorders which are associated with the regular use of metoclopramide

Option D: Contrast radiographic studies have no role in distinguishing early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus

  • Contrast CT is the best test for differentiating early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the gastroenterologist with complaints of diarrhoea for more than one month and colicky abdominal pain for five days. On examination, the patient is a thin and lean man with a blood pressure of 115/70 mmHg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. The doctor has advised a few blood tests and a colonoscopy, which indicate the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Which of the following findings is consistent with the above diagnosis?

choices.text: The disease is confluent, there are no skipareas in the colon, and the rectum is involved
The full thickness of the bowel wall is involved
Microscopic examination of the mucosa reveals granulomas

questions.solution:
Option B: The disease is confluent, there are no skip areas in the colon, and the rectum is involved

  • Based on the clinical symptoms of chronic diarrhoea and abdominal pain and the colonoscopic findings, the likely diagnosis, as given in the scenario, is ulcerative colitis.
  • Ulcerative colitis disease is confluent without any skip areas and almost always involves the rectum.
  • The inflammation observed in ulcerative colitis begins at the anal verge and spreads proximally, as ulcerative colitis always affects the rectum.
  • Ulcerative colitis is a chronic disease that causes large intestine and rectum inflammation.
  • Ulcerative colitis affects the lining of the large intestine, the colon, and the rectum.
Ulcerative Colitis (UC)  
Wall involvement Mucosal and submucosal ulcers
Location Begins in the rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum, the remainder of the GI tract is unaffected
Symptoms Left lower quadrant pain (rectum) with bloody diarrhea
Inflammation Crypt abscesses with neutrophils
Gross appearance Pseudopolyps; loss of haustra 
Complications Toxic megacolon and carcinoma (risk is based on the extent of colonic involvement and duration of disease, generally no a concern until >10 years of disease)

Option A: Rectum is not involved

  • Ulcerative colitis disease is confluent without any skip areas and almost always involves the rectum.
  • In ulcerative colitis, inflammation generally starts in the rectum and spreads to the colon.
  • Rectal lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis.

Option C: The full thickness of the bowel wall is involved

  • In ulcerative colitis, only mucosa and submucosa membranes are involved instead of the full-thickness bowel wall.
  • In Crohn's disease, all the layers of the bowel walls are affected, while ulcerative colitis only affects the colon's innermost lining.

Option D: Microscopic examination of the mucosa reveals granulomas

  • Granulomas are not seen in ulcerative colitis. They are seen in Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A patient with steroid-resistant ITP underwent laparoscopic splenectomy. On day 2 of the postoperative period, the patient had fever episodes. Which of the following scenarios is most likely?
questions.solution:
Option A: Left lower lobe consolidation

  • The patient underwent laparoscopic splenectomy on account of her steroid-resistant ITP. She develops a fever on the third postoperative day, suggesting some infectious complications.
  • Fever on postoperative day (POD) two after laparoscopic splenectomy suggests left lower lobe consolidation
  • The causes of postoperative fever include ‘W’s and are as follows:
    • Wind - POD 1 to 3 - Atelectasis and pneumonia
    • Water - POD 3 to 5 - Urinary tract infection
    • Walking - POD 4 to 8 - Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
    • Wound - POD 5 to 7 - Surgical site infection
    • Wonder drugs - anytime - Drug fever

Option B: Port site infection

  • Surgical site infection occurs in people with poor wound healing, infectious etiology, and immunocompromised patients.
  • It manifests on the 5th to 7th postoperative day

Option C: Intra-abdominal collection

  • Intra-abdominal collection can result from anastomotic leakage or poor hemostatic control.
  • It also manifests on the 5th to 7th postoperative day.

Option D: Urinary tract infection

  • UTI manifests on the 3rd to 5th postoperative day.
  • It presents with fever, dysuria, and burning micturition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of painful swelling of the scrotum and feeling of pressure at the base of the penis. The physical examination reveals that there is a mass on one side of the testicle. The vitals are within normal limits. The sign is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Epididymal cyst

  • In the above-given case, the presence of scrotal mass, painful swelling, and pressure on the penis are suggestive of the diagnosis of the epididymal cyst.
  • Cysts of the epididymis are the cystic transformation of the aberrant structures like paradidymis, hydatid of Morgagni (appendix of the epididymis) etc.
  • There are actually multiple cysts or multilocular cysts above and behind the body of the testis.
  • In contrast to hydrocele, these can be felt apart from the testis.
  • They are tense, fluctuant and brilliantly translucent. But due to the presence of multiple septa, brilliant translucency is finely tessellated, giving the appearance of a Chinese lantern.
  • This condition may be bilateral. The cyst lies behind the testis, whereas the hydrocele lies in front of the testis.

Option A: Spermatocele

  • Spermatocele is an abnormal sac that may develop in the spermatic cord.
  • It is filled with clear or milky fluid that may contain sperm.
  • It is generally painless and noncancerous.

Option C: Hydrocele of cord

  • Hydrocele of the cord can be caused due to unclosed processus vaginalis.
  • There might be a passage of fluid between the abdomen and the spermatic cord.
  • When the baby lies or cry, the area of the cord change in size.

Option D: Secondary hydrocele

  • Secondary hydrocele can be partially palpated on physical examination.
  • It can be communicating and non-communicating hydrocele.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with chronic kidney disease stage 3A who has developed a decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) after the initiation of warfarin therapy due to atrial fibrillation is referred for dialysis. The patient has been admitted and is prepared to initiate dialysis. What is the pathophysiological effect of creating an AV fistula?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased cardiac output

  • When an arteriovenous fistula is formed involving a major artery like the abdominal aorta, it can lead to a large decrease in peripheral resistance.
  • This lowered peripheral resistance causes the heart to increase cardiac output to maintain proper blood flow to all tissues.
  • In this case, a patient with chronic kidney disease has been admitted for dialysis and an arteriovenous fistula has been created for hemodialysis access.
  • As a result of which, veins become dilated, tortuous, and become arterialized.

Option A: Sinus bradycardia

  • Arteriovenous fistula leads to a decrease in total peripheral resistance, as a result of which cardiac output and heart rate increase leading to sinus tachycardia.
  • Sinus bradycardia occurs in enteric fever.

Option B: Decrease in preload

  • An arteriovenous fistula can increase preload. AV shunts also decrease the afterload of the heart.
  • As the blood bypasses the arterioles, it results in a decrease in total peripheral resistance (TPR).
  • AV shunts increase both the rate and volume of blood returning to the heart.

Option C: Cardiac arrhythmias

  • If an arteriovenous fistula is superficial, it may present as a palpable mass with a bruit on auscultation.
  • It increases preload and decreases afterload; as a result, heart rate increases.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias don’t occur in AV fistula.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old male comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired postman. Examination shows a single rough patch on his scalp. A photograph is shown.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option D: Bowen disease

  • This patient is most likely suffering from Bowen's disease.
  • Bowen disease is characterized by squamous cell carcinoma in situ (SCCIS) of the skin.
  • Bowen disease is commonly associated with sun exposure and may appear similar to this patient's lesion.
  • It usually manifests as a solitary lesion rather than the multiple ill-defined, confluent lesions seen on this patient's scalp, as shown in the image below:

  • Bowen disease is considered a precancerous skin lesion. It may progress to invasive squamous cell carcinoma.
  • The diagnostic work-up includes clinical examination and biopsy of the lesion.
  • The treatment includes pharmacotherapy (5-FU, imiquimod) and surgical excision.

Other

Option A: Seborrheic keratosis

  • Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumour in the elderly population.
  • However, in contrast to this patient's rough, patchy lesions, it manifests as darkly pigmented papules or plaques that are soft, sharply demarcated, and appear greasy, wax-like, and 'stuck-on' appearance as shown in the image below:

  • These lesions involve the trunk, back of the hands, face and neck, and forearms rather than the scalp.

Option B: Keratoacanthoma

  • Keratoacanthomas tend to occur in elderly patients who have had chronic sun exposure. These lesions manifest as a round erythematous nodule with a central crater that grows rapidly, usually within weeks to months shown in the image below:

  • However, the multiple erythematous lesions with scales found on the scalp suggest a different diagnosis in this patient.

Option C: Actinic keratosis

  • Actinic keratosis is characterised by a precancerous lesion on sun-exposed skin such as the scalp, face, ears, and dorsal aspects of the hands or arms.
