  • It predominantly affects light-skinned individuals over 50 years of age.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with a history of anterior myocardial infarction, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension visits the doctor after experiencing shortness of breath, low-grade fever, excessive night sweats, and significant weight loss. His vital signs include a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F), a pulse of 104/min. Examination shows a painless fluctuant, non-transilluminate swelling on the neck with a thin watery discharge, as shown in the image below:



Chest x-ray shows bilateral pleural effusion and patchy infiltrates in the right middle lobe of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tuberculous lymphadenitis

  • This patient is most likely suffering from tuberculous lymphadenitis. A tuberculous lymphadenitis is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis that causes granulomatous inflammation and results in necrosis of lymph nodes.
  • It usually manifests as discrete or matted, non-tender lymphadenopathy, with or without discharging sinus tracts, as shown in the image below:

 

 

 

  • Tuberculous lymphadenitis commonly involves the cervical and supraclavicular lymph node groups.
  • The diagnostic workup for tuberculous lymphadenitis involves fine-needle aspiration or excisional (FNAC) and biopsy with the histopathologic examination and culture for mycobacteria.
  • The treatment is by the use of antituberculosis therapy.

Option A: Branchial cyst

  • A congenital neck mass arises if the embryological second branchial cleft or cervical sinus fails to obliterate. A branchial cyst typically presents as a painless mass lateral to the midline, usually anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which does not move with swallowing. These features are not present in this clinical vignette.

Option B: Metastatic tumours in the neck

  • The malignancies can metastasize to the lymph nodes in the cervical region, and the lymph nodes appear enlarged. However, this patient's history and examination suggest no malignancy. Furthermore, the pulmonary infiltrate also suggests tuberculosis, so this option can be ruled out.

Option D: Lymphoma

  • Most patients with lymphoma present with asymptomatic lymphadenopathy or a mass on a chest radiograph.
  • Constitutional symptoms such as fever, night sweats, or unintended weight loss are also present.
  • However, the presence of pulmonary infiltrates and draining cervical sinus suggest tuberculous lymphadenitis as a likely aetiology.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain with distension, bilious vomiting, and fever for 3 weeks. He weighed 8 kg with a history of failure to thrive since early infancy. The abdomen was mildly distended with non-tender hepatomegaly. The chest radiograph was normal. USG suggested dilated large bowel loops that were peristaltic with moderate free fluid. The child was kept nil per oral and the fluid and electrolyte imbalance was corrected. Due to persistent bilious aspirates, an upper gastrointestinal (GI) contrast study was performed that suggested malrotation with  sigmoid volvulus. The patient was scheduled for surgery. Which of the following is a component of the procedure ?

choices.text: Reduction of volvulus by clockwise rotation
Ladd's band divided near the medial aspect of the duodenum
Part of the jejunum is resected and anastomosis performed

questions.solution:
Option A: Reduction of volvulus by counterclockwise wise rotation

  • Volvulus usually twists in a clockwise direction, and reduction is accomplished by twisting in a counterclockwise direction.

Volvulus:

  • A volvulus is the twisting of a loop of the intestine around its mesenteric attachment, resulting in closed-loop bowel obstruction. The affected bowel can become ischaemic due to a compromised blood supply, rapidly leading to bowel necrosis and perforation.
  • Most volvuli occur at the sigmoid colon, while the caecum is the second most common site. It is a common cause of large bowel obstruction in many countries (after malignancy and diverticular disease). They can also occur in the stomach, small intestine and transverse colon but are much rarer.
  • It is a rotation of the bowel on its axis.

  • Malrotation can be asymptomatic or may be manifested as chronic, vague abdominal pain, with or without intermittent bilious emesis, and failure to thrive.
  • The acute onset of bilious vomiting in a neonate is considered a sign of malrotation. It demands immediate radiologic evaluation.
  • Clinical features include abdominal distension, pain, tenderness-like feeling over the abdomen and vomiting followed by perforation/gangrene.

 

Upper Gastrointestinal Contrast Study

  • Malrotation is diagnosed by an abnormal position of the ligament of Treitz. The normal location is typical to the left of the vertebral column and posterior to the stomach.

 

Management:

Sigmoid Volvulus:

  • Gangrenous sigmoid volvulus is best managed with Hartmann’s procedure. Non-gangrenous sigmoid volvulus is best managed with resection and anastomosis unless there are risk factors for anastomotic leakage, in which case the surgeon should consider mesosigmoidopexy with a non-absorbable suture.
  • All patients admitted with suspected sigmoid volvulus should be managed initially as per any patient with bowel obstruction. In particular, they should be examined for any signs of ischaemia and given fluid resuscitation.
  • Conservative management: Most patients with sigmoid volvulus are treated conservatively initially with decompression by sigmoidoscope and insertion of a flatus tube. In sigmoidoscope decompression, the patient is placed in the left lateral position and a lubricated sigmoidoscope is gently guided into the rectum. It is manoeuvred to locate the twisted bowel and once the sigmoidoscope is in the correct position, there will be a rush of air and liquid faeces as the obstruction is relieved. A flatus tube is often left in situ for a period (up to 24 hours) after initial decompression to allow for the continued passage of contents and aid recovery of the affected area. In 25-50% of patients, this approach is unsuccessful and a formal decompression with a flexible sigmoidoscope is required.
  • Surgical management:  The indications for surgery (which is usually a laparotomy for a Hartmann’s procedure) are:

           1. Colonic ischaemia or perforation

           2. Repeated failed attempts at decompression

           3. Necrotic bowel noted at endoscopy

  • The decision on which operation to perform will depend on the patient’s nutritional status, adequacy of blood supply, haemodynamic stability, and the presence of any perforation or peritonitis. Patients with recurrent volvulus who are otherwise healthy may choose to have an elective procedure (most common sigmoidectomy with primary anastomosis) to prevent further recurrence.

​​​​​​​

Caecal volvulus:

  • With cecal volvulus, vascular compromise is more common in cecal volvulus compared to sigmoid volvulus. The plain x-rays are usually adequate for diagnosis. The options for treatment include endoscopic decompression, caecopexy or a right hemicolectomy

Option B: Ladd's band is divided near the medial aspect of the duodenum

  • Ladd's band is divided near the lateral aspect of the duodenum. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option C: Cholecystectomy

  • Appendectomy can also be done during the procedure, not cholecystectomy.

Option D: Part of the jejunum is resected and anastomosis is performed

  • Part of the jejunum should not be resected and anastomosed during the procedure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a watchman by occupation, comes to the OPD complaining of swelling and bulging of veins in the lower limbs. He also describes feeling restlessness, occasional cramping bilaterally, and tiredness at the end of the day. Examination reveals dilated, tortuous veins in the patient's right lower limb, extending from the middle thigh to the leg in a standing position. Doppler test results show venous stasis. On the basis of the patient's condition, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Most common symptom: Dull aching pain in the veins after prolonged standing the whole day
Clinical investigation is the choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins
Bisgard's Regime is not used for venous ulcers
Trendelenberg operation is a gold standard treatment for varicose veins

questions.solution:
Option A: Most common symptom: Dull aching pain in the veins after prolonged standing the whole day

  • In this case, as the patient's occupation is watchman, he has to stand for a prolonged period. The patient is also showing dilated tortuous veins. Both symptoms are indications of varicose veins.
  • If a person has to sit or stand for a long time, the blood in the leg veins can pool, leading to increased blood pressure. 
  • Deep and perforating veins can withstand short periods of increased pressure. But prolonged standing can result in the stretching of veins. This stretching can result in the weakening of the walls of veins and damage vein valves and resulting in an enlarged and swollen vein called varicose vein formation.
  • It is caused by blood reflux and stagnation due to the dysfunction of the superficial veins in the lower extremities. Most people show no obvious discomfort, but some patients can face pain, soreness, swelling and even bleeding.
  • Symptoms of varicose vein include:
    • Enlarged veins in purple-blue colour
    • Aching, heavy and uncomfortable legs
    • Swollen feet and ankles
    • Worsen pain while sitting and standing 
    • Muscle cramp in legs
    • Dry skin and colour changes in the lower leg

Option B: Clinical investigation is the choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins

  • Varicose veins cannot be diagnosed only on the basis of clinical examination.
  • Duplex ultrasound is considered the ideal investigation of choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins.
  • It measures the speed of blood flow and the structure of the veins of the legs.

Option C: Bisgaard's Regime is not used for venous ulcers

  • Bisgaard's Regime is Limb elevation.
  • Compression stockings + Massage for varicose ulcers
  • Bisgaard’s Regime is used for venous ulcers.

Option D: Trendelenberg operation is a gold standard treatment for varicose vein

  • Endothermal Ablation (EVLA and RFA) is a gold standard treatment for varicose veins.
  • It includes Endovenous laser ablation, which restores the normal blood flow of the legs.
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) seals off the varicose vein and redirects the blood flow to healthier veins in the legs.

questions.text: A 36-year-old African-American male presents to a plastic surgeon with a recurrent keloid lesion in the left earlobe with previous injuries. The lesion was operated on but always grows back postoperatively. On examination, the patient has a 2 cm non-tender swelling anterior to his tragus. The most appropriate management of recurrent keloid is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Intramarginal excision followed by radiation

  • A keloid scar is an enlarged, raised scar that comes from the overgrowth of scar tissue.
  • It is more common in people with dark skin, such as people from Africa and African-Caribbean and south Indian communities.
  • Keloids are shiny and hairless bumps that are raised above the surrounding skin. It can also present as a brown hard, rubbery mass.
  • It is usually painless but can sometimes present with pain, tenderness and itchiness.
  • It occurs as a result of an overgrowth of granulation (collagen type 3) at the site of a healed skin injury which is then slowly replaced by collagen type 1.
  • Treatment of keloid:
    • Keloids rarely regress with time and are often refractory to medical and surgical intervention
    • First-line treatment: silicone in combination with pressure therapy and intralesional corticosteroid injection
    • Refractory cases usually after 12 months of therapy: excision + postoperative radiotherapy (external beam or brachytherapy)
    • New treatment modalities: internal cryotherapy and 5% imiquimod.

Option A: Excisional surgery

  • The process of surgically cutting out the keloid
  • It is not a permanent solution, as the keloid may return after the surgery.
  • To reduce the chances of recurring keloids wearing a pressure garment and getting cryosurgery or radiotherapy may reduce the chances of recurrence.

Option C: Cryosurgery

  • The procedure in which an extremely cold liquid or an instrument called a cryoprobe is used to freeze and destroy the keloid.
  • It can cause a permanent light spot; therefore, it is not recommended for dark-skinned individuals.

Option D: Silicone gel sheeting

  • Silicone gel sheeting may help to flatten a keloid.
  • It may be applied to a new keloid or after an injury to prevent the keloid from growing.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of road traffic accidents due to a motorcycle collision with a heavy vehicle. Vitals are within normal limits. On abdominal examination, no guarding or rigidity is found, although the patient has mild tenderness in the left hypochondrium. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is done, and the findings are shown in the image below:



Which of the following does it suggest?
questions.solution:
• Collection of fluid in peri-splenic region elicited in USG→Positive FAST
  • FAST (Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma)

Subxiphoid transverse viewQ

• Assess pericardial sacQ

Right upper quadrant (RUQ) longitudinal viewQ

• Assess perihepatic regionQ

Left upper quadrant (LUQ) longitudinal viewQ

• Assess perisplenic regionQ

Suprapubic longitudinal & transverse viewQ

• Assess pelvisQ
  • e-FAST (extended FAST) has two additional views, right & left thoracic views to rule out pneumothorax or hemothoraxQ.
  • Any patient with blunt trauma abdomen – First investigation done is FAST (stable/unstable)
  • After FAST:
    • If patient unstable – Exploratory laparotomy
    • If patient stable – CECT

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presented with an enlarging lesion on the upper back of 3 years duration. She had multiple co-morbidities. On examination, there was a 4-cm diameter erythematous, shiny plaque. A punch biopsy showed superficial basal cell carcinoma. It was decided to treat her with imiquimod. What is the recommended treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Imiquimod is indicated 5 times per week for 6 weeks in superficial basal cell carcinoma.

Imiquimod

  • Imiquimod is an immune modulator that acts as a toll-like receptor TLR 7,8 agonists. It is used topically to treat warts on the genital and anal areas. But it does not cure warts, and new warts may appear during treatment. Imiquimod does not fight the viruses that cause warts directly, however, it controls wart production. Imiquimod is used in certain types of skin cancer called superficial basal cell carcinoma and is also used to treat a skin condition of the face and scalp called actinic keratoses.
  • Indication:
    Anogenital wart=3 times per week
    Actinic keratosis= 2 times per week
    Superficial BCC= 5 times per week

Learning objective:

  • Imiquimod is a synthetic imidazoquinolone amine with a potent immune response modifier activity. This characteristic property of imiquimod has led to its use in several applications in dermatology, especially in cutaneous malignancies like superficial BCC, where it is effective and safe. Imiquimod is used 5 times per week for 6 weeks in BCC.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with hematemesis, melena, and mild splenomegaly. There is no obvious jaundice or ascites. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option A: Extrahepatic portal venous obstruction

  • The most likely diagnosis, in this case, is extrahepatic portal vein obstruction.
  • Differences between EHPVO and NCPF:
    • EHPVO (Extrahepatic portal venous obstruction) - Usually seen in 1st to 2nd decade; splenomegaly is less common and if its present, it is only mild/moderate.
    • NCPF (Non-Cirrhotic portal fibrosis) - In the 2nd to 4th decade; Splenomegaly is most common and if present, it is moderate to severe; hematemesis present, no obvious jaundice, and ascites.
  • The liver is small but histologically normal in extrahepatic portal vein obstruction resulting from portal vein malformation or obstruction.

Other options

Option B: Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis

  • Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis, also called obliterative portal venopathy, causes portal hypertension.
  • It causes massive splenomegaly, unlike in this patient.
  • The patient also presents with variceal bleeding in young adults from low social backgrounds.

Option C: Cirrhosis

  • Patients with liver cirrhosis must have some history of hepatitis B/C or alcohol. This patient has no such history, so liver cirrhosis is less likely.

Option D: Hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction

  • Hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction is also called Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • Patient with this condition is mostly seen in myeloproliferative disorders in which abnormal growth of cells in the bone marrow.
  • Hepatomegaly is also seen, which is absent in the clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 33-year-old chronic alcoholic female presented with complaints of pain in the epigastric region and multiple episodes of vomiting. The patient was admitted and diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis after an extensive evaluation. The patient had severe abdominal pain, which did not resolve with medical therapy. Which of the following Nerve block helps relieve pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Celiac ganglia

  • Celiac plexus blockade in chronic pancreatitis is used for pain relief
  • Cause of pain in chronic pancreatitis:
    • Inflammatory changes of pancreatic parenchyma with intrapancreatic and peripancreatic neural alterations
    • Ductal and intraparenchymal hypertension
    • Altered nociception of pain
  • Medical treatment options for pain
    • Alcohol abstinence and diet
    • Enzyme therapy
    • Antioxidant therapy
    • Analgesics
      • 0% to 70% of patients seem to benefit from medical treatment

Option B: Vagus nerve

  • Vagus nerve block can be used to block pain in vagal neuralgia and after thoracic surgeries to block the cough.

Option C: Anterolateral column of spinal cord

  • The anterolateral column of the spinal cord is where the spinothalamic tracts travel, responsible for pain, temperature, and crude touch. Blocking the anterolateral spinal column will cause the tracts of the body to be disturbed. We want a local neural block for pain relief in pancreatitis.

Option D: None of the above

  • Celiac plexus block is used for the pain relief of chronic pancreatitis

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with tenderness in the right iliac fossa is being prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. The specimen from the surgery is given below. What gold standard investigation is used to diagnose this condition before surgery in doubtful cases?
questions.solution:
Option A: Contrast-enhanced CT scan abdomen

  • The specimen in the given image is the appendix and the surgery performed is appendectomy through a lower midline incision.
  • The gold standard for diagnosis of acute appendicitis is a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen.

 

  • Findings on CT scan:
    • Inflamed and thickened appendix with surrounding stranding indicating inflammation.
    • The appendix is classically more than 7 mm in diameter with an inflamed, thickened wall and mural enhancement or target sign.
    • Perforation of the appendix is suggested by periappendicular fluid or air.
    • The Arrowhead sign is the demonstration of thickened caecum funneling contrast material into the appendicular orifice.
  • Findings on Ultrasound
    • The appendix is found immobile, enlarged, and non-compressible.

Option B: Ultrasound

  • It is not the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis.
  • It can demonstrate an immobile, enlarged and non-compressible appendix
  • Sensitivity is very low and operator dependent
  • Not a common investigation for diagnosing acute appendicitis

Option C: MRI

  • It is also not a gold standard investigation for acute appendicitis.
  • MRI is reserved for radiosensitive populations such as children and pregnant females.
  • Widespread availability and claustrophobia are important limitations to its use.

Option D: Laparotomy

  • Laparotomy is not a preoperative diagnostic tool.
  • It is diagnostic as well as therapeutic for acute appendicitis.
  • In doubtful cases and the non-availability of imaging modalities, laparotomy is done.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the neurology department with complaints of severe headache associated with blurred vision and vomiting for the last 1 hour. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, a pulse rate of 47 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. His GCS is 12/15, and he has classical features of Cushing's Triad. His MRI brain reveals a posterior fossa lesion leading to raised intracranial pressure. What would be the management of the raised ICP in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Decompressive craniectomy

  • Based on the case discussed above, the patient has classical symptoms (nausea, vomiting, and severe headache) of raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and management would be decompressive craniectomy.
  • Stepwise approach to the treatment of elevated Intracranial pressure:
    • Insert ICP monitor - Ventriculostomy or Parenchymal device.
    • General goals: Maintain ICP < 20 mmHg and CPP 60 mmHg.
    • For ICP > 20-25 mmHg for > 5 min:
      • Elevated head of the bed, midline head position
      • Osmotherapy - mannitol
      • Sedation (e.g., Morphine, Propofol, or Midazolam); add neuromuscular paralysis, if necessary (patient will require endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation at this (point, if not before).
      • Hyperventilation to PaCO2 30-35 mmHg
      • Pressor therapy - Phenylephrine, Dopamine, or Norepinephrine to maintain adequate MAP to ensure CPP 60 mmHg.
  • Consider second-tier therapies for refractory elevated ICP:
    • High-dose barbiturate therapy ("Pentobarb coma”)
    • Aggressive hyperventilation to PaCO2 < 30 mmHg
    • Hypothermia
    • Hemicraniectomy (decompressive craniectomy)

Option A: Hyperthermia

  • Management of raised ICP includes hypothermia, not hyperthermia.
  • Hypothermia reduces cerebral metabolism and cerebral blood flow, decreasing intracranial pressure.

Option B: Hypercapnia

  • ICP is lowered by inducing hypocapnia, not by hypercapnia.
  • Inducing hypocapnia via hyperventilation reduces the partial pressure of arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO2), inciting vasoconstriction in the cerebral resistance arterioles.
  • This constriction decrease cerebral blood flow, reduces cerebral blood volume, and decreases ICP.

Option D: Opioids

  • High-dose barbiturate therapy ("Pentobarb coma") is given in cases with increased intracranial pressure.
  • Barbiturates reduce ICP by suppressing cerebral metabolism, leading to reduced cerebral blood volume.

questions.text: A woman in her early 20s was referred for neurological examination due to slowly progressive wasting of the small hand muscles and weakness of the left hand. She also had a history of being treated for a left-arm fracture some 2yrs ago. The patient had always been healthy, with no known family history of neurological disease. She described reduced fine motor skills and difficulty writing because she struggled to grip the pen. This was not accompanied by pain or loss of sensation. She had not seen any signs of functional decline in the proximal musculature of the arms or in the lower extremities. The probable nerve injury involved in this patient would be?
questions.solution:
• Ulnar nerve innervates 15 of 20 intrinsic muscles of the hand. Hence, its injury results in the n wasting of intrinsic muscles othe f hand
  • Musculocutaneous, radial, ulnar & median nerves are all important to hand function.
  • Musculocutaneous and radial nerves allow forearm supination; the radial nerve alone innervates the extensor muscles.
  • Median nerve is the “eye of the hand” because of its extensive contribution to sensory perception; it also maintains most of the long flexors, the pronators of the forearm & thenar muscles.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents in the hospital with dull pain for 8 months. A round tender mass is present on the right knee. On x-ray, a sunburst pattern of the osteolytic bone lesion is found in the combination of sclerotic bone formation and invasion of surrounding tissues. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Osteosarcoma

  • The sunburst pattern on the x-ray suggests osteosarcoma, which can be defined as a malignant tumor of the mesenchymal cells, characterized by the formation of osteoid or bone by the tumor cells.
  • These tumors occur between the ages of 15-25, with the lower end of the femur, the most common site of pain, usually the first symptom, soon followed by swelling.
  • Other findings in osteosarcoma: periosteal reaction and sunray appearance.

Option A: Ewing’s sarcoma

  • Malignant bone tumors originate from neuroectodermal cells.
  • Due to translocation of EWSR1.

Option B: Chondrosarcoma

  • Has dense calcification.
  • Associated with hyperglycemia.
  • Best prognosis amongst malignant tumors.
  • Chondrosarcoma (Best prognosis)> Osteosarcoma >>> Ewing's sarcoma (worst prognosis).
  • Usually metaphyseal and central, i.e., arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification (described as punctate, comma, popcorn calcification).
  • Solitary osteochondroma in <1% can turn malignant into chondrosarcoma.
  • Multiple osteosarcomas in <6% can turn into malignant chondrosarcoma.
  • It occurs over a broad age range:
    • Peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma.
    • Between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma.
  • It is a slow-growing tumor and most common in age over 50 years.
  • It presents with dull pain, which worsens at night.
  • Localized pain and tenderness are also present on palpation.
  • X-ray findings are mouth-eaten or lytic and popcorn-like calcification also called spiculated calcification.

Option D: Osteoclastoma

  • It is a giant cell tumour bone osteolytic neoplasm.
  • Prevalence is between the ages of 20- 40.
  • Found in epiphysis or metaphysis of a long bone.
  • Local pain and swelling with limited motion.
  • It presents with dull pain, which worsens at night.
  • It affects young adults.
  • Treatment is with surgery.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after encountering a road traffic accident. He was a non-restrained driver in a car. He got hit by a truck from the side, and the car rolled over. The patient has painful neck movements and left finger numbness and weakness. A neck collar is applied, and a CT scan is ordered. The CT scan image of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely fracture?

choices.text: Due to fracture of traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2 over C3

questions.solution:
Option A: Fracture of Atlas

Fracture of Atlas:

  • Burst fracture of C1 (ATLAS), also known as Jefferson fracture.
  • Mnemonic: JAT (Jefferson- ATlas)
  • Burst fracture occurs due to vertical compression force.
  • The neural deficit is rare (because wide spinal canal)
  • It can present with:
    • Pain
    • Restriction in neck movement
    • Hematoma
    • Neurological deficits
  • Two types depending on stability:
    • Stable fractures: Anterior column fracture without any compromise in the stability of the spine
    • Unstable fractures: Posterior column fracture,
    • Spinal cord injury is common, and neurological deficits are usually present.

Option A: Fracture of Axis

Hangman fracture:

  • Hangman fracture is the fracture of the axis
  • Traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2 (axis) over C3 with a fracture through pars – inter articularis of C2
  • Slip of C2 over C3 vertebra called spondylolisthesis.
  • Not usually associated with the neurological deficit as pars fracture expands the canal.
  • The most common fracture of C2 is at the odontoid process or dens.

Option C: Due to fracture of traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2 over C3

  • Traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2 (axis) over C3 with a fracture through pars – inter articularis of C2
  • Slip of C2 over C3 vertebra called spondylolisthesis.
  • Not usually associated with the neurological deficit as pars fracture expands the canal.
  • The most common fracture of C2 is at the odontoid process or dens.

Option D: Avulsion fracture of C7

  • Clay shoveler’s fracture is the fracture of the lower cervical vertebra
  • It is an avulsion fracture
  • fracture in hyperextension dislocation. Sagittal CT image... | Download Scientific Diagram" src="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/260271892/figure/fig23/AS:202814618902551@1425366181430/Avulsion-fracture-in-hyperextension-dislocation-Sagittal-CT-image-shows-an-avulsion.png" />

questions.text: A 5-day-old newborn baby is admitted to the hospital in an agonal state with pale mucosa and acute respiratory failure. The child's mother did not have a prenatal follow-up. She reports the non-existence of disease in the family. An X-ray of the child is given below. Which of the following is not true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cataract

Cataract

  • The given radiograph shows bowing of long bones due to multiple transverse fractures in the femur, humerus right 3rd, 4th, and 6th posterior ribs.
  • The most common cause of fracture in childhood is Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • A cataract is not seen in Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Osteogenesis Imperfecta

  • Bone fragility (brittle "wormian" bone)
  • Short stature
  • Scoliosis
  • Tooth defects (Dentinogenesis imperfecta)
  • Hearing defects
  • Blue sclerae in Types I and II
  • Ligamentous laxity
  • Classification: Four types have been identified
Type Inheritance Sclerae Features
1A,1B A.D. Blue

Onset at preschool age (Tarda); hearing loss; involvement of

teeth (type I.A. only)
II A.R. Blue Lethal; concertina femur, beaded ribs
III A.R. Normal

Fractures at birth, progressively short stature

I.V.A., IVB AD Normal

IV-A,

IV-B		 AD Normal Milder form; normal hearing, involvement of teeth (type I.V.A. only)
  • Treatment:
    • Fracture management
    • Bracing
    • Bisphosphonates

Option A: Blue sclera

  • Because of collagen defects in the blood vessels of the sclera, the scleral vessels become thin.
  • This causes the underlying choroidal vasculature to be seen, giving the sclera a blue appearance

Option B: Multiple Fractures

  • Type I collagen is the major part of the bone.
  • It provides tensile strength to the bone.
  • A defect can lead to weak bone that results in multiple fractures.

Option D: Hearing loss

  • Osteosclerosis or fracture of the bones of the middle ear may result in hearing loss.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department after he fell while playing football and hit his right elbow. Physical examination reveals severe pain and tenderness in his elbow with a limited range of motion. An x-ray was performed that showed a fracture of the medial epicondyle of the right humerus. Which is the most common nerve injured in the given clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulnar

  • The ulnar nerve (C8-T1) arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • It descends downward in the upper arm medial to the axillary artery.
  • At the elbow, it runs posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • It passes through the two heads of the flexor carpi ulnaris and enters the flexor compartment of the forearm.
  • At the wrist, the ulnar nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum and enters the hand through Guyon’s canal.
  • On the hand, it terminates by dividing into superficial and deep branches.
  • It supplies the following muscles:
  • Flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • Medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus.
  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand except for the thenar muscles and two lateral lumbricals.
  • The sensory supply of the ulnar nerve includes:
  • Palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial side of the hand.
  • Palmar and dorsal aspects of the ulnar one and half fingers.

  • As it passes behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus, the ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in case of its fracture.

Option B: Median

  • The median nerve is injured in case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Option C: Radial

  • The radial nerve is most commonly injured in case of a fracture of the humerus shaft.

Option D: Axillary

  • The axillary nerve is most commonly injured in case of a fracture of the humerus neck.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the surgical Outpatient department. His CT scan reveals carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. It is decided to carry out a Whipple's procedure. What will be the replacement fluid required per hour?
questions.solution:
Option C: 8ml/kg

  • The principle of replacement fluid in surgery is that whatever fluid is lost during surgery should be replaced, and its requirement depends upon surgery.

  • Because redistributive and evaporative losses are primarily related to wound size and the extent of surgical dissections and manipulations, procedures can be classified according to the degree of tissue trauma.

  • The usual requirements of most surgeries are as follows:
    • Minor surgery =2-3 ml/kg body weight/hr.
    • Moderate surgery = 4-6 ml/ kg body weight/hr.
    • Major surgery = 8-10 ml/kg body weight/hr.
    • Since Whipple's procedure is major surgery, the patient's hourly requirements will be 8-10 ml/kg body weight/hr.

Option A: 2ml/kg/hr

  • 2-3 ml/kg/hr is the requirement for minor surgery.
  • E.g. incision and drainage, removal of a foreign object.

Option B: 4ml/kg/hr

  • 4ml/kg/hr is the requirement of moderate surgery.
  • Laparoscopic procedures.

Option D: 12ml/kg/hr

  • A fluid requirement of as much as 12 ml/kg/hr is normally not required.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child who is in a case of acute appendicitis is posted for an emergency appendectomy. His medical history is consistent with bronchial asthma. His medication includes an albuterol inhaler. Last week, he suffered from a cough and fever with yellow sputum, which is now better. Which of the following agent must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Desflurane

  • Desflurane is avoided in asthmatic patients as it is bronchoconstrictor
  • Desflurane is a fluorinated methyl ethyl ether that differs from isoflurane by substituting a fluorine atom for a chlorine atom.
  • This fluorination increases vapour pressure(decreases intermolecular attraction), enhances molecular stability, and decreases potency. Its high vapour pressure makes it boil at room temperature, so it needs a heated and pressurized vaporizer that requires electrical power.
  • Desflurane is pungent compared to Halothane and Sevoflurane, which produces airway irritation, salivation, breath holding, coughing, or laryngospasm when >6% inspired desflurane is administered to the awake patient. So it is unlikely to use as an inhalational induction agent.
  • It produces the highest concentrations of carbon monoxide compared to others (although not a common occurrence), resulting from degradation by a strong base in desiccated carbon dioxide absorbents. The propensity for CO production correlates with an anaesthetic concentration in the breathing circuit
    • Though sevoflurane, methoxyflurane, and halothane also degrade in the presence of strong bases, they do not produce CO.
    • CO production is predominantly seen with absorbents that contain barium hydroxide and when the water content of soda lime or Baralyme falls below 1.4% and 5%.
    • Absorb is a CO2 absorbent that is more inert than soda lime and Baralyme and associated with lesser degradation of anaesthetics and less carbon monoxide production.
    • Factors increasing the production of carbon monoxide and the risk of carboxyhemoglobinemia:
      • Inhaled anaesthetic used (Desflurane>Enflurane>Isoflurane>>Halothane=Sevoflurane)
      • Degree of desiccation of the absorbent
      • Type of absorbent(KOH or NaOH containing)
      • High temperature
      • High concentration of anaesthetic
      • Low fresh gas flow rates
      • Small patient size
  • Desflurane has lower blood: gas partition coefficient(0.45) and MAC(6.6%), permitting rapid achievement of alveolar partial pressure necessary for anaesthesia followed by prompt awakening when desflurane is discontinued.
  • Lower blood gas solubility, more precise control over anaesthesia delivery and more rapid recovery from anaesthesia distinguish it from others. This may be particularly advantageous in the morbidly obese patient as it is poorly soluble, and the duration of administration on time to recovery is minimal.
  • Soluble anaesthetics such as halothane and isoflurane cause prolonged recovery in proportion to the duration of anaesthesia. Enflurane has intermediate solubility in blood and permits intermediate onset and recovery

Option A: Halothane

  • Halothane has non-pungent odor.
  • It has minimum airway irritating activity.
  • It causes bronchodilation and is hence safe in patients with asthma

Option B: Nitrous oxide

  • N2O (commonly called laughing gas) produces its anaesthetic effect without decreasing blood pressure or cardiac output.
  • Although it directly depresses the myocardium, cardiac depression is offset by an N2O– mediated sympathetic stimulation.
  • Likewise, respiration is maintained. Tidal volume falls, but minute ventilation is supported by a centrally mediated increase in respiratory rate
  • It is safe for patients with asthma

Option D: Enflurane

  • Enflurane is a non-irritative agent.
  • It causes brochodilation and is safe for asthma patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. He had a traumatic brain injury due to a road traffic accident. The primary survey showed unconsciousness with a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg and a pulse rate of 50 beats/minute. He was posted for emergency decompressive craniotomy under general anaesthesia. The intravenous anaesthetic agent to be avoided in this patient will be?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ketamine

  • The patient has high blood pressure, a decreased pulse rate, and traumatic brain injury.
  • Ketamine is known to increase cerebral blood flow, cerebral metabolism, and intracranial pressure; therefore, it won't be a suitable option in a patient with brain injury.
  • Ketamine increases the cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen due to its excitatory CNS effects.
  • The excitatory effects can be detected by generalised theta wave activity in EEG and petit mal seizure-like activity in the hippocampus.
  • Ketamine administration may be associated with lacrimation and salivation, which can be attenuated by premedication with an anticholinergic agent such as glycopyrrolate.

Option A: Thiopentone

  • Thiopental sodium infusions have been used to treat severe head injuries complicated by uncontrollable raised intracranial pressure.
  • It is known to help reduce intracranial pressure. Hence it is suitable in case of brain injury.

Option B: Propofol

  • Propofol protects astrocytes from oxidative stress and stimulates the protection of neurons.
  • So, propofol is a suitable option in case of traumatic brain injury.

Option D: Etomidate

  • It has been demonstrated, especially in children, that pediatric patients with severe traumatic brain injury had reductions in ICP and improved cerebral perfusion pressure with etomidate use.
  • It is a relatively good choice in case of traumatic brain injury.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child came to the emergency operation theatre for the removal of the aspirated foreign body with the aid of rigid bronchoscopy. During the removal of the foreign body, spontaneous ventilation was maintained with a smaller-sized endotracheal tube. Which among the following is the ideal anaesthetic circuit for this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Jackson rees circuit

  • Mapleson F or Jackson ree's circuit is the circuit of choice for pediatrics in both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.
  • The Jackson-Rees Circuit is commonly used in pediatric general anaesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space. The patient inhales fresh gas from the machine.
  • A reservoir bag allows Anesthesiologists to observe ventilation rates during spontaneous breathing, as well as the ability to control ventilator rates by applying pressure to the bag.

Option A: Magill's circuit

  • Mapleson A is also called the Magill circuit, the circuit of choice in adults for spontaneous ventilation.
  • It consists of a three-way T-tube connected to the fresh gas outlet, a reservoir bag, and a corrugated tube.
  • The other end of the reservoir tube is connected to the patient and a spring-loaded expiratory valve.
  • Corrugated rubber or plastic tubing: 110-130 cm in length.
  • Reservoir Bag at the Machine end.
  • APL valve at the patient end.
  • Tube volume > Tidal volume.
  • Advantages:
    • Best among all Maplesons systems for spontaneous ventilation.
    • Minimal wastage of gases during spontaneous ventilation
  • Disadvantages
    • Not efficient for controlled ventilation.
    • Wastage of gases & operation theatre pollution.
    • The expiratory valve required produces slight resistance during expiration.
    • The expiratory valve is heavy(Headbrink valve).

Option B: Mapleson D

  • Mapleson D (Bains circuit) is a circuit of choice for adults on controlled ventilation.
  • It consists of a fresh gas inlet nearer the patient end, a corrugated rubber tubing at one end, which is connected with an expiratory valve, and then a reservoir bag.
  • It is mainly used for assisted or controlled ventilation.
  • During controlled ventilation, there is little chance of rebreathing.
  • The FGF, which enters during the expiratory pause, accumulates in the patient end and is forced during the inflation. In spontaneous breathing during inspiration, the patient will inhale the fresh gas & gas in a corrugated tube depending on FGF, TV, length of expiratory pause & volume of the corrugated tube.
  • Rebreathing can be minimized by increasing FGF 2-3 times the MV.
  • For an adult, 15L/min FGF, which seems uneconomical, is required.
  • In some cases, 250 ml/kg/min is required to prevent rebreathing.

Option D: Bains circuit

  • Another name for Mapleson D is the Bains circuit.
  • It consists of a fresh gas inlet nearer the patient end, a corrugated rubber tubing at one end, which is connected with an expiratory valve, and then a reservoir bag.
  • It is mainly used for assisted or controlled ventilation.  
  • During controlled ventilation, there is little chance of rebreathing.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents in the outpatient department with a history of frequent micturition, pain while urinating and low-grade fever for five days. He has had recurrent episodes of similar symptoms for the last few years. Physical examination is normal. Which of the following should be used to visualise any congenital defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: MR urography

  • This patient is most likely suffering from a congenital urinary tract abnormality.
  • The best option for assessing pediatric urinary tract abnormalities is MR UROGRAPHY (MRU).
  • MR urography (MRU) is capable of complete urinary tract medium imaging.
  • In MR Urography, there is no need for ionizing radiation and intravenous contrast medium.
  • This is also beneficial in pregnant females and patients with renal insufficiency.
  • MRU is also very effective for imaging most pediatric lesions and anomalies.
  • MR urogram below suggests vesico ureteric reflex VUR, dilatation of ureters, and hydronephrosis.

Option A: IVP

  • Intravenous pyelography (IVP), or excretory urography (EU), is a radiographic study of the renal parenchyma, pelvicalyceal system, ureters, and the urinary bladder
  • It is an X-ray exam to outline the urinary collecting system
  • However, for assessing pediatric congenital abnormalities, an MR urogram is preferred as it is less invasive.

 

 

Option B: Xray Pelvis

  • It is an incorrect option because x ray pelvis does not help detect congenital urinary tract abnormalities

Option C: 3D CT UROGRAM

  • CT urogram is optimised for renal, ureteric and bladder examination using thin–slice, excretory-phase imaging after intravenous contrast medium administration
  • However, MR urography is superior to CT Urogram as it does not use radiation and IV contrast medium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a known case of diabetes mellitus type-2, presents to the emergency department with complaints of mild abdominal pain over the left side of the abdomen for the last 2 days. He has had a history of bloody diarrhoea for the last 5 days. On examination, abdominal tenderness is present. A plain X-ray abdomen is advised; this shows a thumbprint sign. Based on the above-given findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ischemic colitis

  • Ischemic colitis is the most likely diagnosis here.
  • Ischemic colitis is where the blood flow to the colon is temporarily reduced.
  • It may be caused due to constriction of the blood vessels supplying the colon.
  • Thumb printing: Indentation in contrast or air-filled bowel lumen caused by submucosal infiltration resembling a thumb printing, e.g., Ischemia.
  • Thumb printing is a Radiographic sign of large bowel wall thickening, usually caused by oedema, related to an infective or inflammatory process ('colitis').
  • The normal haustra thicken at regular intervals appearing like 'thumbprints' projecting into the aerated lumen.

Option A: Ulcerative colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease causing inflammation and ulcers in the digestive tract. It has a lead pipe appearance in the barium study.

Option B: Meconium ileus

  • Meconium ileus is a small intestine blockage in infants due to increased thickness of intestinal contents (meconium). It is most commonly associated with cystic fibrosis.

 Option C: Crohn's disease

  • Crohn's disease causes inflammation of the tissues in the digestive tract, mainly involving the terminal ileum and parts of the colon. A fat halo sign is seen on the CT scan.

questions.text: A full-term neonate is born by elective cesarean to a gravida II woman. Respiratory distress is reported soon after birth, for which the infant requires NICU admission. Antenatal ultrasound shows polyhydramnios, shortening of proximal limbs, and a large head. The neonate at birth had typical features of achondroplasia, like short proximal limbs, a large head, and a depressed nasal bridge. Based on perinatal history, clinical features, and investigations, a diagnosis of achondroplasia is made. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Acromelic dwarfism

  • Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder.
  • It is due to a mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR3) Gene.
  • This mutation leads to abnormal functioning of fibroblast growth factor receptors, resulting in delayed bone growth in the growth plate's cartilage.
  • It is characterized by Rhizomelic dwarfism, where the limb shortening is more pronounced in the proximal bones than the distal bones.
  • Although rhizomelic dwarfism can be found in several skeletal dysplasias, achondroplasia is the most common short-limbed dysplasia.
  • The clinical features of achondroplasia are:
    • Short stature
    • Macrocephaly (prominent forehead)
    • Shortened arms and legs.
    • Kyphosis and scoliosis
    • Middle ear deformities (recurrent infections that may lead to a hearing loss)
    • Dental anomalies (crowded or misaligned teeth).
    • Normal intelligence.
  • Radiographic features of achondroplasia include:
    • champagne glass pelvis
    • tombstone iliac bone
    • bullet-shaped vertebra

  • The above image demonstrates bowed and short bones of the legs with square lilac blades and champagne glass pelvis.
  • Acromelic dwarfism is seen in Asphyxiating thoracic dysplasia, also known as Jeune syndrome.

Option A: Tombstone iliac bone

  • Also known as Mickey Mouse ears pelvis.
  • They are used to describe the iliac wings of individuals with achondroplasia.

 

Option B: Champagne glass pelvis

  • It is a helpful sign in achondroplasia in which the flattened iliac blades give rise to a pelvic inlet that resembles a champagne glass.

Option D: Bullet-shaped vertebra

  • It is also known as the ovoid vertebra.
  • It refers to the anterior beaking of the vertebral body.
  • In addition to achondroplasia, it is also seen in mucopolysaccharidosis (Morquio disease, Hurler disease), hypothyroidism etc.

questions.text: A patient from the northeast presented with respiratory distress. An NCCT was advised, which reveals a large cystic double-walled lesion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Hydatid cyst

Ultrasound features of Hydatid Cyst:

  • Double-layered wall in univesicular cysts and a double-layered septum in cases of multivesicular cysts (wall sign)
  • Other less common include invasion of the mediastinum, pericardium, pleural, chest wall, cardiovascular system, or inferior vena

CT scan findings of hydatid cyst:

  • Generally, chest CT scan features include
  • 1-Multiple or solitary cystic lesion (most common) diameter of 1-20 cm
  • 2-Unilateral or bilateral
  • 3-Predominantly found in the lower lobes

Radiographic and CT features may differ in complicated and uncomplicated cysts.

Uncomplicated cysts: 

  • Round or oval masses with well-defined borders
  • Enhancement after contrast injection
  • Hypodense content relative to the capsule

Complicated cysts: 

  • Meniscus sign or air crescent sign
  • Cumbo sign or onion peel sign
  • Water-lily sign
  • Consolidation adjacent to the cyst (ruptured cyst)

Option A: Lung abscess

  • Presents as air-fluid levels

Option B: Lung cyst (simple)

  • A lung cyst is a gas-filled structure with a thin perceptible wall, typically <2 mm in thickness but can be up to 4 mm
  • SA simple cyst is homogenous without any solid component or septations.
  • The wall is usually thin.

Option D: Hydropneumothorax

  • Hydropneumothorax occurs when there is both air and fluid in the pleural space.
  • Diagnosis is made with a chest X-ray, preferably upright, or decubitus presence of pleural fluid alone will not result in an air-fluid level; air must also be present in the pleural space to observe an air-fluid level, which should be perfectly horizontal on an upright film

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, G3P2, presents to the labour room due to painful uterine contractions and vaginal bleeding at 35 weeks of gestation. Her blood pressure is 160/100mmHg, and her pulse is 100/min. Physical examination reveals uterine tenderness. Per vaginal examination reveals, cervical dilatation of 2cm with bright red bloody discharge. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Placental abruption

  • The patient presents with placental abruption (class 2), which occurs as a complication of pre-eclampsia.
  • Placental abruption is an obstetric emergency condition in which the placenta is detached prematurely from the uterus before delivery of the baby.
  • It can occur on its own or as a complication of pre-eclampsia.
  • Other complications of pre-eclampsia include:
  • Eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Intracranial haemorrhage
  • Maternal and fetal mortality
  • Abruptio placenta can present with concealed or visible external painful bleeding.
  • It is classified into four types according to PAGE classification of abruption, depending on the severity.

PAGE’s classification of abruption

Class 0: Asymptomatic
  • Diagnosis is made retrospectively by finding an organized blood clot or depressed area on a delivered placenta.
Class 1: Mild (48%)
  • Bleed seen only after delivery
  • No uterine tenderness
  • The fetus is alive, and fetal heart rate (FHR) is normal
Class 2: Moderate (27%)
  • Bleed seen during labour
  • Associated with uterine tetany
  • Fetal heart rate - Normal
Class 3: severe (24%)
  • Most severe
  • FHR shows distress
  • Type A- Without disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Type B - With DIC

Option A: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is an abnormal attachment of the placenta to the lower part of the uterus either at or close to the internal cervical os.
  • It presents with painless cervical bleeding and is not associated with pre-eclampsia.

Option C: Bloody show

  • Bloody show is a typical symptom during late pregnancy when the body prepares for the fetus's delivery.
  • It is a mixture of blood and mucus visible to the normal eye as bloody, brown-red, tinged discharge.
  • A bloody show occurs because the uterus is beginning to efface and dilate in preparation for labour.
  • It is not associated with pre-eclampsia

Option D: Vasa previa

  • Vasa previa occurs due to velamentous cord insertion, i.e., the vessels from the umbilical cord run through part of the chorionic membrane rather than directly into the placenta.
  • These vessels are not protected by Wharton's Jelly making vessels susceptible to bleeding with membrane damage.
  • Vasa previa causes painless bleeding, and fetal blood loss occurs. Therefore, even minute quantities of blood can lead to fetal compromise. It is not associated with pre-eclampsia.

questions.text: 40-yrs-old G3P2 obese woman with Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus presents at 37 weeks gestation. She previously had 2 normal vaginal deliveries of babies of 3.3 and 3.5 kgs. The present estimated weight of the fetus is 3 kg by ultrasonography (USG). Her most recent HbA1c was 6.0. The patient reports that her sugars are within the normal range. Which of the following is correct about the management of this patient?

choices.text: The patient should undergo an elective cesarean section at 38 weeks to avoid shoulder dystocia
The patient should be induced by 38 weeks if spontaneous labour does not occur
After 6 weeks postpartum, the patient should undergo a 75-g glucose tolerance test
In the postpartum period, it is acceptable to use oral contraceptives

questions.solution:
Option B: The patient should be induced by 38 weeks if spontaneous labour does not occur

  • Since the weight of the baby and the prenatal investigations are all in normal values.
  • Hence, a trial of labour is an adequate option. Diabetes in itself is never an indication of a cesarean section.
  • Moreover, the previous two normal deliveries of baby weights of 3.3 and 3.5 kgs indicate an adequate pelvis.
    Type of diabetes Time of delivery
    • GDM controlled on diet
    • GDM requiring medication
    • Overt diabetes (controlled)
    • Overt DM (uncontrolled)
    • 40 - 41 weeks
    • 38 - 39 weeks
    • ≥ 37 wks.( max:39 weeks)
    • 34 weeks (max 37 weeks)

     

 

 

Option A: The patient should undergo an elective cesarean section at 38 weeks to avoid shoulder dystocia

  • Elective caesarean section is not the best option in this case since the weight of the baby and the prenatal investigations are all good. 
  • Hence, a trial of labour is an adequate option. Diabetes in itself is never an indication of a cesarean section.

 

Option C: After 6 weeks postpartum, the patient should undergo a 75-g glucose tolerance test

  • A postpartum glucose tolerance test is not required in overt diabetes. 
  • A postpartum 75-g glucose tolerance test is required for gestational diabetes.

 

Option D: In the postpartum period, it is acceptable to use oral contraceptives

  • Oral contraceptive pills are not recommended in the postpartum period because the estrogen component significantly reduces breast milk production and more so in people with diabetes as they adversely affect carbohydrate metabolism

questions.text: A 38-year-old pregnant woman presents to the emergency at 20 weeks of gestation with breathlessness. She is diagnosed with severe mitral stenosis. The physician advises her on treatment and regular follow-up because of the risk of cardiac failure in late pregnancy. Which of the following is the best method to prevent cardiac failure in this patient?

choices.text: Balloon mitral valvuloplasty in the second trimester
Admit at 30 weeks to monitor and treat for failure

questions.solution:
Option B: Balloon mitral valvuloplasty in the second trimester

  • This patient has severe mitral stenosis and is at risk of cardiac failure.
  • The ideal treatment will be mitral balloon valvuloplasty in the 2nd trimester to prevent cardiac failure in the late antenatal period or during labour.
  • Balloon mitral valvuloplasty is the best treatment to prevent cardiac failure in severe mitral stenosis. The ideal time for surgery would have been the interpregnancy interval, but since the patient is already pregnant, 20 - 24 weeks is the preferable time.
  • In cases of severe mitral stenosis, surgery may be performed at any time during pregnancy in the mother’s interest.
  • Other treatment modalities include
    •  Diuretics
    •  β blockers
    •  limited physical activity.

Option A: Oral furosemide

  • Although furosemide is beneficial in this condition due to its diuretic action, it is not used routinely in pregnancy as it causes volume contraction and subsequently decreased placental perfusion to the fetus resulting in IUGR and oligohydramnios.

Option C: Oral digoxin

  • Digoxin is not indicated unless there is atrial fibrillation and systolic failure. Digoxin is used cautiously in pregnancy because of its narrow therapeutic index and serious side effects.

Option D: Admit at 30 weeks to monitor and treat for failure

  • The patient has an impending cardiac failure in pregnancy. She should be managed prophylactically to prevent cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with G2P1 presents to the antenatal clinic at the 20th week of gestation with a complaint of white discharge from the vagina, not associated with pain or itching. On examination, the discharge is whitish, homogenous and associated with a fishy odour. A microscopic examination shows clue cells. Which of the following is the best drug to use to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Metronidazole

  • Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis, a gram variable rod. It presents a non-painful, non-itchy, thin grey vaginal discharge with a fishy smell. It is due to the overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria in the vagina due to decreased lactobacilli.
  • On microscopy of the vaginal discharge, clue cells are seen, which are vaginal epithelial cells coated with Gardnerella and have stippled appearance along the outer margins.
  • Adding 10% KOH to the vaginal secretions releases an amine-like fishy odour (amine whiff test).
  • Amsel's criteria are used for diagnosis. If 3 out of the following 4 are present, the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is confirmed:
  1. Homogenous, non-clumping, grey-white vaginal discharge.
  2. Positive amine whiff test.
  3. Presence of greater than 20% clue cells/HPF on wet mount microscopy.
  4. Vaginal pH >4.5
  • Treatment of bacterial vaginosis includes metronidazole. It is not a sexually transmitted disease, so only the affected woman must be treated.
  • Metronidazole works by forming toxic free radical metabolites in the bacterial cell that damage DNA. It treats Giardia, Entamoeba, Trichomonas, Gardnerella vaginalis, and anaerobes (Bacteroides, Clostridium difficile). Adverse effects include disulfiram-like reactions with alcohol, headache and a metallic taste in the mouth.
  • Although no drug is considered completely safe in the first trimester of pregnancy, there is relative safety in using class 'B' drugs during pregnancy. Metronidazole comes under this class where the drug is safe in animal studies and most human studies.
  • If given a choice in the first trimester, it is wise to use an absolute safe agent like betadine vaginal pessary, which will buy time until the patient is in the second trimester for safe usage of category B or even C drugs.

 

Option A: Clindamycin

  • It is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that blocks translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit in bacteria.
  • It treats anaerobic lung infections such as aspiration pneumonia, lung abscess and oral infections.
  • It is not used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

Option C: Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.
  • It can be used to treat atypical pneumonia(mycoplasma, chlamydia, legionella), sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia, and bordetella pertussis.

Option D: Rovamycin

  • It is a macrolide antibiotic and is effective against gram-positive aerobic pathogens, N. gonorrhoeae, and staphylococci.
  • It is not used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old diabetic woman, G2P1, at 34 weeks of gestation, comes to the outpatient department complaining of less fetal activities. She is on regular antenatal check-ups and takes iron and calcium pills regularly.  She is nonalcoholic but smokes cigarettes occasionally, which she quit after getting pregnant. Past medical history includes hypertension for 3 years. Her ultrasound suggests fetal parameters corresponding to 29 weeks gestation. Which of the following may not be the cause for her presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Maternal Diabetes

  • This presentation with fetal growth lag of > 2 weeks in ultrasound suggests intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR).
  • In maternal diabetes, fetal macrosomia is common.
  • IUGR, if at all, is seen in neglected 'Burnt out' kind of diabetes with microangiopathy and is the last association that should come to mind with diabetes in pregnancy.

IUGR:

  • Also called fetal growth restriction (FGR).
  • Fetuses with estimated weight below the 10th percentile for their gestational ages or birth weight below 2500g at term are considered FGR babies.

Causes of IUGR:

  • Idiopathic (65%).
  • Maternal causes:
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • HTN
  • Infections
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Heart disease (NYHA type III & IV)
  • Smoking
  • Drugs
  • Alcohol
  • Burnt out DM (with Microangiopathy/ Vasculopathy)
  • Placental causes:
  • Placental infarcts
  • Abnormal placentas
  • Abnormal placentation
  • Fetal Causes:
  • Inborn Errors of metabolism
  • Chromosomal anomalies
  • Infections

Option B: Hypertensive disorder

  • Maternal hypertension is a cause of the IUGR of the baby.

Option C: Placental infracts

  • Placental infarction compromises the blood supply to the fetus and thereby causes IUGR.

Option D: In utero infection

  • IUGR can be caused by in utero infection of the fetus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female at 8 weeks of pregnancy presents to the OPD with complaints of excessive vomiting, nausea, and inability to tolerate orally. She also says that there is a decreased frequency of urination. Lab reports show hypochloremic alkalosis. What can be done to manage this patient?

choices.text: Administer intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalance

questions.solution:
Option B: Admit IV fluids, IV anti emetics, Input/ Output charting

  • Hyperemesis gravidum presents with excessive vomiting, inability to take food orally, and ketonuria.
  • The patient is a case of hyperemesis gravidarum with severe dehydration that has led to oliguria and is also unable to tolerate anything orally. As the patient is not taking anything orally, so her fluid requirement cannot be met by oral fluids.
  • Therefore patient needs hospitalization for IV fluid therapy and input-output charting till her urine output and other signs of dehydration improve. If left untreated; hyperemesis gravidum can progress toward Wernicke's encephalopathy, ketoacidosis, and renal failure.

Management of Hyperemesis gravidarum:

  • IV Hydration:
    • Normal saline
    • Ringer lactate
    • Dextrose (Serum/Urine Ketones to be monitored)]
  • Antiemetics:
    • IV Promethazine (Phenergan)
    • IV Prochlorperazine
    • IV Ondansetron
    • IV Metoclopramide
  • Add 100 mg of Thiamine
  • Monitor hydration status, urine output, urine/serum ketones, electrolytes, liver, and renal functions
  • Refractory cases: IV hydrocortisone
  • Termination of pregnancy may be rarely required when all else fails.

Option A: Pyridoxine + Doxylamine with plenty of oral fluids

  • The patient with hyperemesis gravidum has a deficiency of Vitamin B1 and is unable to take anything orally, so pyridoxine ( Vitamin B6) and oral fluids can not be given.

Option C: Inj Hydrocortisone

  • Hydrocortisone is indicated only in refractory cases

Option D: Inj Phenargan

  • It can sort some relief in nausea and vomiting but does not correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravidity 2, presents with vaginal bleeding after 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy test. What is the most probable cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Genetic factors

  • The most common cause of first-trimester abortions is genetic/ chromosomal defects.
  • Common Causes of abortion in the first trimester:

          1. Genetic factors (50%): Commonest cause. The most common genetic cause is trisomy.

        2. Endocrine disorders (Luteal phase defect, Thyroid abnormalities, and diabetes)

        3. Immunological disorders (Autoimmune and Alloimmune)

        4. Infection (TORCH group)

        5. Unexplained

Option B: Endocrine disorders

  • Endocrine abnormalities are a common cause of first-trimester abortions.
  • These include luteal phase defects, thyroid abnormalities, and uncontrolled diabetes.
  • However, these are much less common causes of first-trimester abortions than genetic and chromosomal defects.

Option C: Immunological disorders

  • Immunological abnormalities are a common cause of first-trimester abortions.
  • These may be autoimmune or alloimmune causes.
  • However, these are much less common causes of first trimester abortions than genetic and chromosomal defects

Option D: Infections

  • Infections are a common cause of first-trimester abortions
  • These include TORCH infections.
  • However, these are much less common causes of first-trimester abortions than genetic and chromosomal defects.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman at 32 weeks of pregnancy presents with labour pains. On examination, her cervix is dilated 2 cm, and one uterine contraction is felt every 5 to 7 minutes. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Isoxsuprine hydrochloride

The patient here is in early preterm labour. The diagnostic criteria of preterm labour include:

  • Uterine contraction should be
    • 4 times in 20 minutes
    • 8 times in an hour
  • On per vaginal examination, the cervix should be
    • ≥1 cm dilated
    • 80% effaced
    • Short cervix
    • < 2.5 cm (Y-shaped)
  • Isoxsuprine hydrochloride is a β agonist which acts as a tocolytic by reducing intracellular ionized calcium levels and preventing the activation of myometrial contractile proteins. The patient should also be given steroid cover for fetal lung maturity.
  • Tocolytics can be used in patients of early preterm labour presenting at less than 34 weeks to cause a delay in delivery for up to 48 hours, allowing transport of the mother with fetus in utero to a centre with a higher level of neonatal care and permitting time for corticosteroid to act.

 

Option B: Wait and watch

  • This patient needs to be managed actively as the cervix is dilated ≥1 cm and has more than 8 uterine contractions in an hour. This patient should be administered maternal steroids and isoxsuprine hydrochloride to allow time for the corticosteroid to act.

Option C: Augmentation of labour

  • The patient is already in preterm labour, and the contraction should be suppressed, and labour should be delayed instead of augmentation using tocolytics.

Option D: Emergency LSCS

  • There is no need for an emergency caesarian section as contractions are adequate, and the labour is progressing normally. Tocolytics should delay the labour to allow time for maternal steroids to act.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the gynaecologist with complaints of being unable to conceive for 2 years. She is diagnosed to have anovulatory cycles. She is started on a drug that acts by antagonizing estrogenic negative feedback on the hypothalamus. She is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is true about the drug involved in a patient's pathology?

choices.text: Significantly increases sperm counts in oligospermic men
1 – 2% increase in the rate of twin pregnancy

questions.solution:
Option A: Increases production of FSH

  • This is a case of anovulatory cycles.
  • Clomiphene citrate is used to cause ovulation
    • Trans enclomiphene 62%: anti-estrogenic
    • Cis zuclomiphene citrate 38%: mildly estrogenic
  • This primarily acts at the receptor in the hypothalamus rather than the ovarian and pituitary axis. Blockade increases the stimulus to the pituitary to produce more FSH.
  • Antagonises the beneficial actions of estrogens on the endometrium, and hence a supplementation of estrogen is required in patients on higher doses of clomiphene for ovulation induction
  • 6-12% increase in the rate of twins
  • Oligospermia relief is not the best benefit of clomiphene…statistically because roughly 10-15% only are benefited from this in oligospermia reversal.

Option B: Increases endometrial thickness

  • It doesn't play any role in increasing the endometrial thickness because it antagonizes the action of estrogens on the endometrium and causes endometrial thinning instead.

Option C: Significantly increases sperm counts in oligospermic men

  • It is ineffective in oligospermic men because only 10 to 15 % of patients benefit from this drug in oligospermic reversal.

Option D: 1-2% increase in the rate of twin pregnancy

  • It has a 6 to 12% increase in the twin pregnancy rate.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 33 weeks of pregnancy with complaints of swelling in bilateral feet. She states that the swelling is worst at the end of the day and subsides by morning. Her BP is 120/74 mmHg, and cardiac examination shows normal S1 and S2. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bed rest with feet elevation
Physiological oedema of pregnancy:

  • The cause of physiological oedema is due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac vein Oedema disappears on rest with foot end elevation
  • BP should be checked to rule out pre-eclampsia
  • Salt restriction, diuretics and fluid restriction have no role in the management of physiological oedema
  • Diuretics and fluid restriction may be offered to patients having oedema secondary to heart disease to reduce preload.

Option A: Salt restriction

  • Salt restriction will lead to a decrease in hydrostatic pressure within the vessel.
  • However, the main mechanism of oedema of physiology is venous stasis.

Option C: 2D echocardiography

  • This is recommended in suspected heart failure.
  • In such cases, dyspnea, orthopnea, and raised JVP will be present.

Option D: Diuretics

  • A volume overload states such as cirrhosis and heart failure leads to oedema.
  • In such cases, diuretic therapy is indicated.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents at 7 weeks of gestation for an ultrasound evaluation. There is a single live intrauterine pregnancy of 7 weeks, adnexa is normal, and the uterus is retroverted. At what gestation may this patient start to experience urinary retention?
questions.solution:
Option C: 12-16

  • The retroverted gravid uterus is because of:
  • Previously retroverted uterus due to poor support
  • Previous pelvic adhesions
  • Tumours on the posterior wall of the uterus
  • Incarceration of the uterus in the pelvis is due to an unusually deep sacral concavity with an overhanging sacral promontory
  • Most of the time, the uterus comes out of the pelvis at 12 weeks, and there is relief from the symptoms
  • Worst case scenario is the incarceration of the uterus in the pelvis: Invariably presents at 14th weeks.

 

 

Option A: 28-32

  • At 28-32 weeks, the uterus is no longer in the pelvis. Hence, the urinary retention symptoms do not occur

   Option B: 20-24

  • The urinary retention symptoms due to retroverted uterus occur in 12-16 weeks, not 20-24 weeks.

   Option D: 8-10

  • At 8-10 weeks, the uterus is small and does not put any pressure on the urinary bladder

questions.text: A 34-years-old woman presents to the Gynaecology OPD with failure to conceive after trying for the last 3 years. She has been married for 3 and a half years. On vaginal examination, there is a nodular, tender uterosacral ligament, a retroverted but normal-sized uterus, and a right adnexal mass. A recent pelvic ultrasound reveals a 6-cm right complex ovarian mass. Her CA-125 is mildly elevated. What is the initial next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option C: Laparoscopy with cystectomy

  • The most likely diagnosis here is an endometrioma of the right ovary.
  • Because this patient has been attempting to get pregnant, conservative surgery to remove the endometrioma while preserving ovarian tissue and ablate any endometriotic implants may improve her chances. CA-125 can be elevated with endometriosis and is not specific to ovarian cancer alone.

Option A: GnRH agonist

  • Medical therapy with a GnRH agonist may treat her symptoms, but it will not help her get pregnant
  • Cystectomy can be immediately followed up with planning a pregnancy, while GnRH causes prolonged amenorrhea, and resumption of fertility after stopping the drug may take a few months.

 

Option B: Diagnostic Hysterosalpingography

  • A hysterosalpingography is used to diagnose intrauterine or tubal factors of infertility here since the cause of infertility is already known, and the cyst is easily treated with a cystectomy.

 

Option D: Laparoscopy and right oophorectomy

  • Laparoscopic oophorectomy is unnecessary in a case of infertility with a benign ovarian pathology for which a cystectomy can be done

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complained of excessive hair growth on her face, upper arms, and back for the past year. She mentions that her hair growth has rapidly increased over the past few months, and she also complains of hoarseness in her voice. Her abdominal ultrasound reveals an ovarian tumor. Which type of tumor is the most likely?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor

  • This patient is showing signs of virilization of rapid progression; such changes are seen with masculinizing ovarian tumors such as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors or Arrhenoblastomas.
  • Ovarian tumors which produce male sex hormones are called virilizing tumors.
  • These tumors occur commonly in the third and fourth decades of life. They are rare tumors. They secrete androgens and cause defeminization followed by masculinization.
  • Virilization: Permanent changes
    • Hoarseness
    • Breast atrophy
    • Clitoromegaly
    • Oligomenorrhea to amenorrhea
    • Benign
    • Rapid onset hirsutism
  • Conservative surgery is the appropriate treatment for young females with Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors. The patient might need adjuvant chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin with poor prognostic factors.

Option A: Granulosa cell tumors

  • These functional ovarian tumors produce estrogen and are associated with precocious puberty, menorrhagia, endometrial hyperplasia, and cancer. So, it is not a true statement.

Option C: Immature teratoma

  • Immature teratoma or benign cystic teratoma is 90% of all teratomas. These are usually present as pelvic masses in women in their second or third decade of life and may also, at times, present with torsion. There are no virilization changes associated with teratoma.

Option D: Polycystic ovarian disease

  • A woman with PCOD may present with similar complaints of excessive hair growth. However, such rapid onset and progression changes must always warrant evaluation for a masculinizing ovarian tumor. Since there is also an ovarian tumor in radiology, a Sertoli cell tumor is most likely. Hence, it is a false option.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman in menopause complains of labia majora itching for 4 years. Topical medication has not helped much. She has started feeling soreness in the same area recently and washing has become uncomfortable. Examination reveals a hard lesion on the right labia with positive inguinal nodes. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid and follow up for lymph node status

questions.solution:
Option D: Biopsy

  • Intractable itching in the post-menopausal age group with indurated lesions with inguinal lymph nodes appears to be a case of vulvar carcinoma
  • In case of suspicion of vulvar carcinoma, a biopsy of the lesion is the most suitable choice
  • A CT scan or PET scan can also be done in case of positive inguinal nodes to visualize tumour size and spread.

 

Option A: Topical beclomethasone

  • It is a topical steroid. It can only decrease inflammation.
  • It can’t stop or reduce cancerous growth and hence will be of no benefit to the patient.

 

Option B: Topical estrogen with antibiotic

  • Topical estrogen is not helpful in malignant conditions.
  • Antibiotic is beneficial in case of infection. However, since there is inguinal lymphadenopathy in a woman of advanced age with all symptoms suggestive of malignancy, we will consider it a cancerous lesion.

 

Option C: Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid and follow-up for lymph node status

  • This could be a possible treatment if the patient was young and sexually active suspecting infection or STDs.
  • However, the patient is old, and she has had symptoms for over 4 years, which makes her a more suitable case of vulvar carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presenting to OPD with postmenopausal bleeding for 3 months has a 1 x1cm nodule on the anterior lip of the cervix. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to be done subsequently?
questions.solution:
Option B : This woman has presented with postmenopausal bleeding. Post menopausal bleeding with a visible cervical growth needs a tissue diagnosis, done by a punch biopsy of the lesion.

Presentation of cervical cancer

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding : post coital bleeding (most common presentation), post menopausal bleeding
  • Foul smelling vaginal discharge
  • Cancer cachexia
  • Cancer pain
