  • Pyometra : causing dirty vaginal discharge
  • Uremic symptoms : decreasing urine output, non specific symptoms like lethargy, muscular weakness, shallow respiration, mental confusion

Option A: Pap smear is a screening test, done in asymptomatic patients.

Option C : Endocervical curettage is indicated in patients with suspected endocervical lesion, or if entire transformation zone could not be evaluated at colposcopy

Option D : Colposcopy + Biopsy is a diagnostic test, indicated in symptomatic patients, like those with postmenopausal or post coital bleeding, or in asymptomatic patients where pap screening was done and turned out abnormal

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman G3P2 at 34 weeks of pregnancy presents with pain in the abdomen, uterine tenderness and mild bleeding per-vaginum. Her vitals are BP 110/70, pulse 89/min and respiratory rate 18/minute. Fetal cardiac tocography (CTG) shows regular fetal heart tracing of 140bpm and no recurrent or late deacceleration. Which of the following steps is not indicated as part of the management of the underlying cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided in the scenario, the option that is NOT indicated as part of the management of the underlying cause in this patient is:

  1. Amniotomy/prostaglandins to induce labor.

Explanation of the options:

  1. Amniotomy/prostaglandins to induce labor: This option is not indicated because the patient is only 34 weeks pregnant and is presenting with abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and mild bleeding per vaginum. These symptoms suggest a potential complication of preterm labor. In this scenario, it is essential to try to prevent or delay labor rather than induce labor. Inducing labor would not be appropriate as the patient is not at term yet and the baby is premature.

  2. Arrange for blood products: This option may be indicated if the patient is experiencing significant bleeding and shows signs of hemorrhage or a severe drop in hemoglobin levels. Blood products such as packed red blood cells or fresh frozen plasma may be needed to manage the patient's condition if bleeding is severe.

  3. Intravenous crystalloids and colloids: This option is indicated to support the patient's fluid balance and maintain adequate hydration, especially if she is experiencing bleeding or shows signs of dehydration. Intravenous fluids (crystalloids and colloids) can help stabilize the patient's hemodynamics.

  4. Tocolysis to arrest labor: Tocolysis is the use of medications to suppress uterine contractions and delay labor. In the case of preterm labor, tocolytic agents may be used to try to halt or delay labor and give time for corticosteroids to be administered to improve fetal lung maturity. Tocolysis can be an appropriate intervention to manage preterm labor and give the baby the best chance for better outcomes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida has regular pre-natal follow-ups during her pregnancy. The fetus on serial growth ultrasound scans and antenatal doppler suggests a normally growing fetus with no signs of hypoxia. Which of the following are normal trends in fetal hematopoiesis during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rise in Hemoglobin content

Fetal hematopoiesis:

  • Hematopoietic tissue is derived from the mesenchymal layer of the embryo.
  • The earliest evidence of haematopoiesis is seen in the blood islands of the yolk sac at 2-3 weeks of gestation.
  • At 5 weeks gestation, haematopoiesis starts in the liver. The liver is the chief site of blood cell production until the 6th fetal month. The liver continues to produce hemic cells until 2 weeks after birth.
  • Spleen, lymph nodes, and thymus are also sites of hematopoiesis during fetal life.
  • Bone marrow is the site for hematopoiesis at 4-5th fetal month. By the sixth month, the bone marrow becomes the chief focus of blood cell production.
  • The earliest haemoglobins detected are Gower and Portland. They disappear by the third month.
  •  Hb F (α2ϒ2), the predominant Hb after the 8th gestational week, rises to 90% of the total Hb by 6 months of gestation. Hb F gradually declines to 70% by the end of term gestation and continues to fall postnatally to adult levels (≤ 2%) by 12 months of age.
  • Hb A (α2β2) is the predominant adult haemoglobin. It appears in small amounts early in gestation and rises to 30% of the total haemoglobin at term and 95% by 1 year.

  • The other adult haemoglobin, HbA2 (α2δ2), reaches the normal adult level of 2%-3.4% by 1 year of age.
  • At birth, haematopoiesis is present in most bones, especially in the bone marrow of long bones. With increasing age, active marrow gradually reduces from the distal portions of the skeleton.

Option A: Rise in MCV

  • The first fetal erythrocytes are nucleated and macrocytic.
  •  MCV is 180 fL and normally decreases to 105 to 115 fL.

Option B: Rise in reticulocyte count

  • The reticulocyte count decreases to about 4 to 5 % at term.
  • It drops to 0.5-2.0% within two weeks post-delivery.

Option D: Decrease in blood volume

  • As the fetus grows, the blood volume in fetoplacental circulation increases.
  • The fetal haemoglobin concentration increases from 12 gm/dL in mid-pregnancy to 18 gm/dL at term.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is admitted with labor pains. On electronic fetal monitoring, the heart rate appears to be 170-180 beats per minute for a sustained period of 15 minutes. Which of the following is the most common explanation for such a finding?
questions.solution:
Option B: Maternal fever from amnionitis

 

This is a case of fetal tachycardia which is defined as a baseline heart rate greater than 160 bpm (Normal heart rate baseline should lie between 110-160 bpm). Acceleration is defined as an increase in heart rate from a baseline of more than 15bpm for more than 15 seconds.

The most common explanation for fetal tachycardia is maternal fever from chorioamnionitis, although fever from any source can increase baseline fetal heart rate.

Other causes of fetal tachycardia include

  • Fetal compromise (distress, meconium )
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Maternal administration of parasympathetic(atropine) or sympathomimetic (terbutaline) drugs.

Amnionitis:

  • Amnionitis is an infection of the uterus, the amniotic sac, and the fetus in some cases.
  • It is also known as intra-amniotic infection or chorioamnionitis.
  • Amnionitis is a rare condition and mostly occurs during a full-term pregnancy.
  • It is caused by bacteria commonly found in the vagina.
  • symptoms of amnionitis include-
  • Abdominal tenderness.
  • Flu-like symptoms.
  • Purulent vaginal drainage
  • Increased maternal heart rate.
  • Increased fetal heart rate.

 

Option A: Normal baseline

  • Normal fetal heart rate baseline lies between 110-160 bpm.

Option C: Normal heart rate acceleration

  • Acceleration is an increase in heart rate from a baseline of more than 15 bpm for more than 15 seconds which drops down back to the baseline in less than 2  mins

Option D: Cardiac arrhythmias

  • Fetal arrhythmia is defined as an irregularity of the cardiac rhythm, as an abnormally slow (<100 bpm) or fast (>180 bpm) heart rate, or as a combination of irregular rhythm and abnormal heart rate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the fertility clinic. She has been married for 3 years and is unable to conceive. She is otherwise healthy but has delayed menstrual cycles. An ultrasound for follicle monitoring shows the absence of a developing follicle with evidence of polycystic ovaries. Which drug should be used in the first line in her next cycle for her condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Letrozole

  • It is the drug of choice for induction of ovulation in a case of PCOS.
  • Mode of action:
  • Aromatase Inhibitor
  • Decrease estrogen production-->inhibit negative feedback on FSH --> increases FSH --> increase stimulation of follicles
  • Letrozole is preferred over clomiphene citrate because:
  • Decreases chances of multifetal pregnancy
  • Increased live birth rate
  • OHSS: Rare with it
  • Given for 5 days (D5-D9)
  • Start with 2.5mg
  • Max dose 7.5mg

Option A: Clomiphene citrate

  • Clomiphene citrate has been the most used drug for ovulation induction for PCOD patients with anovulation for other reasons.
  • However, it has now been replaced by letrozole as the drug of choice.
  • Clomiphene citrate:
  • Causes ovulation in 80% of cases and pregnancy in 40% of cases.
  • Excess estrogens in PCOD give negative feedback, which causes low FSH. This leads to less follicle development.
  • Clomiphene citrate is a hypothalamic E receptor blocker that causes high FSH, leading to follicle development.
  • Given on days 2-6 in doses of 50 mg-250 mg.
  • Combine with follicular monitoring.
  • Side effects: vasomotor flushing, headache, visual scotomas.
  • Incidence of twinning: 8-10 %.
  • It can cause mild-moderate OHSS and ovarian cysts.

Option B: GnRH agonist

  • GnRH agonists are not the first line for ovulation induction in PCOD

Option C: Combined oral Pills

  • COCs inhibit ovulation.
  • In some cases, these can be used for pretreatment before ovulation induction, which improves success in resistant cases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with leakage of urine for the last 3 months. She has been married for 14 years and is multiparous with 4 children. Her urodynamic studies suggest stress incontinence, demonstrating urine leakage only when she is asked to cough or do a Valsalva manoeuvre. She was advised some pelvic floor exercises, but she was not relieved. Which of the following surgeries may be helpful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kelly's stitch

  • Stress incontinence is the involuntary loss of urine when intravesical pressure exceeds the maximum urethral pressure with increased abdominal pressure.
  • Treatment of stress incontinence includes:
    • Conservative management:
      • Pelvic floor muscle training.
      • Biofeedback therapy.
      • Drugs.
      • Para urethral implants.
    • Surgical Management.
      • Kelly's plication (Kelly's stitch)— Features of Kelly’s plication are shown in the figure below:

 

1. Kelly operation 1914 

  • It consists. of repair of cystocele and/or urethrocele.
  • Vertical mattress sutures are then placed to plicate the whole urethra and bladder neck
  • This gives support to the urethra and restores the normal posterior urethrovesical angle.
  • Operation is done for mild and moderate cases of stress incontinence.
  • Long term success rate is 55-65%. 

 

      • Bursch colposuspension.
      • MMK procedure.
      • Transvaginal sling.
      • Trans obturator sling.
      • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck.

Option B: Le Fort

  • It is a surgery for vaginal prolapse for older women unfit for a vaginal hysterectomy.

Option C: Manchester

  • It is a conservative uterine surgery for prolapse, not for treating stress incontinence.

Option D: Posterior colporrhaphy

  • It is done along with vaginal hysterectomy for posterior compartment tightening. It has no role in the correction of stress incontinence.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her parents, who are worried about their daughter's growth. They mention that her shoe size has not changed for the last 1.5 years. On examination by the physician, he notices a low hairline and a short and wide neck. Her arms are also turned out slightly at the elbows. He finds that her nails are spoon-shaped and small. He orders an investigation to rule out the causes of proportionate short stature. Which of the following condition is most probably the cause of her short stature?
questions.solution:
Option A: Turner Syndrome

  • It is characterized by the X chromosome's monosomy and a characteristic phenotype (45XO).
    • Webbed neck
    • Hallmark – Congenital dorsal
    • Lymphedema of hands and feet
    • Shield-like chest with widely spaced hypoplastic nipples
    • Renal abnormalities 60% → Horseshoe kidney > Renal pelvic abnormalities
    • Streak ovary
    • Lymphedema
    • Short stature

Option B: Edward’s syndrome

  • It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by an extra copy of chromosome no. 18, known as trisomy 18.
  • It causes physical growth delays during fetal development.
  • It is characterized by the following features:
    • Intellectual disability
    • Hypotonia
    • Rocker-bottom feet
    • Micrognathia
    • Clenched hand
    • Overlapping fingers or clubfeet

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta

  • Osteogenesis imperfect is a genetic disorder characterized by soft bones that fracture easily.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is one of the causes of disproportionate short stature, where the limbs are mainly involved, as compared to the trunk.
  • Most commonly caused by mutation of the COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes.
  • There are 12 types of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Both types I and IV are further divided into A and B subtypes depending on the absence (A) or presence (B) of dentigerous imperfecta.
  • M/C mode of inheritance in osteogenesis imperfecta-TYPE I to IV is autosomal dominant.

Option D: Chronic kidney disease

  • In this condition, the level of phosphate and calcium is raised, the amount of creatinine in the body is also raised, and erythropoietin secretion is decreased, resulting in anaemia.
  • ​​​​​​​It is a condition in which the kidneys are failed to filter excess fluid and waste from the blood.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old male child presents to the paediatrician with fever, vomiting, frequent bed-wetting, and constipation from the last 2 weeks. Upon examination, delayed growth and decreased energy is observed in the patient. His parents are very concerned about his growth. His blood test is sent for evaluation. Which of the following is the diagnosis of this patient?


	
		
			Na+
			154
		
		
			K+
			4.5
		
		
			HCO3
			22
		
		
			Osmolality
			295
		
		
			Urea
			50
		
		
			Urine specific gravity
			1.005
questions.solution:
Option A: Diabetes insipidus

  • In this case, a male child presents with fever, vomiting, frequent bed-wetting, and constipation from the last 2 weeks. Delayed growth and decreased energy are observed upon examination. His lab test show (in meq/L) Na+ – 154, K+ – 4.5, HCO3– 22, S. Osmolality – 295, B. Urea – 50, Urine specific gravity – 1.005. The scenario, in this case, indicates that the patient has diabetes insipidus.
  • The child is presented with polyuria, polydipsia, hypernatremia, raised S. osmolality, raised blood B. urea, normal K+ and HCO3-. These are the features of diabetes insipidus.
  • DI is a disorder of water reabsorption caused by resistance to the action of ADH on its receptor. Hence absorption of water in the distal tubules and collecting ducts is significantly impaired.
  • Hypernatremia with low urine sodium is characteristic, serum chloride and serum osmolality are high, and urine osmolality is low.

Option B: Renal tubular acidosis

  • It is a condition in which the kidney does not remove acid from the blood into the urine as normally it should. In return, it increases the acid level, which is called acidosis.
  • It can present with kidney stones, fast breathing, tiredness, and muscle weakness. It presents as acidosis (low bicarbonate), B. urea is normal, and nephrocalcinosis.

Option C: Bartter's syndrome

  • Bartter's syndrome is a rare disease which causes an abnormality in the function of the kidney. It is characterised by an excess of calcium and a defect in the ability to reabsorb sodium.
  • The patient with Bartters syndrome presents fatigue, cramping, polydipsia, and polyuria in this condition. It shows hypokalemia, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hypercalciuria, and hyponatremia.

Option D: Reccurent UTI

  • If there are 2 episodes of urinary tract infection in the last 6 months or 3 episodes in a year, it indicates a recurrent UTI.
  • It can be due to poor hygiene, stones, or an inherited risk of bladder infection. The patient presents a history of fever, burning or crying while micturition, and pus cells on urine examination.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child presents to the hospital with complaints of fever, vomiting and alteration of sensorium from the last 2 weeks. Also, have a history of night wets and chills for 4 weeks. A CT brain is done, which reveals basal exudates and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely etiological agent in the condition mentioned in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mycobacterium tuberculosis

  • History suggests the diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis is caused by mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It is one of the most severe forms of TB.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • Primary infection → bacillemia → seeding of meninges (Rich's Foci) → rupture →tubercular meningitis.
  • Clinical features:
  • Stages:
      • Prodromal stage (fever, anorexia, vomiting, irritability)
      • Focal deficits, seizures, meningeal signs
      • Coma, neurological sequelae

 

  • Investigations:
  • CNS imaging (CT Head)
      • Basal exudates

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Image showing basal exudates

  • Hydrocephalus
  • Tuberculoma with perilesional edema
  • CSF study:
  • Opening pressure elevate
  • Cell count → 500/mm3 (lymphocytic predominance).
  • Elevated proteins & low glucose
  • Cob-web coagulum
  • Diagnosis is confirmed if CSF culture / PCR is +ve for mycobacterium tuberculosis / acid-fast bacilli

Treatment – ATT + Steroids

Option B: Cryptococcus neoformans

  • The obligate aerobe cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that can live in both plants and mammals.
  • It is a member of the tremellomycetes class.
  • A filamentous fungus known as filobasidiella neoformans is its teleomorph. It frequently appears in bird faeces in its yeast stage.

Option C: Listeria monocytogenes

  • Listeria monocytogenes (L. monocytogenes) is a pathogenic (disease-causing) bacterium found in wet areas, soil, water, rotting plants and animals. It even thrives when exposed to refrigeration and other food preservation techniques.

Option D: Streptococcus pneumonia

  • More than 100 recognized serotypes of the lancet-shaped, gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic bacteria known as streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • However, just a small number of S. pneumoniae serotypes are responsible for most pneumococcal infections

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presented to a local subcenter with a 4-day history of fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. The child has a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, and a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). On auscultation, there are crackles in the right lower lung zone. The oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The child appears lethargic but is still responsive to verbal stimuli. The parents report that the child has had no prior illnesses of note and is up to date with vaccinations. A complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 15,000/µL, with 70% neutrophils. A chest X-ray indicates an area of consolidation in the right lower lobe. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child's condition?

choices.text: IV antibiotics at PHC and observe
Give the first dose of IV antibiotics & refer to a higher centre
Oral amoxicillin for 5 days and send home

questions.solution:
Option C: Oral amoxicillin for 5 days and send home

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of pneumonia with a Respiratory rate is >40/min for 18 months of age. Treatment would be Oral Amoxicillin for 5 days and sent home with follow-up in 5 days.

Pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia is a lung infection which causes air sacs to fill up with pus or fluid and causes fever and cough.
  • Pneumonia can be classified anatomically as lobar Pneumonia, interstitial Pneumonia or bronchopneumonia.
  • Onset may be insidious, causing upper respiratory tract infection or acute with high-grade fever, tachypnea, dyspnea and grunting respiration.
  • Flaring of alae nasi and retractions of lower chest and intercostal spaces may also be present.
  • Physical examination findings: impaired percussion note, decreased air entry, crepitations and bronchial breathing over areas of consolidation.
  • Diagnosis is made on clinical features, findings of lobar consolidation on chest x-ray and leukocytosis.
  • Bacteriological confirmation can be done with gram staining and culture of sputum.
  • Treatment of pneumonia depends on the severity of the symptoms.
  • As in the above case, no danger signs are present, so the patient can be discharged with oral antibiotics and follow up after 5 days.

Option A: IV antibiotics at PHC and observe

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends intravenous antibiotics for five days as first‐line treatment for children with severe pneumonia.
  • In the above case, pneumonia is classified as non-severe pneumonia as no danger signs are present yet. So the patient can be given oral medications.

Option B: Give the first dose of IV antibiotics & refer to a higher centre

  • No need for IV medications for the mentioned sign and symptoms.
  • This patient can be managed at the Primary health centre if no danger signs are present.

Option D: Home remedies

  • Treatment includes symptomatic management and a short course of antibiotics.

questions.text:
A newborn in a maternity hospital develops feeding difficulties and cyanosis during feeding. Physical examination reveals excessive salivation, coughing, and choking spells during feeding attempts. Medical records show that the mother of the affected baby reported experiencing polyhydramnios during her pregnancy. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach was unsuccessful, and an abnormality is noted as shown in the chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula

  • Chest X­ ray showing a feeding tube coiled in the upper oesophagus with no gases in bowel loops in a newborn with frothing, excessive drooling & coughing with feeds, with a history of antenatal polyhydramnios suggests a diagnosis of Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (EA with TEF)
  • This is characterised by the blind oesophagal pouch and a connection between the trachea and the oesophagus. It usually presents copious secretions, cyanosis, and choking in the first hour of life.

Classification of TEF

  • Type A: Atresia only (60%)
  • Type B: Atresia with proximal TEF (2%)
  • Type C: Atresia with distal TEF (85%): most common
  • Type D: Atresia with proximal and distal TEF (rare)
  • Type E: Isolated TEF (H-type) (1%)

Management

  • Stop feeding, give intravenous fluids
  • Start nasogastric suctioning.
  • Definitive treatment- surgical correction

Option A. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)

  • In congenital diaphragmatic hernia, the chest x-ray will reveal a loop of small bowel in the chest and collapsed lung on the side of intestinal herniation.
  • But this patient’s X-ray doesn’t show any bowel loops in the thorax, so CDH is ruled out.

Option B. Bilateral choanal atresia

  • Neonates with bilateral choanal atresia develop cyanosis when feeding. This becomes evident when feeding because the mouth is used for respiration instead of the nose. When the nasogastric tube is passed, the tube will be present in the nose and won't be seen in the oesophagus, in contrast to what is seen in this patient.

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

  • Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis present with projectile non-bilious vomiting and palpable olive-shaped abdominal mass. This patient’s clinical presentation is not consistent with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Moreover, the nasogastric tube will reach the stomach in these patients, which is not the case here.

questions.text: A boy aged 8 years presented at the hospital with complaints of significant pallor, exhaustion, and subconjunctival bleeding. Upon examination, enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes were noted. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, leading to a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Among the following options, which is considered a good prognostic factor?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hyperdiploidy

  • This term refers to the presence of more than the normal number of chromosomes in the leukemia cells. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favorable prognosis in pediatric ALL. Children with hyperdiploid ALL tend to respond better to treatment and have a higher chance of achieving long-term remission.

Option B: Organomegaly

  • The presence of organomegaly (enlarged organs) is generally a poor prognostic factor in ALL, as it may indicate a more advanced or aggressive form of the disease.

Option C: TLC more than 50,000/uL

  • A high TLC count carries the worst prognosis
  • However, if the TLC count is low, the prognosis is good.

Option D: Early response to treatment

  • While early response to treatment is important, it alone is not the best prognostic factor. It is an important clinical parameter, but hyperdiploidy has been shown to have a stronger association with favorable outcomes in pediatric ALL.

questions.text: A five-day-old, full-term male infant was severely cyanotic at birth. He had respiratory difficulty, with a respiratory rate of 65/min. On auscultation, a single loud S1 was heard. His chest X-ray showed an 'Egg-on-string' appearance. Prostaglandin E1 was administered initially, and later balloon atrial septostomy was done which showed improvement in oxygenation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this infant?
questions.solution:
Option B: Transposition of Great Arteries

  • This patient with tachypnea, respiratory distress and post-natal cyanosis are most likely suffering from TGA.
  • TGA is caused by failure of spiralling of the aorticopulmonary septum.
  • Chest X-ray shows a characteristic “egg-on-string” appearance and ECG shows right axis deviation.

Option A: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Most common congenital cyanotic heart disease in children
  • It has 4 components:
    1. Large, unrestricted VSD
    2. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis
    3. Overriding of aorta
    4. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart and pulmonary oligemia
  • ECG shows right axis deviation and a dominant R wave in the right precordial chest leads or an RSR′ pattern.

Option C: Truncus Arteriosus

  • A single arterial trunk (truncus arteriosus) arises from the heart and supplies the systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations. A VSD is always present
  • It is a total mixing lesion with complete mixing of pulmonary and systemic blood
  • Chest x-ray shows Cardiac enlargement due to the prominence of both ventricles, a high bulge left of the aortic knob (produced by the main or left pulmonary artery) and increased pulmonary vascularity
  • In truncus arteriosus, the aortic arch is right-sided in 50% of patients.

Option D: Tricuspid Atresia

  • Congenital absence of tricuspid valve. The right ventricle is hypoplastic
  • Systemic venous return reaching the right atrium reaches the left atrium through an atrial defect & reaches the left ventricle resulting in their hypertrophy due to overload
  • Complete mixing of systemic & pulmonary venous blood is seen in the left atrium
  • Symptoms include cyanosis at birth, holosystolic murmurs audible along the left sternal border, single 2nd heart sound.
  • Congenital cyanotic heart disease with Left axis deviation on ECG
  • The treatment of choice is surgical repair by Modified Fontan operation

questions.text: A premature newborn of 34 weeks is delivered at home. The mother had no antenatal care. The newborn is brought to the clinic after bullous lesions develop on his skin.  An X-ray reveals periostitis. What should be the next investigation?
questions.solution:
Option A: VDRL for mother & baby

  • Bullous lesions and periostitis are specific findings of congenital syphilis. Therefore, VDRL is done for the mother & baby.

Option B: ELISA for HIV

  • If the mother is HIV positive, 100% of children will test positive at birth. About 20% of these will remain HIV positive at one year of age.

  • Many patients will develop low-grade fevers, chronic fatigue, and general weakness. HIV may also cause a combination of food malabsorption, loss of appetite, and increased metabolism that contribute to AIDS wasting

  • There is a rise in the frequency of opportunistic infections and cancers.

Option C: PCR for Tuberculosis

  • The most common manifestations of congenital tuberculosis are poor appetite, fever, irritability, hypoplasia, weight loss, cough, respiratory distress, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and abdominal distention.

Option D: Hepatitis surface antigen for mother

  • Congenital hepatitis B presents jaundice, vomiting, dark urine, and low-grade fever

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with a complaint of ear pain (otalgia) and greenish-black discharge. On otoscopic examination, the patient has marked tenderness with multiple granulations in the external auditory canal. The culture of the discharge turns out to be Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following is the best prognostic test for the follow-up of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gallium (Ga-67) Scan is correct

  • This patient is presented with necrotising otitis externa, an inflammatory condition most commonly caused by Pseudomonas infection.

  • It is found in elderly diabetics or immunocompromised patients (immunosuppressive therapy patients with cancer, AIDs, etc.)
  • The main symptoms, as described in the above scenario, are excruciating pain and granulations in the external ear.
  • Diagnosis is made by history and examination, and culture is done to confirm the presence of Pseudomonas.
  • CT scan can be done to check for any necrosis of bones, but Gallium-67 is more useful in the patient's follow-up; it is repeated every three weeks to check the response of the treatment. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells and indicates soft tissue infection.
  • If untreated, malignant otitis externa can cause facial palsy, and infection may spread to the skull base causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • The mainstay of the treatment is controlling blood sugar levels, toileting the ear canal, and removing all granulations, dead tissue debris, or bone, along with antibiotics.
  • Antibiotics found effective are:
    • Gentamicin combined with Ticarcillin.
    • Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime.
    • Ciprofloxacin, Ofloxacin, and Levofloxacin.

Option A: Technetium 99m Scan

  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or more and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Option C:  MRI temporal bone

  • The role of MRI remains unclear in the follow-up of malignant otitis externa.

Option D: CECT Temporal bone

  • CT scan may show bony destruction but is often not helpful.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought in by his parents reporting eight episodes of acute otitis media in the last 6 months and has difficulty resolving the effusions between infections. He had low birth weight and had been on broad-spectrum antibiotics with every episode of infection. His examination along with mucus fluid in the middle ear. Further examination revealed hypertrophied adenoids. His elder brother suffered from recurrent upper respiratory tract infections leading to acute otitis media in the past. What should be done to effectively eliminate the infections?

choices.text: Continuing treating each infection as it arises
Child should be operated for Adenoidectomy

questions.solution:
Option D: Child should be operated for adenoidectomy

  • It is a true statement.
  • It is a case of serous otitis media which is a long-standing collection of serous or mucoid fluid in the middle ear.
  • Adenoid hypertrophy can lead to recurrent acute otitis media with effusion.
  • It may be a result of eustachian tube dysfunction due to hypertrophy of adenoids.
  • Mechanical obstruction of the eustachian tube due to hypertrophy of adenoids causes a negative pressure in the middle ear and plays a key role as a reservoir for infection in the upper respiratory tract with swelling of the pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube.
  • Serous otitis media presents as ear pain, fullness in the ear, hearing loss, and tinnitus.
  • Treatment includes medical as well as surgical options.
  • The mainstay of treatment is the restoration of nasal ventilation by giving education to improve nose-blowing or adenoidectomy,
  • and maintenance of eustachian tube patency with steroid nasal decongestants and mucolytic agents to restore middle ear functioning.
  • Nasal decongestants can help can help but may necessitate a myringotomy.
  • The most common indications for adenoidectomy are recurrent upper airway infections, acute otitis media, serous otitis media with non-resolving effusion, and adenoid hypertrophy.

 Option A: Continuing treating each infection as it arises

  • It is a false statement.
  • There will be recurrent bouts of serous otitis media as adenoids causes mechanical obstruction of the eustachian tube leading to a buildup of fluid in the eardrum.
  • Repeated treatment with antibiotic therapy may lead to resistance.

 

Option B: Place ventilating tubes

  • It is a false statement.
  • An ear ventilation tube is placed in the eardrum. It's also called a myringotomy tube, vent tubes allow the fluid trapped behind the eardrum drain, but have no role in recurrent infections as in adenoid hypertrophy.

Option C: Prescribe prophylactic antibiotics for 6 months

  • It is a false statement.
  • Prescribing antibiotics in 5-year-old children are not favorable as there us an increased rise of antibiotic resistance.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics will not prevent the recurrent infections caused by adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a previous history of myocardial infarction presented with nasal discharge. The patient is currently on maintenance therapy for his myocardial infarction. The patient also has a history of intense itching and sneezing when gardening on his lawn. On examination, the nasal cavity has numerous polyps. Which of the following triad is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Samter's triad

  • This patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction is likely taking aspirin as a maintenance medication. His aspirin usage, allergic history, and the presence of nasal polyps on examination give a clue to Samter's triad.
  • Thirty-six percent of the patients with aspirin intolerance may show polyps.
  • Samter’s triad or aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) consists of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin intolerance.
    • It is due to the shunting of arachidonic acid metabolites towards the leukotriene pathway.
    • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits the cyclooxygenase pathway of prostaglandin synthesis. This blockage leads to a backup of arachidonic acid metabolites. These metabolites are then shunted towards the leukotriene synthesis pathway.
    • Increased leukotriene production causes an allergic reaction characterised by nasal congestion, sneezing, and cough after using aspirin.
    • They are difficult to treat.

Option B: Trotter's triad.

  • Trotter’s triad consists of ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia involving the mandibular division of the 5th cranial nerve.
  • Ipsilateral palatal palsy leads to palatal asymmetry due to 10th cranial nerve involvement.
  • Unilateral serous otitis media can lead to ipsilateral conductive hearing loss.

Option C: Sinus of Morgagni syndrome

  • Trotter's triad is present in the sinus of Morgagni syndrome.
  • It is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option D: Melkersson Rosenthal syndrome

  • This syndrome consists of swollen lips, fissured tongue, and recurrent facial palsy.
  • This syndrome is not related to asthma and aspirin use.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female of low socioeconomic status visits the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing for the last 3 months. On physical examination, she is pale and the typical laryngeal crepitus is absent. Which of the following conditions is characterized by the absence of laryngeal crepitus?
questions.solution:
Option B: Post cricoid malignancy

  • Laryngeal crepitus is a normal finding in the laryngeal examination. Laryngeal cartilages are held between the thumb and fingers and rubbed against the vertebral column. In a normal individual, it gives a gritty sensation. It is known as laryngeal crepitus. It is lost in post-cricoid growth or retropharyngeal abscess, as the larynx cannot be rubbed against the vertebral column.

Option A: Normal person

  • In a normal person laryngeal crepitus is present.
  • The laryngeal cartilages rub against the vertebral column to give the gritty sensation.

Option C: Carcinoma vocal cord

  • Laryngeal crepitus is present in vocal cord carcinoma.
  • The growth is not present between the laryngeal cartilages and the vertebral column. So, crepitus is present.

Option D: Carcinoma tonsil

  • Laryngeal crepitus is present in carcinoma tonsil.
  • There is no retropharyngeal growth preventing the rubbing of the laryngeal cartilages against the vertebral column.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came to the ENT outpatient department with the complaint of ear discharge for 3 months with pain behind his eyes. The patient also has double vision. On physical examination, the vitals of the patient is within normal range. Based on the given information, which of the following is the most probable diagnosis related to the complications of the disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Petrositis

  • Three months' history of discharge says the case is otitis media which is chronic.
  • The above clinical features are seen in petrositis, which is one of the intra-temporal complications of otitis media.
  • The syndrome depicted here is the Gradenigo syndrome.
  • Gradenigo syndrome: Long-standing discharge, deep-seated retro-orbital pain, diplopia of lateral gaze -due to the involvement of the 6th cranial nerve.

Petrositis:

  • The spread of infection from the middle ear and mastoid to the petrous part of the temporal bone is called petrositis.
  • It may be associated with acute coalescent mastoiditis, latent mastoiditis, or chronic middle ear infections.
  • Pathology like mastoid and petrous bone may be of three types: pneumatized with air cells extending to the petrous apex, diploic containing only marrow spaces, and sclerotic.
  • Pneumatization of the petrous apex occurs in only 30% of cases, with cells extending from the middle ear or mastoid to the petrous apex.
  • The pathological process is similar to coalescent mastoiditis forming epidural abscess at the petrous apex involving cranial nerve VI and trigeminal ganglion.
  • Diagnosis of petrositis requires both a CT scan and MRI.
  • CT scan of the temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells, while MRI helps to differentiate the diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.
  • Treatment Cortical, modified radical or radical mastoidectomy is often required if not already done.

Option A: Tympanic membrane perforation

  • A common complication of AOM- is tympanic membrane perforation, but the above said symptoms are not seen in perforation.
  • There is tinnitus, sudden hearing loss, high temperature and ear discharge can be seen in tympanic membrane perforation.

Option C: Labyrinthitis

  • Circumscribed labyrinthitis (fistula of the labyrinth) is thinning or erosion of the bony capsule of the labyrinth, usually of the horizontal semicircular canal.
  • Clinical features. A part of the membranous labyrinth is exposed and becomes sensitive to pressure changes.
  • The patient complains of transient vertigo often induced by pressure on the tragus, cleaning the ear, or while performing a Valsalva manoeuver.
  • But in the above case, there is no vertigo.

Option D: Lateral sinus thrombosis

  • The clinical features of lateral sinus thrombosis are pallor and headache.
  • Picket fence fever: Temperature does not come to normal baseline.
  • Griesinger’s sign: Griesinger’s sign is mastoid tenderness and oedema secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is done in type 4 thyroplasty?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lengthened.

Type 4 Thyroplasty:

  1. Lengthening (tightening) the cord to elevate the pitch (gender transformation from male to female), for example, as a treatment of androphobia
  2. Type IV thyroplasty involves the procedure used to lengthen (tighten) the vocal cord and elevate the pitch.
  3. It converts the male character of voice to female and has been used in gender transformation.
  4. It is also used when the vocal cord is lax and bowing due to the aging process or trauma.

Option A: Medially displaced

  • Occurs in type I thyroplasty by injection of gel foam/Teflon paste.

Option B: Laterally displaced

  • Occurs in type II thyroplasty, which is done to improve the airway.

Option D: Shortened

  • Occurs in type III thyroplasty in an attempt to relax the vocal cords to lower the pitch (gender transformation from female to male).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of epistaxis. After a series of treatments, the bleeding could not be stopped. His medical history is consistent with hypertension and diabetes. His medications include metformin and amlodipine. An attempt to block the external carotid artery is made which does not lead to resolution of the bleeding. Which of the following artery is responsible for the bleeding in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anterior Ethmoidal Artery

  • Both external and internal carotid arteries supply the nose through their branches.
  • The source of epistaxis after ligation of the external carotid artery is from the internal carotid branch, i.e., the anterior ethmoidal artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery ligation is considered for continued epistaxis uncontrolled by other means.
  • The anterior ethmoid artery is an extension of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery system.
  • As such, this is branch is unable to be addressed by embolization techniques.
  • If epistaxis is severe enough to consider addressing the anterior ethmoid artery, additional consideration of ligating the sphenopalatine artery should be entertained.
  • The posterior ethmoid artery, also a branch of the ophthalmic artery, is not routinely ligated due to its proximity to the optic nerve and inherent risk of injury to the nerve.
  • The anterior ethmoidal artery is identified via subperiostial elevation through a Lynch incision.
  • The artery is approximately 24mm from the anterior lacrimal crest and lies along the frontoethmoidal suture line. The following drawing demonstrates the artery as a distal branch of the ophthalmic artery.

Option A: Maxillary artery

  • The maxillary artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

Option B: Greater palatine artery

  • The greater palatine artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

Option C: Superior labial artery

  • The superior labial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with complaints of throat pain and difficulty swallowing. He has also experienced a change in voice. He is a non-smoker, non-alcoholic, and has never used illicit drugs. The examination findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Tip of uvula points towards the normal side
Ipsilateral ear ache occurs due to referred pain via the 10th cranial nerve
Trismus occurs due to spasm of pterygoid muscles

questions.solution:
Option C: Ipsilateral ear ache occurs due to referred pain via the 10th cranial nerve

  • This patient, with pain in the throat, difficulty in swallowing, a change in voice, and unilateral hypertrophy of the tonsil, most likely have Quinsy.
  • Ipsilateral otalgia associated with this condition is due to referred pain via the 9th cranial nerve.

Option A: Associated with Hot potato voice

  • Hot potato Voice/Change in voice is a symptom of Peritonsillar abscess.

Option B: Tip of the uvula points toward the normal side

  • Quinsy is characterized by unilateral hypertrophy of the tonsil, with the tonsil pushing the uvula and soft palate to another side; subsequently, the tip of the uvula points towards the normal side.

Option D: Trismus occurs due to spasm of pterygoid muscles

  • Trismus is a symptom of Peritonsillar abscess, which is due to spasm of medial pterygoids.

questions.text: A 30 years old lady who has been diagnosed with Multiple sclerosis presented with redness, blurred vision associated with floaters, and also pain in both eyes. On fundus examination, the following finding was noted (shown in the image). Your probable treatment would be?
questions.solution:
The fundus finding shown in the image is Snowball & snow banking appearance which is a feature of Intermediate uveitis

Intermediate uveitis

  • Causes: Idiopathic (MC); Sarcoidosis (2nd MC); Multiple sclerosis
  • Treatment:
    • Intravitreal or Posterior Sub Tenon's Steroid injections: Triamcinolone acetonide
    • Steroids may also be given by Subconjunctival route or by Sub Tenon's route

questions.text: A 27-year-old male is presents to the opd with episodes of blurry vision. His intraocular pressure is 25mmhg. On slit-lamp microscopy, intermittent halos with pigmentation are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pigmentary Glaucoma

  • It is secondary open-angle glaucoma due to pigment release in young male myopes who present with intermittent halos, an open angle and a Krukenberg spindle of pigment. Hence, this patient has pigmentary glaucoma.
  • These findings are visible on the corneal endothelium on slit-lamp microscopy.
  • Increased pigmentation in the trabecular meshwork seen as the Sampaolesi line on gonioscopy is also characteristic.
  • Symptoms:
    • Early: No obvious signs.
    • Later: Peripheral vision loss.
    • Advanced: Central vision loss.

Option A: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PFX or PEX) is an age-related systemic syndrome that targets mainly ocular tissues.
  • There is the gradual deposition of fibrillary white flaky material from the lens, mainly on the lens capsule, ciliary body, zonules, corneal endothelium, iris and pupillary margin.
  • It is caused by generalized fibrillopathy.
  •  It is linked to a broad spectrum of ocular complications, including glaucoma and perioperative problems during cataract surgery.

Option B: Phacolytic glaucoma

  • Phacolytic glaucoma is caused by an inflammatory process caused by the leakage of lens material through the capsule of a mature cataract.
  • The released lens material comprises altered lens protein, macrophages, and other inflammatory cells that lead to trabecular meshwork obstruction and precipitate glaucoma.
  • The typical presentation of phacolytic glaucoma is a painful eye with photophobia, decreased vision, and severe conjunctival hyperemia, often in an older patient with a history of poor vision.
  • The definitive treatment of phacolytic glaucoma (PG) is cataract extraction.
  •  Extracapsular cataract extraction (e.g., phacoemulsification) with an intraocular lens implant has largely replaced intracapsular cataract extraction as the procedure of choice.

Option D: Acute anterior uveitis

  • Sudden onset and limited duration characterize the acute disease.
  • The symptoms of acute anterior uveitis are pain, redness, and photophobia (sensitivity to light), which typically develop rapidly over a few days.
  •  The symptoms will resolve with appropriate anti-inflammatory therapy.
  • Viral infections are the most common infectious underlying etiology of anterior uveitis.
  •  Increased IOP, iris atrophy, and unilateral presentations are common with viral etiologies.

questions.text: A 42-years-old male patient presents to the physician with complaints of transient visual obscurations for 1 week. On examination, his vision was normal and no macular oedema. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. He is an occasional smoker and smokes one pack per week. The image given below shows the fundoscopic findings. What is the best management plan for this patient regarding his current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Wait and watch

  • This is a case of central retinal vein occlusion in which the patient presents with complaints of transient visual obscurations for 1 week.
  • On examination, his vision was normal and no macular oedema.
  • The image shows dilated tortuous retinal veins with sclerotic retinal arteries and associated retinal flame-shaped and dot-blot hemorrhages - suggestive of central retinal vein occlusion (called tomato splash appearance). The foveal reflex remains intact, which suggests the absence of Macular oedema.
  • It is a case of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion without macular oedema.
  • All the options provided are management modalities:
    • Wait, and Watch (Observation) is the first line of management in CVRO.
    • If visual acuity is 6/9 or better, improving without macular oedema.
    • Management of Systemic and Ocular co-morbidities and risk factors.

Option B: Intravitreal Ranibizumab

  • Intravitreal Anti-VEGF, such as Ranibizumab, is useful in cases with macular oedema.

Option C: Pan retinal photocoagulation

  • This is the most important step in the management of CRVO.
  • In cases of ischemic CRVO with neovascularization at disc/elsewhere/iris (NVD/NVE/NVI), scatter pan-retinal photocoagulation is done to reduce metabolic demand of the retina and thereby allow for regression of the neovascularization.

Option D: Intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide

  • Intravitreal Triamcinolone acetonide is useful in cases with macular oedema as an alternative to Anti-VEGFs.
  • Intravitreal dexamethasone implant is an alternative for a more sustained effect.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents to the emergency department due to sudden severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, and with no light perception. The rest of the examination, including pupillary reflexes, fundus, and optokinetic nystagmus, is normal. She could approximate the tips of her index fingers with the right eye closed but not with the left eye closed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Functional visual loss

  • Functional visual loss is vision loss without any organic cause.
  • They can be divided into three categories:
  • Somatoform disorders
  • Factitious disorders
  • Malingering
  • Appropriate history and physical exam would help in ruling out any organic cause
  • Accommodation, pupillary light reflex, and optokinetic test are normal.
  • A person with functional blindness cannot touch the tips of the index fingers together, while those with an organic cause of vision loss can.
  • Normal visual evoked potentials will confirm the presence of a functional cause.

Option A: Optic neuritis

  • Optic neuritis is characterised by acute unilateral painful vision loss due to an inflammatory and demyelinating disease of the optic nerve.
  • It is usually seen in multiple sclerosis.
  • Signs and symptoms include impaired vision, colour vision, dark adaptation, relative afferent pupillary defect, fundus normal or papilledema, and visual evoked response showing decreased amplitude.
  • A normal pupillary reflex makes optic neuritis less likely in this patient.

Option B: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

  • Anterior ischemic Optic Neuropathy (AION) refers to ischemia of the optic nerve head from blockage of the short posterior ciliary arteries.
  • It is of two types: arteritic and non-arteritic.
  • Signs and symptoms may include marked vision loss, relative afferent pupillary defect, optic disc swelling and pallor, cotton wool spots, and splinter hemorrhages.
  • A normal pupillary reflex and normal fundus examination make AION less likely in this patient.

Option C: CMV retinitis

  • Cytomegalovirus retinitis usually occurs in immunosuppressed patients (AIDS patients, long-term immunosuppression following organ transplantation).
  • Fundoscopic examination shows yellow-white exudates with perivascular sheathing and retinal hemorrhages, giving it a pizza pie appearance.

questions.text: A patient came to eye OPD with disc-shaped edema over the cornea and a history of vesicles over lips a few weeks back. There is no ulcer on the staining. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Disciform viral keratitis

  • HSV infection can cause inflammation in nearly every ocular tissue. In cases of corneal involvement, the epithelium, stroma, or endothelium may be affected. Both herpes stromal keratitis (HSK) and HSV endothelins can present clinically with stromal opacity and, therefore, may be difficult to distinguish. In HSK, stromal opacity is due to immunopathology within the stroma, is often associated with corneal neovascularization, and recurrent episodes can lead to irreversible stromal scarring and vision loss.
  • In HSV endothelitis, either secondary inflammation caused by the virus and/or direct infection of endothelial cells is thought to cause endothelial dysfunction and subsequent stromal edema and opacity. Stromal scarring from true endothelitis is rare. While the presentation may appear similar between HSK and HSV endothelins, they represent two distinct pathologic mechanisms that are both induced by HSV infection.

Option B: Marginal ulcer

  • Marginal keratitis is an inflammatory disease of the peripheral cornea characterized by peripheral stromal infiltrates, which are often associated with epithelium breakdown and ulceration.
  • It is usually associated with the presence of blepharoconjunctivitis and is thought to represent an inflammatory response against S. aureus antigens.
  • This patient presents with features of disciform viral keratitis.

Option C: Metaherpetiform keratitis

  • Metaherpetic corneal disease = chronic or chronic recurrent superficial postherpetic disease without any detectable HSV activity  (main types: metaherpetic erosion, metaherpetic ulcer, metaherpetic bullous keratopathy). One of four superficial herpetic corneal diseases proved to be nonviral, i.e. metaherpetic in our series.
  • Metaherpetic diseases may be widely considered a therapeutic entity. The differential diagnosis with the slitlamp only.

Option D: Fungal Keratitis

  • Fungal keratitis is an infection of the cornea that is caused by a fungus. Some fungi that can cause fungal keratitis include:
    • Fusarium species
    • Aspergillus species
    • Candida species
  • Symptoms of fungal keratitis include:
    • Eye pain
    • Eye redness
    • Blurred vision
    • Sensitivity to light
    • Excessive tearing
    • Eye discharge.
  • Thus, this patient does not have fungal keratitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being suddenly hit by a ball in the left eye. He complained of pain and redness in the left eye. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On ocular examination, there was no perforation of the eyeball, and there was no intraocular foreign body. Which of the following investigation should be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gonioscopy

  • This is a case of blunt trauma of the left eye in which the patient presents to the emergency department after being suddenly hit by a ball on the left eye.
  • The patient only complained of pain and redness in the left eye. He doesn’t complain of any bleeding, which suggests blunt trauma.
  • The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • On examination of the patient’s eye, there is no penetrating wound or any intraocular foreign body.
  • Multifocal ERG is not required in a patient with recent blunt trauma.

Investigations Needed

  • Gonioscopy
  • Indirect ophthalmology
  • CT Head and orbit to rule out any bony injury.
  • Ultrasound in case of vitreous hemorrhage.

Option B: Multifocal ERG

  • Electroretinogram (ERG) - very sensitive in the diagnosis of metallosis bulbi, which may be characterized by a decrease in b wave amplitude and complete flattening of ERG in advanced cases.

Option C: Slit lamp examination

  • The slit lamp examination is not used in cases of blunt trauma.
  • It is used for the evaluation of the intraocular foreign body.

Option D: B mode ultrasound

  • Ultrasound - gives a general idea of the presence and relative position of IOFB, especially in patients with hazy media.
  • B mode ultrasonography.
  • UBM (Ultrasound biomicroscopy) - for obscured IOFB hidden in the anterior chamber or angle.

questions.text: A forty-five year old man presents to your clinic with the complaint of gradually progressive, painless diminution of vision in both eyes for 3 months. Slit-lamp examination of the eyes shows an anterior subcapsular cataract, and the patient is scheduled for a cataract removal surgery. The surgery is complicated by the rupture of the posterior capsule. All of the following complications can be expected in this patient due to rupture of the posterior capsule, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Angle recession

  • A cataract is the opacification of the lens, which causes decreased vision.
  • This is mostly due to ageing.
  • Treatment of a cataract is the surgical removal of the lens and replacement with an intraocular lens (IOL).
  • A breach in the posterior capsule of the lens during surgery is known as posterior capsular rupture.
  • Complications of posterior capsular rupture include:
    • Vitreous loss
    • Dislocation of IOL
    • Glaucoma
    • Endophthalmitis
    • Uveitis
    • Pupillary peaking
    • Macular edema
    • Retinal detachment
    • Cystoid macular edema
  • Angle recession is not a complication of posterior capsule rupture.

Option A: Retinal detachment

  • Retinal detachment is a complication of posterior capsular rupture.

Option B: Macular edema

  • Macular edema is a complication of posterior capsular rupture.

Option C: Dislocation of intraocular lens

  • Dislocation of the intraocular lens is a complication of posterior capsular rupture.

questions.text: A 27-year-old, 38 weeks pregnant woman with a height of 130 cm and a weight of 51 kg diagnosed with cephalopelvic disproportion with fetal distress has been admitted for the emergency cesarean section. A lower segment cesarean section is performed, and a live male infant of 1.8 kg with an APGAR of 8/9 is delivered. Which of the following would be expected in the eyes of the newborn?
questions.solution:
Option B:Hypermetropia

  • At birth, the eye is hypermetropic by +2 to +3D and usually becomes emmetropic by the age of 5 to 7 years.
  • This is because of the smaller eyeball.
  • Eyeball length at birth is 16mm.

Hypermetropia:

  • It is that dioptric condition of the eye in which, with the accommodation at rest, the incident parallel rays of light come to a focus posterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina.
  • Newborns are invariably hypermetropic (average 2.5 D).
  • The incidence decreases rapidly, with age remaining at about 50% after 20 years.
  • Etiology:
    1. Axial: due to short length of the eyeball.
    2. Curvature: due to flat curvature of the cornea.
    3. Index: due to an increase in the refractive index of the cortex, e.g., as in diabetic and senile cortical cataracts.
    4. Positional: due to backward displacement of the lens as in posterior dislocation.
    5. Absence of lens or aphakia: It is a classic example of acquired high hypermetropia.
  • Types: Total hypermetropia may be divided into:
    1. Latent hypermetropia is overcome by the normal tone of the ciliary muscle. It is detected only when the ciliary muscle is paralyzed by atropine.
    2. Manifest hypermetropia—It is detected without paralyzing the ciliary muscle.
      • Facultative: It can be overcome by an effort of accommodation.
      • Absolute: It cannot be overcome by an effort of accommodation.
  • Treatment: It is treated by prescribing suitable correcting spherical convex lenses.

Option A: Hypermetropic with regular astigmatism

  • Astigmatism is an abnormal condition of the eye.
  • Normally the cornea is flatter from side to side (horizontal meridian), perhaps because of the pressure of the eyelids. It is curved downwards (vertical meridian).
  • Regular astigmatism is present when the two principal meridians are at right angles.

Option C: Hypermetropic with irregular astigmatism

  • It is present when the corneal surface is irregular.
  • It cannot be adequately corrected by lenses, e.g., following healed corneal ulcer.
  • A soft contact lens may be used. Partial or full-thickness keratoplasty may be done depending on the opacity depth as the last resort.

Option D: Myopia

  • It is that dioptric condition of the eye in which, with the accommodation at rest, incident parallel rays of light come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina.
  • Not present at birth.

questions.text:
A 1-month-old baby presents a 2-week history of a red, slightly raised plaque on the left forehead, periorbital area, and malar cheek with a rim of vasoconstriction around it. A similar image of the lesion from another case is given below: 



The lesion has been thickening each day per mm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option D: Echocardiography

  • If hemangiomas are present in the facial/segmental region (as in this patient), perform echocardiography and MRI of the head.
  • Infantile or strawberry hemangioma is a benign capillary vascular tumor of infancy (mostly girls), which occurs in 3–10% of infants.
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal development of vascular endothelial cells.
  • Prognosis: Rapid proliferation followed by subsequent spontaneous slow involution (occurring at the age of 5–8 years). Complications include ulceration and disfigurement. Visual impairment if the periorbital hemangioma is left untreated.
  • Infantile hemangioma is also associated with PHACES syndrome:
    • P- Posterior fossa and other structural brain malformations;
    • H-Hemangioma - Extensive plaques that appear to occupy one or more facial dermatomes and may initially be mistaken for port-wine stains. They may be either unilateral or bilateral. Ulceration is common.
    • Arterial anomalies of cervical and cerebral vessels.
    • C-Cardiac defects (especially coarctation of the aorta).
    • E-Eye anomalies.
    • S-Sternal defects and supraumbilical raphe.
  • Special considerations while evaluating infantile hemangioma are:If >5 cutaneous hemangiomas, perform a liver ultrasound.
    1. Facial/segmental hemangiomas (as in this patient), perform echocardiography and MRI of the head (PHACES syndrome)
    2. If cervicofacial (beard) hemangioma, perform laryngoscopy.
    3. If lumbosacral hemangioma, perform spinal ultrasound.

Option A: Spinal ultrasound

  • If the hemangioma is present in the lumbosacral region, perform a spinal ultrasound.

Option B: Liver ultrasound

  • If >5 hemangiomas are present, then perform a liver ultrasound.

Option C: Laryngoscopy

  • If the hemangioma is present in the beard region, perform a laryngoscopy.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old Asian male presents to the dermatologic clinic for the evaluation of a lesion on the right sole of the foot. He states that the lesion has been present for the past many years, but now it seems to be enlarging. On examination, irregular, hyperpigmented plaque on his right sole is seen as shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acral lentiginous melanoma

  • This patient with a hyper-pigmented plaque on the sole most likely has acral lentiginous Melanoma.
  • The acral lentiginous subtype accounts for less than 5 percent of all melanomas. However, it is the most common type of Melanoma among darker-pigmented individuals (60 to 72 percent in African Americans and 29 to 46 percent in Asians), who are at lower risk for more sun-related melanoma subtypes.
  • Acral lentiginous melanomas commonly arise on palmar, plantar, and subungual surfaces (beneath the nail plate).
  • Acral lentiginous melanomas first appear as dark brown to black, irregularly pigmented macules or patches, with raised areas, ulceration, bleeding, and larger diameter generally signifying deeper invasion in the dermis.
  • Occasionally, acral melanoma can present as amelanotic or hypomelanotic lesions mimicking benign diseases, such as warts, calluses, tinea pedis, nonhealing ulcers, or ingrown toenails.
  • Visual analysis and pattern recognition typically assess whether a given pigmented lesion has one or more features that may suggest Melanoma, including asymmetry, irregular borders, variegated color, and diameter >6 mm.
  • These features have been included in the widely adopted ABCDE (asymmetry, border irregularity, color variegation, diameter >6 mm, evolution) checklist, a clinical prediction rule devised to help clinicians and laypeople identify suspicious lesions.

Option B: Nodular melanoma

  • Nodular Melanoma is the second most common type, accounting for 15 to 30 percent of all melanomas.
  • They may appear darkly pigmented, pedunculated, or polypoid papules or nodules but frequently present with a uniform color or amelanotic/pink hue, symmetric borders, and a relatively small diameter, making early detection difficult.

Option C: Lentigo maligna melanoma

  • Lentigo maligna melanoma most commonly arises in chronically sun-damaged areas of the skin in older individuals and begins as a tan or brown macule.
  • The lesion gradually enlarges over the years and may develop darker, asymmetric foci of pigmentation, color variegation, and raised areas that signify vertical growth within the precursor in situ melanoma, termed "lentigo maligna."

Option D: Superficial spreading melanoma

  • Superficial spreading Melanoma typically presents as a variably pigmented macule or thin plaque with an irregular border, ranging from a few millimeters to several centimeters in diameter.
  • Lesions may have multiple shades of brown, red, blue, black, gray, and white.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a complaint of fever for the past day. His mother states that her child has also developed multiple skin lesions on the face and upper extremities. On examination, the following lesions are noted as shown below:



Microscopic examination of the skin lesions shows neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sweet syndrome

  • Sweet syndrome (acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis) is an uncommon inflammatory disorder characterized by the abrupt appearance of painful, edematous, and erythematous papules, plaques, or nodules on the skin.
  • Fever and leukocytosis frequently accompany the cutaneous lesions. In addition, involvement of the eyes, musculoskeletal system, and internal organs may occur.

  • The cutaneous lesions of Sweet syndrome typically present as tender, edematous, and inflamed papules, plaques, and nodules. Lesions are usually several millimeters to several centimeters in diameter and exhibit a brightly erythematous or violaceous color.
  • Bullous Sweet syndrome is an uncommon presentation of Sweet syndrome in which vesicles and flaccid bullae are overly erythematous to violaceous plaques. Ulceration resembling pyoderma gangrenosum may occur in bullous Sweet syndrome; this manifestation most commonly occurs in the setting of hematologic malignancy.
  • Histopathological findings: Neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis.
  • Drug of choice: Oral Corticosteroids.

Option B: Behçet syndrome

  • It Is also known as Behçet disease, is characterized by recurrent oral aphthae and several systemic manifestations, including genital aphthae, ocular disease, skin lesions, gastrointestinal involvement, neurologic disease, vascular disease, or arthritis.
  • This patient's clinical features are typical of sweet syndrome.

Option C:Pyoderma gangrenosum

  • PG is an uncommon neutrophilic dermatosis that presents as an inflammatory and ulcerative disorder of the skin.
  • The most common presentation of PG is an inflammatory papule or pustule that progresses to a painful ulcer with a violaceous undermined border and a purulent base.
  • Ulceration resembling pyoderma gangrenosum may occur in bullous Sweet syndrome; this manifestation most commonly occurs in the setting of hematologic malignancy.

Option D: Juvenile dermatomyositis

  • It is an inflammatory disease of the muscle (myositis), skin (derma-), and blood vessels that affects about three in one million. Most patients with JDM experience muscle weakness and skin rash.
  • All age and ethnic groups are affected. This patient most likely has Sweet syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient with a family history of allergy presents with a rapidly evolving red rash involving the back of knees and wrists. Histopathological examination of the skin shows a finding known as spongiosis, as shown in the image below. Is it characterized by one of the following?

choices.text: Retention of nuclei in stratum corneum

questions.solution:
Option B: Extracellular edema

  • In spongiosis, there is the extracellular accumulation of fluid in stratum spinosum, characterized by widening intercellular spaces, i.e., Acute eczema.
  • This leads to the diminution and rounding of keratinocytes (condensation) and widening intercellular spaces resulting in a sponge like appearance of the epidermis that can lead to the formation of small intraepidermal vesicles.

Option A: Retention of nuclei in stratum corneum.

  • Parakeratosis is characterized by the retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum.
  • It is usually seen in Psoriasis.

Option C: Thickening of stratum spinosum

  • Acanthosis is characterized by the hyperplasia of stratum spinosum
  • It is usually seen in acanthosis nigricans and seborrheic dermatitis

Option D: Loss of cohesion between cells

  • Acantholysis is characterized by the loss of cohesion of epidermal cells
  • It is usually seen in pemphigus Vulgaris
